summary_llm:
The play opens on Christmas Eve in the comfortably furnished home of Nora and Torvald Helmer. Nora, in high spirits, returns with Christmas gifts, playfully defying her husband Torvald's rule by secretly eating macaroons. Torvald, who has just been promoted to Bank Manager, addresses Nora with affectionate but diminishing pet names like "little lark" and "little squirrel," and scolds her for being a "spendthrift." He prides himself on avoiding debt and maintaining a respectable home. Nora, however, expresses joy at their newfound financial security, hinting that their "hard times" are over.

Their conversation is interrupted by the arrival of Mrs. Linde, an old school friend of Nora's, who has come to town seeking work after years of hardship. Mrs. Linde is a widow who previously married for financial security to support her sick mother and younger brothers, but was left with nothing after her husband's death. Nora, eager to help, promises to speak to Torvald about finding her a position at the bank.

In a moment of confidence, Nora reveals her biggest secret to Mrs. Linde: eight years ago, when Torvald was gravely ill, doctors advised a year in Italy. Torvald believed the money came from Nora's dying father, but Nora confesses she procured the 250 pounds by forging her father's signature on a loan bond with lawyer Nils Krogstad. She has since been secretly repaying the debt through odd jobs and careful household budgeting, hiding her efforts from Torvald, who would have been humiliated by owing her money and by her taking on debt. She has been looking forward to the New Year when Torvald's new salary would allow her to finally pay off the remaining debt and be "free from care."

Shortly after, Krogstad arrives to speak with Torvald about bank business. Mrs. Linde is visibly distressed upon seeing him, revealing a past connection between them. Doctor Rank, a close family friend who visits daily, also arrives and exits Torvald's study, referring to Krogstad as having a "diseased moral character."

Krogstad confronts Nora, revealing that Torvald intends to dismiss him from his post at the bank and give it to Mrs. Linde. He pressures Nora to use her influence to keep him on staff, threatening to expose her forgery. Nora, initially defiant, is terrified when Krogstad presents the bond, pointing out that her father's signature was dated three days after his death. Nora confesses to the forgery, explaining she did it to save Torvald's life and couldn't burden her dying father with the truth or disclose Torvald's critical condition to him. Krogstad warns her that "the law cares nothing about motives" and that if he loses his position, she will "lose yours with me." After Krogstad leaves, Nora is consumed by fear, particularly after Torvald's earlier pronouncement that a deceitful parent "poisons the whole life of a home" and infects their children. She stops her children from coming near her.

Act II begins with Nora’s growing anxiety. She considers fleeing and questions the nurse about whether children forget their mothers. Mrs. Linde returns to help Nora mend her Tarantella dress for the upcoming fancy-dress ball. Nora reveals to Mrs. Linde that Doctor Rank is dying from a hereditary spinal disease, a consequence of his father's dissolute life. Mrs. Linde suspects Doctor Rank might be Nora's secret lender, which Nora denies.

Nora attempts to ask Doctor Rank for help with her "tremendously big favour," believing he is her truest friend. However, before she can reveal her predicament, Doctor Rank confesses his deep love for her. His confession makes it impossible for Nora to ask him for such a personal sacrifice, as it would be exploiting his feelings.

Krogstad reappears, having learned of his dismissal. He informs Nora that he has sent a letter detailing her forgery to Torvald. He now demands not money, but a higher position at the bank, asserting that he will become Torvald's "right hand." He implies that if Nora were to take extreme measures, it would be futile, as he would still have power over Torvald. Krogstad drops the letter into the Helmers' locked letter-box and leaves.

Nora is distraught, seeing the letter through the glass. Mrs. Linde, learning the full extent of Nora's crime, offers to intercede with Krogstad, revealing her own past relationship with him. To delay Torvald from reading the letter, Nora frantically begs him to help her practice her Tarantella dance, insisting he focus entirely on her and not open any mail until after the ball. Torvald, flattered, agrees, amused by her "childish nervousness."

In Act III, Mrs. Linde waits for Krogstad at the Helmers' home after the ball. When he arrives, she explains why she left him years ago: she sacrificed her personal feelings for him to support her family. Now, her family no longer needs her, and she feels "unspeakably empty." She proposes they reunite, suggesting they need each other and that she can be a mother to his children. Krogstad is overjoyed and believes they can now build a life together and clear his name. He wants to retrieve his letter from Torvald's letter-box. However, Mrs. Linde persuades him not to, explaining that she has witnessed "incredible things in this house" and believes the "unhappy secret must be disclosed" to force a complete understanding between Nora and Torvald, free from concealment and falsehood. She takes responsibility for leaving the letter.

Torvald and Nora return from the ball. Torvald is flushed with desire, playfully dominating Nora and boasting about her success at the dance. He expresses his longing to be alone with her, but Nora, repulsed, resists his advances. Doctor Rank then makes a final, sombre visit. He hands Torvald two cards with black crosses on them, signifying his imminent death and his intention to withdraw and die alone.

After Rank leaves, Torvald checks the letter-box, despite Nora's desperate attempts to distract him. He finds Krogstad's letter and reads it. Enraged, he condemns Nora as a "hypocrite, a liar—worse, worse—a criminal!" He rails against her "father's want of principle" and declares she has destroyed his happiness and ruined his future by placing him under Krogstad's power. He locks the hall door, telling her she will remain in the house but will not be allowed to raise their children, stating their marriage will continue only "in the eyes of the world" to preserve appearances.

Just then, the maid delivers a second letter to Nora. Torvald snatches it and reads it. His fury instantly turns to overwhelming joy: Krogstad has returned the bond, expressing regret and repenting, due to "a happy change in his life" (his reconciliation with Mrs. Linde). Torvald tears up both letters and the bond, burning them in the stove, declaring they are "saved" and "it's all over!" He forgives Nora, rationalizing her actions as misguided love and her "womanly helplessness" as making her "doubly attractive." He expects life to return to normal, promising to shelter and guide his "scared, helpless darling."

However, Nora, having changed into her everyday clothes, tells Torvald they need to have a "serious conversation"—their first in eight years of marriage. She asserts that he has never understood her and that she has been "greatly wronged" by both her father and him. She explains that she has lived as his "doll-wife," just as she was her "papa's doll-child," merely performing tricks and making nothing of her life. She confesses she has never been truly happy, only merry.

Nora reveals that the "wonderful thing" she had hoped for—Torvald taking all the blame and responsibility for her crime—did not happen. His reaction revealed he would sacrifice her honor, but not his own. She realizes she has been living with a "strange man" and can no longer be his wife. She declares she must leave to "educate myself" and "understand myself and everything about me." Torvald protests, forbidding her to leave and emphasizing her "sacred duties" as a wife and mother. Nora counters that she has "other duties just as sacred"—duties to herself—and that she must learn to think for herself, rather than accepting society's or his views. She no longer believes in his understanding of religion or law, finding them unjust to women.

She calmly states she no longer loves him. Torvald is aghast. Nora explains that her eight years of waiting for him to prove himself the man she thought he was culminated tonight, and he failed. She returns her wedding ring and demands his, setting them both free from all obligations. She states she will not see the children, believing they are in "better hands" now. When Torvald asks if she could ever be more than a stranger, Nora replies that the "most wonderful thing of all" would have to happen: "Both you and I would have to be so changed that... our life together would be a real wedlock." She says goodbye and leaves, shutting the door behind her, leaving Torvald alone with a glimmer of hope for "the most wonderful thing of all."

summary_llm:
This detailed summary recounts the plot of "Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland" based solely on the provided text.

The story begins with **Alice**, who is bored sitting on a riverbank with her sister, who is reading a book without pictures or conversations. As Alice contemplates whether to make a daisy-chain, a **White Rabbit with pink eyes** suddenly runs past, exclaiming, "Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!" Alice is intrigued when the Rabbit takes a watch out of its waistcoat-pocket and hurries on. Burning with curiosity, Alice follows the Rabbit down a large rabbit-hole without considering how she will get out.

The rabbit-hole plunges suddenly into a very deep well. As Alice falls, she observes cupboards, book-shelves, maps, and pictures adorning the sides. She takes down an empty jar of "ORANGE MARMALADE" and places it in a cupboard. During her long descent, she muses about her location (the center of the earth, New Zealand or Australia) and talks aloud to herself about her cat, Dinah. The fall finally ends as she lands unhurt on a heap of sticks and dry leaves.

Alice jumps up and sees the White Rabbit still hurrying along a long passage, muttering about being late. She follows closely but loses sight of him when she turns a corner, finding herself in a long, low hall lit by lamps. All the doors in the hall are locked. She discovers a tiny golden key on a three-legged glass table, but it is too small for any of the visible doors. However, she then finds a small door, about fifteen inches high, hidden behind a low curtain. The golden key fits this lock.

Alice opens the tiny door and sees a beautiful garden, but she is too large to fit through. She wishes she could shrink "like a telescope." Returning to the table, she finds a bottle labeled "DRINK ME." After prudently checking that it is not marked "poison," she tastes it. Finding its mixed flavor (cherry-tart, custard, pine-apple, roast turkey, toffee, and hot buttered toast) very pleasant, she drinks it all. This causes her to shrink to ten inches high, a perfect size for the small door. However, she realizes she left the golden key on the glass table and cannot reach it. She tries to climb a table leg but it is too slippery, and she begins to cry.

Scolding herself, Alice notices a small cake under the table with "EAT ME" marked on it. She decides to eat it, hoping it will either make her grow larger to reach the key or smaller to creep under the door. She eats a bit but remains the same size. Disappointed by the ordinary outcome, she finishes the entire cake.

Immediately, Alice grows enormously, becoming more than nine feet high, her head striking the hall's roof. She grabs the key and hurries to the garden door, but she is now far too large, only able to lie on her side and peer into the garden with one eye. She starts crying again, shedding so many tears that a large pool, about four inches deep and reaching halfway down the hall, forms around her.

She hears the **White Rabbit** returning, dressed elaborately with white kid gloves and a fan, muttering about the **Duchess** and being late. Alice, feeling desperate, timidly asks the Rabbit for help. Startled, the Rabbit drops his gloves and fan and flees. Alice picks them up and, fanning herself in the hot hall, begins to question her identity, wondering if she has been changed. She attempts to recite school lessons and poems, but her memory is faulty, and the words come out wrong. She puts on one of the Rabbit's gloves and realizes she is shrinking again. She discovers the fan is causing her to shrink and drops it hastily, just in time to avoid shrinking out of existence.

Now about two feet high, Alice finds the small door shut again and the key still on the table, out of reach. Her foot slips, and she falls into the pool of tears she herself had wept. As she swims, she encounters a **Mouse**. She tries to speak to it, first in a formal way, then in French, asking "Where is my cat?" This terrifies the Mouse. Alice apologizes, but then unwisely mentions her cat, Dinah, and her mouse-catching abilities, which deeply offends the Mouse. Alice then tries to talk about dogs, inadvertently mentioning how a farmer's dog kills rats, further angering the Mouse, who swims away. Alice calls after it, promising not to talk about cats or dogs. The Mouse returns, its face pale, and agrees to tell its history on the shore. The pool is now crowded with other creatures, including a **Duck**, a **Dodo**, a **Lory**, and an **Eaglet**. Alice leads them all to the shore.

On the bank, the wet and uncomfortable party discusses how to get dry. The Mouse, taking authority, proposes "the driest thing I know," and begins to recite a dull history lesson about William the Conqueror. The others interrupt, and Alice complains she is still wet. The Dodo then proposes a "Caucus-race" as the best way to get dry. This race involves a circular course, no fixed start or end, with everyone running and stopping as they please. After about half an hour, everyone is dry. The Dodo declares the race over, and everyone has won, deserving prizes. Alice distributes comfits from her pocket to everyone. The Mouse then points out Alice needs a prize, so the Dodo solemnly presents her with a thimble from her pocket.

The group then asks the Mouse to tell its promised history, and Alice specifically asks why it hates "C and D" (cats and dogs). The Mouse begins a "long and a sad tale," but Alice, looking at its actual long tail, mistakes "tale" for "tail" and is distracted by the visual shape of the printed poem forming a tail. The Mouse is angered by Alice's inattention and her confusion about a "knot" in its "tale." Offended, the Mouse walks away. Alice's subsequent remark about her cat Dinah being "a capital one for catching mice" and eating "a little bird as soon as look at it" causes all the birds and animals to hastily depart, leaving Alice alone and regretful.

Soon, the **White Rabbit** returns, searching frantically for his fan and gloves, muttering about the Duchess and fear of execution. Alice realizes he is searching for the items she picked up earlier, but the great hall and glass table have vanished. The Rabbit mistakes Alice for his housemaid, **Mary Ann**, and imperiously orders her to fetch a pair of gloves and a fan from his house. Frightened, Alice obeys, running to the Rabbit’s house.

Inside, Alice finds a room with a fan and small white kid gloves. She also sees a bottle and, despite no "DRINK ME" label, drinks from it, hoping to grow back to her normal size. Instead, she grows rapidly, filling the house. Her head presses against the ceiling, and she has to kneel, then lie down, eventually extending one arm out a window and one foot up the chimney, becoming stuck. The Rabbit arrives outside, calls for Mary Ann, and tries to open the door, but Alice's elbow blocks it. He decides to enter through the window. Alice snatches at the air outside her window, causing a shriek, a fall, and broken glass, which she guesses is the Rabbit falling into a cucumber-frame.

The Rabbit then angrily calls for **Pat** (a **Lizard**), who is "digging for apples." Pat identifies Alice's arm in the window. The Rabbit orders him to remove it, leading to more shrieks and broken glass as Alice makes another snatch. A group of creatures then arrive with ladders, planning to go down the chimney. Alice realizes "Bill" (the Lizard) is chosen for this task. She kicks her foot down the chimney, sending Bill flying out like a "Jack-in-the-box." The Rabbit suggests burning the house down, but Alice threatens to set Dinah on them, causing a momentary silence. They then decide to throw pebbles at the house. The pebbles turn into little cakes on the floor. Alice eats one, correctly guessing it will make her shrink. She shrinks small enough to exit the house and runs into a thick wood, escaping the crowd of animals (including Bill, being revived).

In the wood, Alice plans to grow back to her right size and find the beautiful garden. She encounters an enormous **Puppy** and, after a playful but terrifying interaction with a stick, escapes while the puppy is resting. She realizes she needs to eat or drink something to grow. She finds a large mushroom and, looking over its edge, sees a large blue **Caterpillar** sitting on top, smoking a hookah.

The Caterpillar asks Alice, "Who are _you_?" Alice explains her identity crisis due to constantly changing sizes. The Caterpillar dismisses her confusion, asking her to recite "You are old, Father William," which Alice performs with altered words. The Caterpillar declares her recitation "wrong from beginning to end." When Alice expresses a desire to be a "little larger" than three inches (the Caterpillar's height), the Caterpillar takes offense. As it crawls away, it tells Alice that "One side will make you grow taller, and the other side will make you shorter," referring to the mushroom.

Alice breaks off a piece of the mushroom from each side. She nibbles the right-hand piece and shrinks rapidly until her chin is pressed against her foot. She quickly eats some of the left-hand piece. Her head becomes free, but her neck has grown immensely long, like a serpent's. She manages to bend her neck down towards her hands but is then attacked by a **Pigeon**, which screams "Serpent!" The Pigeon accuses her of being a serpent who eats eggs, complaining about having to guard its nest. Alice tries to explain she is a "little girl," but the Pigeon doesn't believe her due to her long neck. Alice clarifies she doesn't eat raw eggs. The Pigeon, sulkily, tells her to be off. Alice, untangling her neck from branches, remembers the mushroom pieces and carefully nibbles from them alternately until she returns to her usual height.

She then sees a small house, about four feet high. Realizing she is too big to approach it without frightening anyone, she nibbles the shrinking mushroom piece again until she is nine inches high.

She approaches the house and witnesses a **Fish-Footman** deliver a croquet invitation from the **Queen** to the **Duchess** to a **Frog-Footman**. Alice laughs, then tries to enter the house. The Frog-Footman explains that knocking is useless due to the noise inside (howling, sneezing, crashing) and his position on her side of the door. A plate then flies out of the house, narrowly missing the Footman's head. Frustrated by his nonsensical replies, Alice opens the door and enters.

Inside, she finds a smoky kitchen. The **Duchess** is nursing a constantly howling and sneezing **Baby**. A **Cook** stirs a cauldron of soup and throws kitchenware at the Duchess and baby, who take no notice. A grinning **Cheshire Cat** sits by the fire. Alice asks the Duchess why her cat grins, learning it's a "Cheshire cat." The Duchess, after calling the baby "Pig!", tells Alice that all cats can grin, and that Alice "don't know much." Alice tries to change the subject as the Cook throws more objects. The Duchess offers moralistic proverbs, which Alice attempts to correct with facts, leading the Duchess to exclaim "Chop off her head!"

The Duchess then gives the screaming Baby to Alice, telling her to nurse it while she goes to play croquet with the Queen. Alice struggles to hold the oddly shaped, snorting baby. She carries it outside, deciding it would be murder to leave it. She notices the baby's pig-like features developing further. Alice warns the baby that if it turns into a pig, she'll have nothing to do with it. The baby grunts violently again, and Alice realizes it has fully transformed into a pig. She sets it down, and it trots off into the wood.

Alice then encounters the **Cheshire Cat** sitting on a tree branch. She asks it which way to go. The Cat explains it depends on her destination. When Alice says she doesn't care, the Cat replies it doesn't matter which way she goes. The Cat then points out the **Hatter** and **March Hare** live in different directions, both of whom are mad. Alice expresses reluctance to go among mad people, but the Cat insists everyone there is mad, including Alice and himself, offering his own opposite behaviors (growling when pleased, wagging tail when angry) as proof. The Cat asks if Alice will play croquet with the Queen, says she'll see him there, and vanishes. It reappears to ask about the baby (Alice tells him it turned into a pig), then vanishes again, leaving only its grin, which fades slowly.

Alice walks towards the March Hare's house, which has ear-shaped chimneys and a fur-thatched roof. She eats more mushroom to grow to two feet high before timidly approaching.

She finds the **March Hare** and **Hatter** having a **Mad Tea-Party** at a table under a tree, with a **Dormouse** asleep between them. They tell Alice there's no room, but she sits down anyway. The March Hare offers her non-existent wine. The Hatter comments on her hair. The Hatter poses a riddle: "Why is a raven like a writing-desk?", but neither he nor the March Hare knows the answer. They argue about the meaning of words. The Hatter checks his watch, which only tells the day of the month, and blames the March Hare for putting butter in its works. The Hatter explains that he and "Time" (a personified entity) had a quarrel in March at the Queen of Hearts' concert, where he sang "Twinkle, twinkle, little bat!" and the Queen ordered "Off with his head!" As a result, it is now "always six o'clock" (tea-time) for them, so they perpetually move around the table as things get used up.

The March Hare then suggests Alice tell a story, but she doesn't know one, so they demand the Dormouse tell one. The Dormouse, after being pinched awake, begins a story about three sisters (Elsie, Lacie, and Tillie) who lived at the bottom of a "treacle-well" and lived on treacle. Alice questions this, but the others silence her. The Dormouse then says they learned to draw, and drew "Treacle." The Hatter demands a clean cup, causing them all to shift places around the table, leaving Alice in a worse spot. Alice tries to clarify how they drew treacle from a well they were _in_. The Dormouse, getting sleepy, says they drew things that begin with "M," such as "mouse-traps, and the moon, and memory, and muchness." Alice, disgusted by their rudeness, walks off. The Dormouse falls asleep, and the others ignore her, attempting to put the Dormouse into the teapot.

Alice decides it was the "stupidest tea-party" ever. She notices a door in a tree and enters it, finding herself back in the long hall near the glass table. This time, she retrieves the golden key and, by carefully nibbling her mushroom, adjusts her size to about a foot high, finally entering the beautiful garden.

In the garden, Alice observes three gardeners (named Five, Seven, and Two, shaped like playing cards) frantically painting white roses red on a rose-tree. They explain they mistakenly planted a white rose-tree where a red one should be, and the Queen will order their execution if she finds out. Suddenly, Five shouts "The Queen! The Queen!", and the gardeners fall flat on their faces. A grand procession enters, including soldiers (clubs), courtiers (diamonds), royal children (hearts), guests (Kings and Queens, including the **White Rabbit**), the **Knave of Hearts** carrying the King's crown, and finally, **THE KING AND QUEEN OF HEARTS**.

Alice remains standing. The Queen sternly asks who she is. Alice introduces herself politely, deciding she needn't fear them as they are "only a pack of cards." The Queen then asks who the prostrate gardeners are. Alice says she doesn't know, to which the Queen screams "Off with her head!" Alice, loudly and decidedly, says "Nonsense!", silencing the Queen. The King timidly intervenes, noting Alice is "only a child." The Queen then orders the Knave to turn the gardeners over. They rise and bow. The Queen asks what they've been doing. Two explains they were painting the roses red. The Queen, seeing the roses, again shouts "Off with their heads!" Soldiers prepare to execute them, but Alice puts the gardeners into a large flower-pot, protecting them. The soldiers search and then march off, reporting that the gardeners' "heads are gone."

The Queen then asks Alice if she can play croquet. Alice agrees. The croquet game is chaotic: the ground is ridged, the balls are live hedgehogs, the mallets are live flamingoes, and the soldiers must double up to form arches, but they constantly move. Alice struggles to control her flamingo and finds the game very difficult. The players quarrel, and the Queen frequently screams "Off with his head!" or "Off with her head!", sentencing many players to execution. Alice, uneasy, looks for an escape.

She sees the **Cheshire Cat's** grin appear in the air, followed by its head. She describes the confusing game to the Cat. The Cat asks how she likes the Queen. Alice, noticing the Queen nearby, quickly changes her critical comment to a polite one. The King, intrigued by the Cat's disembodied head, orders it removed. The Queen agrees, shouting "Off with his head!" The King goes to fetch the executioner. Alice leaves to find her hedgehog.

When Alice returns, a large crowd is gathered around the Cat's head, as the **Executioner**, King, and Queen are arguing. The Executioner claims he cannot cut off a head without a body. The King argues any head can be beheaded. The Queen threatens to execute everyone if the matter isn't resolved. Alice suggests asking the Duchess, to whom the Cat belongs. The Queen orders the Duchess fetched from prison. As the Executioner leaves, the Cat's head begins to fade, completely disappearing by the time the Executioner returns with the **Duchess**. The King and Executioner frantically search for the vanished head, while the others return to the game.

The Duchess affectionately greets Alice, her temper seemingly improved. She shares her moralistic philosophies about how different substances affect people's temperaments (pepper for hot, vinegar for sour, etc.), much to Alice's discomfort as the Duchess leans her sharp chin on Alice's shoulder. The Queen reappears, frowning. She warns the Duchess to leave instantly or face execution. The Duchess vanishes in a moment.

The Queen orders Alice to continue the game. The King, unseen by the Queen, quietly pardons all the imprisoned players. The Queen and Alice then set off to find the **Mock Turtle**, as the Queen wants him to tell Alice his history. They find a **Gryphon** asleep in the sun. The Queen orders the Gryphon to take Alice to the Mock Turtle, then leaves to oversee "executions" (which the Gryphon later tells Alice are "all her fancy" and "they never executes nobody").

The Gryphon leads Alice to the Mock Turtle, who sits sadly on a rock, sighing, though the Gryphon says his sorrow is also "all his fancy." The Mock Turtle, sobbing, recounts his history, claiming he "was a real Turtle." He tells them he went to school in the sea, taught by a turtle they called "Tortoise because he taught us." Alice interrupts, questioning this, and is scolded by the Gryphon. The Mock Turtle describes their lessons: "Reeling and Writhing," and branches of Arithmetic like "Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision." He also learned "Mystery, ancient and modern, with Seaography," and "Drawling, Stretching, and Fainting in Coils." The Gryphon mentions his own Classics master, an old crab, who taught "Laughing and Grief." The Gryphon explains their "lessons" "lessen from day to day," from ten hours to nine, and so on. The Gryphon eventually cuts off the Mock Turtle's story of lessons.

The Gryphon then asks the Mock Turtle to describe the games. The Mock Turtle, still sobbing, describes the "Lobster Quadrille," a dance involving two lines of sea creatures partnered with lobsters, throwing the lobsters out to sea, swimming after them, turning somersaults, and changing partners. He and the Gryphon demonstrate the first figure, dancing around Alice while the Mock Turtle sings "Will you walk a little faster?" Alice finds the song and dance very interesting. The Mock Turtle then explains that whitings (a type of fish) have their tails in their mouths because they got thrown out to sea with the lobsters and fell a long way, getting their tails caught. The Gryphon adds that whitings "do the boots and shoes" for undersea creatures (like blacking for land shoes), and that undersea shoes are made of "Soles and eels." The Mock Turtle insists wise fish always travel "with what porpoise," mispronouncing "purpose."

The Gryphon then asks Alice to tell her own adventures. Alice begins, starting from seeing the White Rabbit and her subsequent size changes and incorrect recitations. When she reaches the part about saying "You are old, Father William" differently to the Caterpillar, the Mock Turtle finds it "very curious." The Gryphon orders Alice to recite "'Tis the voice of the sluggard'," but Alice, her head full of the Lobster Quadrille, recites it incorrectly as "'Tis the voice of the Lobster." The Mock Turtle finds it "uncommon nonsense" and demands an explanation. Alice then recites another verse incorrectly, about an Owl and Panther sharing a pie, but the Mock Turtle interrupts, demanding explanations. The Gryphon tells Alice to stop reciting.

The Gryphon asks if they should try another figure of the Lobster Quadrille or if the Mock Turtle should sing a song. Alice eagerly requests a song. The Mock Turtle, sighing and sobbing, sings "Turtle Soup." As he finishes, a cry of "The trial's beginning!" is heard in the distance. The Gryphon grabs Alice's hand and hurries off with her towards the sound.

They arrive at the trial, where the **King and Queen of Hearts** are seated on their throne, surrounded by a crowd of birds, beasts, and cards. The **Knave of Hearts** stands in chains, guarded by soldiers, accused of stealing tarts. The **White Rabbit** serves as the herald. Alice notes a large dish of tarts on a table in the court. The King, wearing his crown over a wig, acts as the judge, and twelve "creatures" (animals and birds) act as jurymen, busily writing on slates. The Gryphon explains they are writing their names. Alice loudly calls them "Stupid things!", which they dutifully record. Alice then removes Bill the Lizard's squeaky pencil, forcing him to write with his finger, which leaves no mark.

The White Rabbit reads the accusation: a poem stating that "The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts, / All on a summer day: / The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts, / And took them quite away!" The King calls for a verdict, but the Rabbit insists there is more evidence.

The first witness is the **Hatter**, who arrives with a teacup and bread-and-butter, claiming he hadn't finished his tea. The King asks when he started. The Hatter, March Hare, and Dormouse give conflicting dates (14th, 15th, 16th of March), which the jury writes down and adds up. The King orders the Hatter to remove his hat. The Hatter says it's not his, but he keeps hats to sell. The King exclaims "Stolen!", which the jury notes. The King demands the Hatter give his evidence without nervousness, threatening execution. The Hatter, growing more flustered, bites his teacup instead of his food.

During the Hatter's testimony, Alice begins to grow larger again, making the Dormouse (sitting next to her) complain about being squeezed. The Queen stares at the Hatter, and demands the list of singers from the last concert, causing the Hatter to tremble. The King angrily repeats his demand for evidence. The Hatter gives a rambling, nonsensical account about tea, bread-and-butter, and "twinkling," which the King tries to make sense of. He mentions the March Hare and Dormouse, but the March Hare denies his statements, and the Dormouse is asleep. The Hatter cannot remember what the Dormouse said. The King threatens execution if he doesn't remember. Alice notes that a cheering guinea-pig is "suppressed" by being stuffed into a canvas bag and sat upon. The Hatter, dismissed, hurries out of court, and the Queen orders his head chopped off outside, but he is gone.

The second witness is the **Duchess's Cook**, who causes everyone to sneeze with her pepper-box. She refuses to give evidence. The King, advised by the White Rabbit, cross-examines her, asking what tarts are made of. The Cook says "Pepper, mostly." The sleeping Dormouse interjects "Treacle." The Queen, enraged, orders the Dormouse beheaded, turned out, suppressed, pinched, and its whiskers cut off. In the ensuing confusion, the Cook disappears.

The King, relieved, calls for the next witness, telling the Queen she must cross-examine this one. To Alice's great surprise, the White Rabbit calls out the name "**Alice!**"

Alice cries "Here!" and jumps up, forgetting her immense size. She tips over the jury-box with her skirt, sending all the jurymen sprawling. She apologizes and hastily gathers them, putting Bill the Lizard right-side up after mistakenly placing him head downwards. The King demands the trial proceed only when all jurymen are in place.

The King asks Alice what she knows about the business. Alice replies, "Nothing whatever." The King declares this "very important," but the White Rabbit quickly corrects him to "unimportant." The King agrees, muttering to himself. The King then reads "Rule Forty-two" from his notebook: "_All persons more than a mile high to leave the court_." Everyone looks at Alice, who is now very large. She denies being a mile high, but the King and Queen insist she is. Alice refuses to leave, arguing it's an invented rule. The King claims it's the oldest rule; Alice retorts it should be "Number One" then. The King, looking pale, tells the jury to consider their verdict.

The White Rabbit interrupts again, stating he has new evidence: a paper, a letter from the prisoner. He reads it, revealing it to be a set of nonsensical verses without a signature or direction. A juryman asks if it's the prisoner's handwriting; the Rabbit says no. The King deduces the Knave imitated someone else's hand. The Knave protests he didn't write it and there's no name. The King asserts that not signing it implies mischief. The Queen declares this "proves his guilt." Alice argues it proves nothing since they don't even know what the verses mean.

The King orders the Rabbit to read the verses. The White Rabbit reads the poem, which is full of vague references to "her," "him," "them," inability to swim, returning items, and an "obstacle." The King finds it "the most important piece of evidence yet." Alice, now grown to her full size and fearless, interrupts, stating she doesn't believe there's "an atom of meaning in it" and offers sixpence to anyone who can explain it. The jury writes down Alice's statement. The King attempts to interpret the verses, connecting parts of the poem to the Knave and the tarts, but Alice points out inconsistencies. The King triumphantly points to the tarts on the table as proof they returned. He also questions the Queen about a line about "fits," and the Queen furiously denies having any, throwing an inkstand at Bill the Lizard, who then uses the ink trickling down his face to write. The King makes a pun about the words not "fitting" the Queen.

The King orders the jury to consider their verdict. The Queen interjects, demanding "Sentence first—verdict afterwards." Alice loudly calls this "Stuff and nonsense!" The Queen, turning purple with rage, screams "Off with her head!" But Alice, now at her full size, defiantly declares, "Who cares for you? You're nothing but a pack of cards!"

At this, the entire pack of cards rises into the air and flies down upon her. Alice screams, half in fright and half in anger, and tries to beat them off. Suddenly, she finds herself lying on the riverbank, her head in her sister's lap, as her sister gently brushes dead leaves from her face.

Alice's sister wakes her, remarking on her long sleep. Alice recounts her "curious dream" to her sister. After Alice finishes, her sister kisses her and sends her off for tea. Alice runs off, thinking about her wonderful dream.

Alice's sister remains on the bank, leaning her head on her hand, watching the setting sun, and dreaming of Alice's adventures. She imagines the White Rabbit, the frightened Mouse, the tea-party, the Queen's shrill cries, the pig-baby, the Gryphon, the Lizard's pencil, the suppressed guinea-pigs, and the Mock Turtle's sobs. She knows that if she opens her eyes, all these fantastical elements will revert to ordinary sounds of nature: rustling grass, rippling water, tinkling sheep-bells, a shepherd boy's voice, and farmyard noises. Lastly, she pictures Alice as a grown woman, sharing these strange tales with other children, retaining her childhood's loving heart, and finding joy in their simple lives, remembering her own happy summer days.

summary_llm:
The provided text, titled "ANNA KARENINA," presents a detailed plot across several parts and chapters, focusing on the interwoven lives of several families in 19th-century Russia.

**PART ONE**

The narrative begins in the Oblonskys’ house, in a state of "confusion." The wife, Darya Alexandrovna (Dolly), has discovered her husband, Prince Stepan Arkadyevitch Oblonsky (Stiva), is having an affair with their French governess. Dolly announces she can no longer live with him, and the household is in turmoil. Stiva wakes in his study, recalling the quarrel and his "idiotic smile" that seemed to make things worse. He feels at fault but also resentful of Dolly's unforgiving nature. He rationalizes his infidelity, believing Dolly, being "worn-out," should be more understanding. His valet, Matvey, informs him his sister, Anna Arkadyevna, is arriving from Petersburg, hoping she can reconcile the couple. The nurse, Matrona Philimonovna, urges Stiva to beg Dolly's forgiveness for the children's sake.

Stiva then attends to his daily routine, reading a liberal newspaper and thinking about his financial difficulties, including the sale of his wife's forest, which is complicated by their marital discord. He interacts with his children, Tanya and Grisha, feeling guilt when Tanya blushes for his pretense of cheerfulness. He decides to confront Dolly.

Dolly is found trying to pack, contemplating leaving but realizing it's impossible due to her children and her enduring love for Stiva. She attempts to appear stern but shows her suffering. Stiva, timidly, mentions Anna's arrival. Dolly screams at him, expressing her loathing for his "passion" and ordering him away. Stiva, weeping, begs her to consider the children. Dolly, though softening and calling him "Stiva," recoils from his touch, calling him "loathsome" and a "stranger." A child's cry draws her away. She threatens to expose him to the servants. Stiva leaves, bothered by her "vulgarity."

Stepan Arkadyevitch goes to his government office, where he holds a respected position obtained through his brother-in-law, Alexey Alexandrovitch Karenin (Anna's husband). He is widely liked for his good humor. He is joined by his old friend, Konstantin Dmitrievitch Levin, a country gentleman. They share a playful banter, with Stiva mocking Levin's rural life. Levin is in Moscow to propose to Kitty Shtcherbatskaya, Dolly's younger sister. He has long been in love with the Shtcherbatsky family but feels unworthy of Kitty. He had left Moscow abruptly two months prior due to his doubts but is now resolved to propose.

Levin visits his half-brother, Sergey Ivanovitch Koznishev, a philosopher, who is discussing deep philosophical questions with a professor. Levin finds their debate abstract. Sergey Ivanovitch informs Levin that their estranged brother, Nikolay, is in Moscow. Levin is horrified, as Nikolay is a ruined man with a scandalous past, but resolves to visit him after seeing Kitty.

Levin, nervous, goes to the Zoological Gardens, where Kitty is skating. He is overcome by her radiant beauty. Kitty approaches him, they exchange pleasantries, and she invites him to skate. He is elated. When he tells her his stay depends on her, she becomes reserved. Levin feels he has offended her. Kitty leaves with her mother, Princess Shtcherbatskaya, who gives Levin a stiff invitation to visit on Thursday, which Kitty softens. Stepan Arkadyevitch arrives and invites Levin to dine, which he accepts with ecstasy.

At the restaurant, Levin is uncomfortable with the opulent setting. Stepan Arkadyevitch, ordering an extravagant meal, teases Levin about his mood. Levin criticizes city life. Stiva then reveals he knows Levin is in love with Kitty and that Dolly, with her foresight, believes Kitty will be his wife. Levin is overjoyed. He confesses his past sins, feeling unworthy. Stiva then asks Levin for advice on his own infidelity, describing his mistress as a loving creature. Levin expresses moral revulsion for "fallen women," comparing them to "vermin," and asserts that life should be "all of a piece." Stiva argues for the complexity of life, with "light and shadow." They feel a distance between them. Stiva leaves for another engagement, while Levin, paying the bill, heads to Kitty's.

Kitty, 18, is a social success. Her father favors Levin, but her mother wants a brilliant match with Vronsky, a wealthy and charming officer. The princess is anxious about Vronsky's intentions. With Levin's return, she fears Kitty might refuse Vronsky out of a sense of honor. Kitty, though desiring Vronsky, is wounded by her mother's mercenary motives.

At the ball, Kitty feels intense anticipation. Levin arrives early, intending to propose. He asks her to marry him. Kitty is ecstatic but remembers Vronsky and hastily refuses Levin. Levin is crushed. The princess, entering, is relieved. Countess Nordston teases Levin. Vronsky arrives, and Kitty's bright eyes confirm to Levin her love for Vronsky. Levin observes Vronsky's humble submission to Anna. The old prince, seeing Vronsky, shows him coldness. The conversation turns to spiritualism, which Levin disdains. Levin leaves, heartbroken by Kitty's joyful interaction with Vronsky.

Kitty reflects on her refusal of Levin, feeling remorse but also justified by her love for Vronsky. The prince and princess argue over Kitty's future. The prince blames the princess for chasing Vronsky, calling him a "peacock." The princess is disturbed.

Vronsky, who has a history of fleeting affairs, had been charmed by Kitty's innocence but had no intention of marriage. He felt a strong, pure connection with her after the ball and believed she loved him. He returned home content.

Vronsky meets Stepan Arkadyevitch at the Petersburg railway station. Stiva tells Vronsky about Levin's proposal to Kitty, implying Vronsky is the better match. Vronsky feels triumphant. Anna Karenina, Stiva's sister and Vronsky's mother's fellow traveler, arrives. Vronsky is immediately struck by Anna's "caressing and soft" expression and her "suppressed eagerness." A railway guard is crushed to death by a train. Anna is agitated, calling it an "omen of evil." Vronsky, noticing her distress, gives money to the assistant for the widow. Stiva praises Vronsky. Anna then confides in Stiva about his marital problems. Vronsky's mother tells him Anna is "very sweet" and that he is "in perfect love" (with Kitty). Vronsky coldly deflects. Anna, saying goodbye to Vronsky's mother, gives Vronsky an "energetic squeeze" of his hand, which delights him.

Anna spends the day with Dolly, reconciling her and Stiva by framing his affair as a male weakness, not an "infidelity of the heart." Dolly is comforted. Anna encourages Stiva to seek out Dolly. Anna tells Kitty that Vronsky's mother has praised him as a "hero." She avoids discussing Vronsky's 200-rouble donation at the station. Anna facilitates Dolly and Stiva's reconciliation. Anna sees Vronsky in the Oblonskys' hall, feeling "pleasure and dread." He refuses to come upstairs. Kitty blushes, believing Vronsky came to see her.

At the ball, Kitty observes Anna and Vronsky's clear attraction. Anna intentionally ignores Vronsky's bow. Kitty realizes Vronsky loves Anna, and her own "unhappiness is complete." Anna leaves the ball, confirming her departure for Petersburg.

Levin visits his gravely ill brother Nikolay in Moscow, who is living with Marya Nikolaevna. Nikolay, emaciated, expresses his bitterness and his interest in a locksmiths' association. Levin is distraught by Nikolay's condition and cynical views. Nikolay is irritable and accuses Levin of hypocrisy, then drinks heavily. Konstantin, with Marya Nikolaevna's help, gets Nikolay to bed.

Levin returns to his country estate, feeling a sense of clarity and peace. He resolves to live a purer, more disciplined life, working harder. He finds joy in the birth of a calf. He is still pained by Kitty's rejection. He now sees his farming system as a "cruel and stubborn struggle" with his laborers and resolves to reform it.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, after Anna's public display of emotion at the races, confronts her. Anna confesses her love for Vronsky and her hatred for Alexey Alexandrovitch. He is shocked and demands she maintain external propriety. Vronsky attempts suicide, shooting himself but only wounding himself. He is nursed by his sister-in-law, Varya.

Alexey Alexandrovitch struggles with Anna's confession. He feels betrayed and humiliated. He decides to pursue a divorce and take Seryozha. He consults a lawyer, who outlines the options, including "adultery by mutual consent." Alexey Alexandrovitch, due to religious scruples and a desire to avoid public shame, rejects this and opts for "undesigned detection" supported by letters. He finds Anna's portrait "insolent."

Kitty falls ill and goes abroad with her mother. She is drawn to Varenka, a selfless, compassionate woman. Kitty is disillusioned by her father's cynicism about Madame Stahl's piety. Kitty, realizing her "philanthropic" efforts were a "sham," decides to return to Russia.

**PART TWO**

Kitty's illness (nervous irritability) leads to doctors recommending Soden waters and a tour abroad. The prince blames Vronsky. Dolly visits, struggling with her own marital problems. Kitty, in a fit of anger, lashes out at Dolly for tolerating Stiva's infidelity, then breaks down, confessing her misery and shame. She stays with Dolly to nurse the children through scarlet fever. Kitty and the Shtcherbatskys go abroad.

Anna, in Petersburg, is drawn to fashionable society to meet Vronsky, realizing he is now the "whole interest of her life." Vronsky confesses his desire for her. He mediates a dispute between officers and a government clerk. Anna arrives at Betsy's, radiant. Vronsky is captivated. Anna discusses marriage, then tells Vronsky about Kitty's illness, accusing him of behaving "wrongly." She demands he end their relationship and go to Kitty. Vronsky declares his love for Anna is his "whole life." Alexey Alexandrovitch enters. Anna, delighted by Vronsky's love, returns to the general conversation. As she leaves, Vronsky confesses his love and desire for her.

Alexey Alexandrovitch resolves to confront Anna about her impropriety. He warns her about her "too animated conversation" with Vronsky, then speaks of their sacred marriage. Anna feigns indifference. Their desire is fulfilled, and Anna and Vronsky become lovers. Anna feels sinful, begging Vronsky for forgiveness. He feels like a "murderer." She declares, "All is over; I have nothing but you." She experiences a recurring nightmare where both Alexey Alexandrovitch and Vronsky are her husbands.

Levin is still pained by Kitty's rejection. He goes abroad to see his ill brother Nikolay. He begins a book on agriculture. Spring arrives, and he resolves to live a pure life. He finds joy in farm work, eventually realizing his love for Kitty is paramount, not a simple peasant life. He is distraught by Nikolay's severe illness and cynical views. Alexey Alexandrovitch's letter demands Anna return home and cease contact with Vronsky. Anna is enraged, feeling trapped, and contemplates suicide. She leaves for Betsy's.

Anna meets Vronsky in the Vrede garden. She confesses she told Alexey Alexandrovitch everything. Vronsky, thinking of a duel, is rigid, but then expresses joy, believing this forces a resolution. Anna is disappointed by his reaction, as he doesn't immediately suggest they leave together. She shows him Alexey Alexandrovitch's letter. He says he rejoices because things cannot remain as they are. Anna, distraught, insists she cannot leave Seryozha. She declares her love for Vronsky and that she will die soon, in childbirth. He dismisses this. She senses the new life within her.

Vronsky is agitated, late for the races. He reads his mother's and brother's letters criticizing his affair. He falls at the steeplechase, breaking his mare's back. He is devastated.

Anna is devastated by Vronsky's perceived indifference. She confronts him, but he dismisses her. She contemplates suicide and has a recurring nightmare of a peasant with iron. She decides to confront Vronsky again. She goes to Seryozha's birthday, bribes servants, and embraces him. Alexey Alexandrovitch arrives, and Anna, filled with hatred, flees.

Anna, distraught, believes death is the only escape. On the train, she is consumed by suicidal thoughts, believing Vronsky's love was vanity and he is tired of her. She sees the world as full of hatred. At the station, she learns Vronsky is meeting Princess Sorokina. She receives a cold note from him. Filled with fury, she throws herself under a train and dies.

Alexey Alexandrovitch is distraught by Anna's death. He cares for the newborn baby (Vronsky's child), finding spiritual peace in forgiveness. He realizes society's contempt for his situation. Anna's spirit is unsettled. She complains to Alexey Alexandrovitch that Vronsky wants to say goodbye before leaving for Tashkend. Alexey Alexandrovitch is conflicted but agrees. Vronsky is recovering from his self-inflicted wound. Betsy tells him Alexey Alexandrovitch has agreed to a divorce. Vronsky rushes to Anna. They embrace passionately. She says, "You have conquered me, and I am yours." She speaks of their love and her premonition of death. Vronsky declines the Tashkend appointment and leaves the army. They go abroad without a divorce.

**PART THREE**

Sergey Ivanovitch visits Levin in the country. Their differing views on country life and peasants cause discomfort. Levin, needing physical activity, decides to mow with the peasants, finding joy in the labor. Sergey Ivanovitch, meanwhile, discusses district council issues and urges Levin to participate, but Levin argues for self-interest over public good. Levin is struck by a peasant's words about living "for the soul," which profoundly changes his philosophical outlook. He realizes his love for Kitty is central to his life.

Stepan Arkadyevitch, in Petersburg, neglects his family, while Dolly struggles at Ergushovo. Marya Philimonovna brings order to Dolly's household. Dolly finds joy in her children. Levin meets Dolly, who mentions Kitty's upcoming visit. Dolly questions Levin about his anger towards Kitty, revealing she knows he was rejected. Levin, stung, confirms it. Dolly expresses pity for Kitty, saying her refusal was due to doubt. Levin, wounded, declares Kitty "out of the question." Dolly speaks French to Tanya, which annoys Levin. Dolly is upset by her children fighting. Levin discovers the peasants have cheated him in the hay division. He observes the love between a young peasant couple.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, after Anna's confession and tears, feels relief and decides Anna is corrupt. He contemplates divorce but decides to keep her with him to avoid scandal and punish her, rationalizing it as a Christian act. He sends Anna a letter commanding her to live as before, without contact with Vronsky, or face consequences for her and Seryozha. Anna is enraged by his "vile, base creature" of an offer and contemplates suicide. She decides to see Vronsky.

Anna meets Vronsky in the Vrede garden. She confesses she told Alexey Alexandrovitch everything. Vronsky, thinking of a duel, is rigid, but then expresses joy, believing this forces a resolution. Anna is disappointed by his reaction. She insists she cannot leave Seryozha. She declares she loves Vronsky and will die soon, in childbirth. He dismisses this. She senses the new life within her.

Vronsky is agitated, late for the races. He falls, breaking his mare's back. He is devastated. Anna is devastated by Vronsky's perceived indifference. She contemplates suicide. She goes to Seryozha's birthday, bribes servants, and embraces her son. Alexey Alexandrovitch arrives, and Anna, filled with hatred, flees.

Anna, distraught, believes death is the only escape. On the train, she is consumed by suicidal thoughts, believing Vronsky's love was vanity and he is tired of her. She steps in front of a train and dies.

**PART FOUR**

Alexey Alexandrovitch and Anna live as strangers in the same house. Vronsky is tasked with entertaining a foreign prince in Petersburg, finding it tedious and seeing his own flaws reflected. He receives a note from Anna asking him to visit, as she is ill and unhappy. He decides to go. He arrives at her house just as Alexey Alexandrovitch is leaving. Anna, distraught, confesses she has been waiting for him. Anna, consumed by jealousy, accuses Vronsky of spending time with other women. He denies it. She accuses him of being "disgusting." She says she feels on the "brink of calamity" and that she will die soon, in childbirth. She recounts her nightmare of the peasant. He dismisses it, then senses her pregnancy.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, furious that Anna received Vronsky in his house, decides to punish her with divorce and take their son. He confronts her, demands her lover's letters, and calls her "base." Anna, angered, confesses her love for Vronsky and her hatred for Alexey Alexandrovitch. He announces he will go to Moscow to arrange a divorce and take Seryozha, but Anna begs him to leave Seryozha until her confinement. He furiously leaves.

Alexey Alexandrovitch visits a lawyer to arrange the divorce. He rejects "adultery by mutual consent" due to religious scruples and a desire to avoid public shame. He decides on "undesigned detection." His political career is floundering due to Stremov's tactics. He decides to investigate a native tribes issue himself in remote provinces, returning travel expenses. In Moscow, he meets Dolly and Stiva, acting cold.

Stepan Arkadyevitch is in Moscow, planning a dinner party to introduce Levin to Karenin. Levin arrives, still wrestling with his past rejection by Kitty. Kitty is delighted and embarrassed to see him. They communicate using chalk, and he proposes again, confessing his love. She accepts, confessing she always loved him. The old prince interrupts.

At the dinner, Pestsov, Karenin, and Sergey Ivanovitch discuss politics. Levin and Kitty have their own conversation. Kitty tells Levin about Turovtsin's kindness to Dolly's children. Pestsov discusses the inequality of rights in marriage. Turovtsin announces a duel over a wife. Dolly confronts Alexey Alexandrovitch about Anna. He coldly confirms Anna's infidelity and his decision for divorce, saying he hates her. Levin, witnessing this, feels pity.

Levin and Kitty's engagement is formalized. Levin confesses his past sins and lack of faith to Kitty, who forgives him. He feels unworthy but immensely happy.

Alexey Alexandrovitch receives a telegram from Anna saying she is dying and begs forgiveness. He suspects a trick but goes to Petersburg. He arrives to find Anna has had a successful confinement and is gravely ill. Vronsky, the doctor, and midwife are present. Anna, in delirium, asks Alexey Alexandrovitch for forgiveness and also begs him to forgive Vronsky. Alexey Alexandrovitch, moved by "blissful spiritual condition," forgives them both. Vronsky attempts suicide (shooting himself) but only wounds himself. He is nursed by his brother's wife, Varya.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, finding spiritual peace in forgiveness, cares for the newborn baby (Vronsky's child). He realizes society's contempt for his situation. Anna, recovering, is afraid of him. Princess Betsy visits. Alexey Alexandrovitch overhears Anna and Betsy discussing Vronsky's suicide attempt. Anna confesses Vronsky wants to say goodbye before leaving for Tashkend. Alexey Alexandrovitch agrees. Stepan Arkadyevitch, in Petersburg, hears gossip about Anna. Betsy tells him Anna is "killing her" and needs a divorce. Stiva visits Anna, who confesses her hatred for her husband. Stiva soothes her, suggesting divorce. Stiva convinces Alexey Alexandrovitch to grant Anna a divorce, using Alexey Alexandrovitch's letter of forgiveness.

Vronsky, recovering, agrees to go to Tashkend. Betsy informs him Alexey Alexandrovitch has agreed to a divorce. Vronsky rushes to Anna. They embrace passionately. She yields, saying, "You have conquered me, and I am yours." She speaks of their love and her premonition of death. Vronsky declines the Tashkend appointment and leaves the army. A month later, Anna and Vronsky go abroad without a divorce, having abandoned the idea. Alexey Alexandrovitch is left alone with Seryozha in Petersburg.

**PART FIVE**

Kitty and Levin are married after hurried preparations. Levin is in a blissful daze, letting others manage the details, including his required confession, which he finds hypocritical. On his wedding day, he is suddenly assailed by doubts about Kitty's love and rushes to her, offering to call off the wedding. She tearfully assures him of her love, and they reconcile. The wedding proceeds. Levin is deeply moved by the church service and a new sense of divine aid. Kitty, too, feels a profound joy and the start of a new life, having broken from her past. After the ceremony, they leave for the country.

Vronsky and Anna spend three months traveling in Italy. Vronsky experiences _ennui_ (boredom) despite fulfilling his desires. He takes up painting. They meet Golenishtchev, an old comrade, who criticizes modern art and the artist Mihailov. Vronsky commissions Mihailov to paint Anna's portrait. Mihailov paints a striking portrait, capturing Anna's beauty and an expression Vronsky had not fully seen himself. Vronsky's own attempt at painting Anna's portrait fails. His interest in painting and medieval life wanes. They decide to return to Russia, Vronsky to settle property, Anna to see Seryozha.

Levin, three months into his marriage, finds his idealistic dreams replaced by a mix of unexpected joys and challenges. He struggles with Kitty's focus on domestic details, but loves her for it. They experience frequent, intense quarrels, especially an early one over his lateness and her jealousy. He realizes they are inextricably linked. This initial period is difficult, but their life smooths out after a month in Moscow.

Back in the country, Levin focuses on his farm work and book, finding a new balance. Kitty, happy, is also absorbed in home-making. She receives a letter stating Nikolay Levin is dying. Levin decides to go to him, and Kitty insists on accompanying him, despite his objections. They travel to a provincial hotel, where Nikolay is gravely ill, living in squalor with Marya Nikolaevna. Levin is horrified. Kitty, however, compassionately takes charge, cleaning the room and caring for Nikolay. Nikolay dies. Kitty falls ill, a symptom of pregnancy.

Alexey Alexandrovitch, finding spiritual peace in forgiveness after Anna's near-death, cares for their newborn daughter (Vronsky's child). He realizes society's contempt for his situation. Countess Lidia Ivanovna offers him moral and practical support, managing his household and guiding him towards a new, mystical interpretation of Christianity. Anna, desperate to see Seryozha, writes to Lidia Ivanovna, who cruelly refuses her request, telling Seryozha his mother is "dead" to him. Anna, enraged, resolves to visit Seryozha on his birthday. She bribes servants and embraces Seryozha in his room. Alexey Alexandrovitch enters, and Anna, filled with hatred, flees.

Anna, distraught, believes death is the only escape. On the train, she is consumed by suicidal thoughts, believing Vronsky's love has waned. At the station, she learns Vronsky is meeting Princess Sorokina. Receiving a careless note from him, she is filled with fury and throws herself under a train, dying instantly.

**PART SIX**

Dolly and her children stay with the Levins at Pokrovskoe. The old princess and Varenka also visit. Levin feels overwhelmed by the "Shtcherbatsky element." Sergey Ivanovitch expresses interest in mushroom picking with Varenka, which Kitty interprets as a sign of impending romance. The women make jam. Kitty, in private, tells her mother she hopes Sergey Ivanovitch will propose to Varenka. Dolly and the princess reflect on love and marriage. Kitty then expresses her frustration with Levin's perceived jealousy over her past with Vronsky, and his inability to understand her. Levin enters, senses the conversation, and is discontent.

Kitty and Levin discuss Sergey Ivanovitch and Varenka, with Kitty hoping for a proposal, while Levin finds his brother too spiritual for a practical union. Kitty questions Levin's self-dissatisfaction and work ethic. They are interrupted by the arrival of Stepan Arkadyevitch and Vassenka Veslovsky, a charming young sportsman. Levin is annoyed by the prince's absence and Veslovsky's flirtation with Kitty, which reignites his jealousy. He leaves, vexed.

Levin returns for supper. Veslovsky and Stiva discuss shooting. Dolly subtly criticizes Stiva. Stiva mentions Veslovsky's visit to Anna and suggests Dolly visit her. Kitty, blushing, asks Levin about shooting tomorrow. Levin, in a fit of jealousy, believes Kitty is in love with Veslovsky. He agrees to stay home. He confronts Kitty, expressing his "humiliation" and anger at Veslovsky's gaze. Kitty, though initially offended, reassures him of her love. She attributes his jealousy to his deep love. They reconcile. Levin, despite his reservations, agrees to keep Veslovsky in the house.

The next morning, Veslovsky and Stepan Arkadyevitch prepare for shooting. Levin, before leaving, returns to Kitty to confirm her forgiveness and to caution her about her pregnancy. Kitty is cheerful. Levin argues with a carpenter about a faulty staircase. He sets off for shooting, feeling joyful and focused. Veslovsky, realizing he left his pocketbook, gallops back.

Levin, Stepan Arkadyevitch, and Veslovsky go shooting. Levin is annoyed by Veslovsky's ineptitude and accidental discharge of his gun. Veslovsky then drives the carriage into a marsh, getting the horses stuck. Levin, vexed, works to free them, but blames himself for being cold to Veslovsky. They have lunch. Veslovsky,

summary_llm:
This detailed summary is based *solely* on the provided text, without external knowledge of the book.

**Part I**

**Chapter I**
The story begins on a hot July evening with a young man, Raskolnikov, leaving his cramped garret in S. Place. He is deeply in debt to his landlady, who lives on the floor below, and he avoids meeting her due to fear and shame. Raskolnikov is described as handsome but poorly dressed, in an irritable, hypochondriac-like state, isolated and absorbed in his own thoughts. He is burdened by poverty but also by a "hideous but daring recklessness" – a "plan" he contemplates.

As he walks towards K. bridge in Petersburg, the oppressive heat and city stench exacerbate his overwrought nerves. He mutters to himself, acknowledging his confused ideas and physical weakness from lack of food. A drunken man in a passing wagon shouts at him, calling him "German hatter," which makes Raskolnikov realize his worn-out, noticeable hat could spoil his "whole plan." He has counted the 730 steps from his lodging to a particular house. He is on a "rehearsal" of his project, his excitement growing.

He approaches a large house by the canal, inhabited by various working people. He is glad to avoid the door-keepers and slips up a dark, narrow back staircase to the fourth storey. Porters are moving furniture from a German clerk's flat, meaning only the old woman will be on that floor. He rings the old woman's bell, which has a peculiar tinkle that reminds him of something. The door opens a tiny crack, revealing the old woman's suspicious eyes. Seeing others on the landing, she opens the door wider.

The old woman is Alyona Ivanovna, a diminutive, withered woman of sixty with sharp, malignant eyes. Raskolnikov identifies himself as a student who visited a month ago. He has returned "on the same errand," which disconcerts him. He enters her small, clean room, noting the yellow wallpaper, geraniums, and old yellow furniture. He observes a cotton curtain leading to another tiny room where the old woman's bed and chest of drawers are.

Alyona Ivanovna asks what he wants, and he offers an old silver watch to pawn. She reminds him his last pledge is overdue. He promises interest for another month, but she states her right to sell his pledge. He asks for four roubles for the watch, which was his father's, promising to redeem it. She offers a rouble and a half, plus interest in advance. He is angered but accepts, remembering he has nowhere else to go and "another object" in coming.

While she fumbles for keys and goes behind the curtain to unlock a chest, Raskolnikov mentally notes she keeps keys in her right pocket, on a steel ring, with one large, deeply notched key that must be for a strong-box. He feels the situation is "degrading." Alyona Ivanovna returns, calculates the interest owed and due, and gives him one rouble and fifteen copecks for the watch. He does not dispute it. Before leaving, he casually asks if her sister, Lizaveta, is always alone. Alyona Ivanovna responds defensively.

Raskolnikov leaves in extreme confusion, feeling "loathsome." He wonders how such an "atrocious thing" could come into his head and feels disgust for his own heart. He walks like a drunk man, bumping into passers-by, until he finds himself near a tavern. He has never been in one before but feels a sudden thirst and weakness from lack of food. He orders beer, feels better after drinking, and his thoughts clear. He dismisses his fears as "physical derangement." He then notices other patrons, including a man who looks like a retired clerk, staring persistently at him.

**Chapter II**
Raskolnikov, usually a loner, now desires company due to a "new" feeling within him. He rests in the tavern, observing the proprietor and a boy at the counter. The clerk, Marmeladov, is over fifty, bald, grizzled, and stout, with a face bloated and greenish from drink. He wears ragged clothes but maintains a semblance of respectability. He addresses Raskolnikov, sensing he is educated. Marmeladov introduces himself as a titular counsellor and asks if Raskolnikov was in service.

Raskolnikov, surprised, says he is studying. Marmeladov, already drunk but speaking fluently, moves to sit with Raskolnikov. He declares poverty is not a vice, but beggary is, and that he is a beggar. He mentions Mr. Lebeziatnikov beat his wife a month ago and asks if Raskolnikov has ever "petitioned hopelessly for a loan." Raskolnikov admits he has. Marmeladov explains that one goes to ask for money even knowing it's hopeless because "every man must have somewhere to go."

He confesses his daughter first "went out with a yellow ticket" (a reference to prostitution) because of their dire poverty. The tavern boys laugh, but Marmeladov accepts it. He calls himself a "pig" but his wife, Katerina Ivanovna, a lady of education and an officer's daughter. He laments that she doesn't "feel for him" but acknowledges her magnanimity and injustice. He admits she pulls his hair, but he sees it as pity. He sold her stockings and mohair shawl for drink, even though she has consumption and they have three small children. Katerina Ivanovna works tirelessly but is proud and won't tolerate disrespect, which led to her being beaten by Mr. Lebeziatnikov.

Marmeladov continues, recounting Katerina Ivanovna's past as a widow of an infantry officer, left with three children in poverty. He, a widower with his own daughter, Sonia, offered his hand out of compassion. Katerina Ivanovna married him, weeping. For a year he was sober, but lost his job through no fault of his own, and then returned to drink. They now live in a part of a room at Amalia Fyodorovna Lippevechsel's, in dirt and disorder. His daughter, Sonia, had little education. When the children were hungry, Katerina Ivanovna taunted Sonia into prostitution, suggesting "Darya Frantsovna," a woman of "evil character," could help. Sonia silently laid thirty roubles on the table and then covered her face with a shawl and lay on the bed, shuddering. Katerina Ivanovna later knelt and kissed Sonia's feet.

Sonia was forced to take a "yellow ticket" and could no longer live with them due to the landlady and Mr. Lebeziatnikov. She now lives with tailors, the Kapernaumovs, and mostly visits her family after dark, giving them what she can. Five weeks ago, Marmeladov got his job back, and his family rejoiced, treating him with reverence. He brought home his first earnings, twenty-three roubles forty copecks, and Katerina Ivanovna called him her "poppet." But exactly five days ago, he stole the key to Katerina Ivanovna's box, took the remaining money, and has been drunk and away from home since. He spent Sonia's last thirty copecks on the quart of drink he is now finishing. He asks Raskolnikov if he pities him.

When the innkeeper asks why he should be pitied, Marmeladov dramatically declares he should be "crucified," not pitied, for seeking "tears and tribulation" in drink. He speaks of God's mercy forgiving Sonia and all, drunkards and children of shame. He then asks Raskolnikov to accompany him home to Katerina Ivanovna, fearing her eyes and the children's crying more than blows.

They reach Kozel's house and go to the fourth storey. Katerina Ivanovna is thin, emaciated, with magnificent hair and a hectic flush on her cheeks, pacing her disordered room. The youngest child sleeps on the floor; an older boy cries, having been beaten; a nine-year-old girl, Polenka, comforts him. Katerina Ivanovna, unaware of their entry, screams when she sees Marmeladov on his knees in the doorway. She searches him for money, finds none, and drags him into the room by his hair, calling him a "criminal" and "monster." Marmeladov calls it a "consolation." The children cry. Katerina Ivanovna blames Raskolnikov, thinking he drank with her husband, and orders him away. As Raskolnikov leaves, he secretly places some coppers (his change from the tavern) on the window-sill. On the stairs, he regrets it, thinking "they have Sonia and I want it myself," but dismisses it. He reflects that Sonia's "smartness costs money" and that "man grows used to everything." He then questions if man is truly a scoundrel, or if all is "prejudice, simply artificial terrors."

**Chapter III**
Raskolnikov wakes late, bilious and irritable. He hates his tiny, cupboard-like room. His landlady stopped sending him meals two weeks ago. Nastasya, the cook, brings him tea and cabbage soup. She tells him the landlady, Praskovya Pavlovna, plans to complain to the police about his unpaid rent. Raskolnikov dismisses it, plans to talk to her, and admits he's doing nothing now, just "thinking." Nastasya laughs. He mentions needing boots to give lessons and wanting "a fortune." Nastasya then tells him a letter arrived for him yesterday.

The letter is from his mother, Pulcheria Raskolnikov. He feels a sudden pang and wants to be alone to read it. The letter details her distress at his giving up university. She mentions sending him fifteen roubles four months ago, borrowed from Vassily Ivanovitch Vahrushin against her pension. Now, her financial situation has improved, and she can send more. His sister Dounia has been living with her for six weeks, and her "sufferings are over."

The letter explains Dounia's difficult time as a governess with the Svidrigaïlovs. Mr. Svidrigaïlov initially treated her rudely, but later developed a "passion" for her and made an "open and shameful proposal," offering inducements and to take her abroad. Dounia couldn't leave due to a debt to the family (sixty roubles she took to send to Raskolnikov) and to spare Marfa Petrovna, Svidrigaïlov's wife. Marfa Petrovna overheard her husband, misunderstood the situation, and publicly slandered Dounia, sending her home in a peasant's cart. The town gossiped, and acquaintances avoided them.

However, Mr. Svidrigaïlov repented and provided Marfa Petrovna with "complete and unmistakable proof of Dounia’s innocence," a letter Dounia had written refusing his advances and reproaching him. Servants' testimony also cleared Dounia. Marfa Petrovna was convinced, begged Dounia's forgiveness, and spent days circulating the letter and asserting Dounia's innocence, restoring her reputation.

Now, Dounia has a suitor, Pyotr Petrovitch Luzhin, a counsellor and distant relation of Marfa Petrovna. He is well-to-do, has two government posts, and has made his fortune. He is forty-five, prepossessing, but seems morose and conceited. Dounia has consented to marry him, not out of love, but because he is a "practical man" who shares "many of the convictions ‘of our most rising generation’" and is an "opponent of all prejudices." Pulcheria Alexandrovna believes Dounia will make him happy and that he will care for her. Luzhin expressed that he sought a poor girl without a dowry who had experienced poverty, so his wife would view him as her benefactor. Pulcheria Alexandrovna found this rude, but Dounia dismissed it, saying "words are not deeds." Dounia walked all night, praying before deciding.

Luzhin is going to Petersburg to open a legal bureau and will be a great help to Raskolnikov's career. Dounia plans for Raskolnikov to become his associate, even partner. They hope Luzhin will pay for Raskolnikov's university studies, not as charity, but as earned salary. Pulcheria Alexandrovna mentions not wanting to live with them after the wedding, preferring independence near Raskolnikov. She is sending him twenty-five or thirty roubles from a loan against her pension, and she and Dounia are coming to Petersburg very soon, perhaps in a week. She expresses her love for her children and asks if Raskolnikov still prays.

Raskolnikov is deeply affected, his face wet with tears, then pale and distorted with a "bitter, wrathful and malignant smile." He feels suffocated in his room and goes out, forgetting his dread. He walks towards Vassilyevsky Ostrov, muttering to himself.

**Chapter IV**
Raskolnikov's mother's letter is a "torture." He resolves "Never such a marriage while I am alive and Mr. Luzhin be damned!" He sees Dounia's sacrifice as being for his sake, to secure his future. He rejects this sacrifice, stating, "I won’t have your sacrifice, Dounia, I won’t have it, mother! It shall not be, so long as I am alive, it shall not, it shall not! I won’t accept it!"

He then questions how he can prevent it, as he has nothing to offer them. He reflects on Marmeladov's question, "Do you understand, sir, what it means when you have absolutely nowhere to turn?" This brings back a thought he had yesterday, which now appears as a "new menacing and quite unfamiliar shape."

He walks to K---- Boulevard, looking for a seat. He notices a young, drunk girl, disheveled and with her dress torn, staggering in the street. Another gentleman, a plump dandy, is clearly waiting to accost her. Raskolnikov, furious, confronts the gentleman, calling him "Svidrigaïlov" (a name he uses in anger, not necessarily the actual person). A policeman intervenes. Raskolnikov explains the girl's state and the gentleman's intentions, giving the policeman twenty copecks to get her a cab and take her home. The policeman, showing compassion, tries to get her address. The girl mutters, "Go away! They won’t let me alone," and staggers off, followed by the dandy. The policeman follows, sighing about the vice in the world.

Raskolnikov has a sudden "revulsion of feeling." He calls after the policeman to "Let them be! What is it to do with you? Let her go! Let him amuse himself." He then curses himself for interfering, questioning his right to help and his twenty copecks. He feels wretched, wanting to forget everything. He reflects on the girl's likely tragic future, then thinks, "But what if Dounia were one of the percentage!"

He suddenly remembers he was going to see Razumihin on Vassilyevsky Ostrov. Razumihin is an old university comrade, a good-humored, intelligent, and resilient young man who supports himself through various work. Raskolnikov has avoided him for months.

**Chapter V**
Raskolnikov considers asking Razumihin for work but dismisses it as not what he truly wants. He has a "fantastic thought": he will go to Razumihin "on the next day after It, when It will be over and everything will begin afresh." He realizes this implies his "plan" will actually happen. He jumps up, filled with loathing for his room where "all _this_ had for a month past been growing up in him." He walks aimlessly, feeling cold and feverish.

He crosses Vassilyevsky Ostrov and the Lesser Neva bridge, walking towards the islands. The natural beauty temporarily calms him, but soon turns to morbid irritability. He counts his money: thirty copecks. He realizes he gave twenty to the policeman and three to Nastasya, meaning he must have given forty-seven or fifty to the Marmeladovs yesterday. He drinks vodka and eats a pie. The vodka makes him drowsy, and he falls asleep in the bushes in Petrovsky Ostrov.

He has a "fearful dream." He is seven years old, walking with his father to the graveyard in his hometown. They pass a tavern, a place he fears, filled with drunken, shouting people. Near the tavern, a thin, sorrel mare is hitched to a large cart, usually drawn by heavy horses. A peasant named Mikolka, drunk, shouts that he will take everyone in the cart, even if he has to beat the mare to death. Other drunken peasants join him. Raskolnikov, as a child, is horrified and cries out for his father to intervene as Mikolka and others brutally whip the mare. The mare struggles, kicks, and is eventually beaten to death with a shaft and then an iron crowbar. The child Raskolnikov, beside himself, rushes to the dead mare, embraces its bleeding head, and then tries to attack Mikolka. His father pulls him away.

Raskolnikov wakes up, gasping and sweating, relieved it was a dream. He feels utterly broken. He questions if he will truly take an axe and shed blood.
