Raskolnikov was ill for a long time. Prison life, hard labor, bad food, shaven head, and patched clothes did not crush him; he was even glad of the work. His pride was wounded because he could not blame himself for his crime, seeing it as a "simple blunder" rather than a moral failing. He was ashamed of his "hopelessly, stupidly" coming to grief, not the crime itself. He found no particularly terrible fault in his past, believing his theory was no stupider than others. He only recognized his criminality in his failure and confession.

He questioned why he hadn't killed himself, like Svidrigaïlov. He couldn't understand why he chose to live, attributing it to a "dead weight of instinct." He saw his fellow prisoners, even tramps, loved life, prizing small things like a ray of sunshine. He felt a "terrible impossible gulf" between himself and the other convicts, who disliked him and called him an "infidel." During Lent, they attacked him, but he remained calm.

Sonia was universally loved by the convicts, who called her "Little mother Sofya Semyonovna." She wrote letters for them, received gifts from their families, and they admired her.

Raskolnikov dreamt that the world was condemned by a new plague from Asia, causing madness, fury, and endless conflict. Only a few chosen people would survive to found a new race. This dream haunted him. After Easter, he began to recover. Sonia had visited him twice during his illness. He saw her at the hospital gate one evening and felt "something stabbed him to the heart." He missed her when she didn't come.

He was discharged. Sonia had a cold but sent him a note saying she would visit him at work. His heart throbbed. On a warm spring morning, at work by the Irtish river, he sat gazing at the wide, deserted river and the distant nomad tents. He was troubled by a vague restlessness. Suddenly, Sonia appeared and sat beside him. He did not know how it happened, but he was seized by an impulse and flung himself at her feet, weeping and embracing her knees. Sonia was terrified, then understood, and a "light of infinite happiness" filled her eyes. She knew he loved her and that the moment had come.

They could not speak, but tears stood in their eyes. Their pale, thin faces were bright with the dawn of a new future and a full resurrection. They were renewed by love, finding "infinite sources of life" in each other. They resolved to wait and be patient for the remaining seven years of his sentence. Raskolnikov felt he had risen again, and Sonia "only lived in his life."

That evening, Raskolnikov thought of Sonia. He felt the other convicts looked at him differently, and he even spoke with them. He remembered how he had tormented Sonia, but now he knew he would repay her suffering with "infinite love." His past agonies, crime, sentence, and imprisonment now seemed "an external, strange fact." He could not think logically; he was simply feeling. "Life had stepped into the place of theory." He picked up Sonia's New Testament, which he hadn't opened before. He wondered if her convictions and aspirations would now be his. Sonia, happy but almost frightened by her happiness, was also ill again that night. The narrator concludes by stating this is "the beginning of a new story--the story of the gradual renewal of a man, the story of his gradual regeneration, of his passing from one world into another, of his initiation into a new unknown life."

summary_llm:
Gustav Aschenbach, a renowned writer in his fifties, feels overwrought by his work one spring afternoon in 19-- in Munich. During a long walk, he finds himself at the North Cemetery waiting for a tram. There, he observes an unusually appearing, pug-nosed, red-haired man whose presence awakens in Aschenbach a sudden, intense longing for travel, a "youthful longing after far-off places" that manifests as a vivid hallucination of a tropical swampland. Though he previously considered travel merely a hygienic necessity, this new urge is a powerful desire to escape the "steady drudgery" and creative deadlock of his current work, which he feels lacks emotional fire. He decides to take a three to four-week trip to a pleasant southern resort.

Aschenbach's background is detailed: he is an artist of discipline and tenacity, from a family of severe public servants, though his mother brought a "more sensuous blood." He achieved early fame and had to manage a demanding career despite a frail constitution. He consciously cultivated a dignified style, moving away from youthful skepticism. His works often feature a hero-type embodying "intellectual and youthful masculinity" that faces adversity with self-mastery. After his wife's death, he settled in Munich and was ennobled as "von Aschenbach" on his fiftieth birthday. His artistic life has left deep marks on his face.

Two weeks later, Aschenbach departs for Trieste, then Pola, seeking something foreign and quickly reachable. He stops at an Adriatic island but is displeased by the weather and the lack of a sandy beach. Feeling restless, he abruptly decides to go to Venice. He leaves the island on a motorboat and boards a decrepit ship. On board, he encounters a theatrical ticket-seller and a group of young clerks. He is horrified to realize one of the jovial "young" men is an old man in disguise with paint, a wig, and false teeth, and feels a "dream-like estrangement."

The journey to Venice is dreary. Aschenbach feels a growing sense of discomfort as the city appears in a misty rain, different from his past experiences. As the ship enters the narrow port, he sees the previously observed old dandy, now painfully drunk and making repulsive, suggestive gestures. Aschenbach feels the world distorting into the "peculiar and the grotesque." Finally seeing Venice's iconic sights, he feels it's the only proper way to approach the "unreal of cities."

He boards a black Venetian gondola, which evokes feelings of shudder and thoughts of death. The gondolier, a brutal-looking, non-Italian man, insists on taking him directly to the Lido, refusing to go to the steamer dock for the vaporetto. Aschenbach, feeling helpless and suspecting the gondolier is a criminal or trying to cheat him, eventually resigns himself. After being serenaded by musical brigands, they arrive at the Lido dock. Aschenbach goes to get change, and when he returns, the gondola and gondolier have vanished. An old man with a grappling hook informs him the gondolier was unlicensed.

Aschenbach proceeds to his hotel on the beach, where he is given a room with a sea view. Still uneasy from his strange journey, he observes the other guests. He is immediately captivated by a Polish family, particularly a fourteen-year-old boy of "absolutely beautiful" and "godlike" appearance, Tadzio, who resembles Greek sculpture. Tadzio's older sisters are dressed severely, contrasting with his luxurious English sailor suit. Aschenbach notes Tadzio's pale, ivory-like skin, wondering if he is sickly or merely pampered. Their eyes meet briefly across the lobby. Aschenbach is profoundly touched by the family's formal demeanor.

The next day, the weather is still poor. Aschenbach feels depressed and contemplates leaving, recalling past illness in Venice. At breakfast, Tadzio enters, displaying "extraordinary charm" and "godlike beauty." Aschenbach, though initially thinking of leaving, decides he must stay as long as the boy. On the beach, he observes Tadzio playing with other children. He notices a moment of "scorn and detestation" on Tadzio's face towards a Russian family. Aschenbach, while pretending not to look, feels inexplicably cheered. He deduces the boy's name is Tadzio. He watches Tadzio bathe, emerging from the sea like a "frail god," stirring a "sense of myth" in the artist.

Later, in the hotel lift, Aschenbach observes Tadzio close-up, noting his "jagged and pale" teeth, brittle enamel, and general frailty, concluding Tadzio is sickly and "will not grow old." He refuses to acknowledge a "gratification or reassurance" at this thought. That afternoon, Aschenbach visits Venice, but the city's oppressive heat, foul smells, and crowds sicken him, confirming his earlier decision to leave. He makes arrangements for departure the next morning.

However, the next morning, he feels regret, questioning his hasty decision as the air seems fresher. At breakfast, as he prepares to leave, Tadzio enters. Their eyes meet, and Aschenbach whispers a silent "Good-bye, Tadzio!" He leaves the hotel, feeling a "painful journey through all the depths of regret" on the steamboat. He realizes how deeply he is attached to Venice and the prospect of never seeing it again causes him intense misery and tears. At the station, in a moment of extreme conflict about leaving, he learns his trunk has been mistakenly sent to Como. Aschenbach is seized by "adventurous delight" and "unbelievable hilarity." He immediately decides to return to the beach hotel to wait for his luggage, feeling that fate has turned him back, rectifying a grave error. Back in his new, identical room, he sees Tadzio again, and realizes with "exhilaration" and "a conflict of pain and pleasure" that Tadzio was the true reason it was so hard to leave. He performs a "spontaneous act of welcome, of calm acceptance," spreading his arms.

Days turn into weeks under a beautiful, sunny sky. Aschenbach fully unpacks, deciding to remain indefinitely. The easy, splendid rhythm of life, particularly the constant presence of Tadzio, bewitches him. He spends hours on the beach watching the boy, who now regularly walks past his spot, often unnaturally close. Aschenbach feels a connection to Tadzio's beauty, comparing it to "form as the thought of God." He is inspired to write, even making his style emulate Tadzio's "godlike" body, producing a praised prose piece. He experiences mythical dreams, seeing Tadzio as Hyacinth, the youth loved by gods.

The unique, unspoken relationship with Tadzio intensifies. One evening, Tadzio smiles at Aschenbach, an "infatuated, and infatuating" smile like Narcissus, which leaves Aschenbach overwhelmed. He retreats to the dark park, whispering "I love you!"

In his fourth week, Aschenbach notices fewer guests and overhears the hotel barber mention "the plague." Later, in Venice, he detects a "sweetish and drug-like" smell and sees official posters euphemistically warning of gastric diseases. He discovers that the authorities are covering up an outbreak of Indian cholera, which is ravaging the city with an 80% fatality rate, leading to increased crime and debauchery among the lower classes. An English clerk confirms the horrific truth and advises Aschenbach to leave immediately before a quarantine is declared.

Aschenbach is "feverishly excited, triumphant in his possession of the truth," but also filled with "weird horror." He considers warning Tadzio's mother but ultimately chooses to remain silent, intoxicated by his "share in the facts and the guilt," and by the "advantages of chaos." He feels a "dark contentment" and "egregious sweetness" as the city's secret aligns with his own hidden passion.

That night, Aschenbach experiences a frightful, vivid dream of a raging, orgiastic mob worshipping a "foreign god," engaging in wild dances, sacrifices, and "unchastity and fury of decay." He awakens "unnerved, shattered," and "hopelessly under the power of the demon." He no longer cares about being noticed or suspected. Despite others fleeing, the Polish family remains. Aschenbach feels that flight and death might remove all distractions, leaving him alone with Tadzio, and moral laws seem to disappear.

Driven by a desire to please, Aschenbach starts to rejuvenate his appearance, adding youthful details to his clothes, using perfumes, and visiting the barber. The barber dyes his hair black, curls it, and applies cosmetics to his face, making him appear younger, with crimson cheeks and red lips. The barber remarks, "Now the gentleman can fall in love unhesitatingly." Aschenbach, in a red necktie and new straw hat, feels "happy as in a dream."

A storm wind rises, bringing the smell of rotting things. Aschenbach, tracking Tadzio through the labyrinthine, diseased city, gets lost. Tadzio, aware of Aschenbach's pursuit, occasionally looks back to confirm he is still following, not betraying him. Aschenbach is "drunk with the knowledge" and follows "meekly by his passion," but eventually loses sight of the boy. Exhausted and feverish, he collapses on the steps of a cistern in a quiet square, smelling carbolic acid.

In a semi-slumber, Aschenbach has a final internal dialogue, reflecting on the Socratic idea that beauty is the artist's road to the spiritual, but a "perilous road," "wrong and sinful." He concludes that poets cannot be wise and dignified, that their "mastery of our style is all lies and foolishness," and that even the pursuit of form and rigor ultimately leads to "intoxication and to desire," to the "precipice." He feels that he, as a poet, cannot force himself but must "merely let ourselves out." He utters, "And now I am going, Phaedrus. You stay here; and when you no longer see me, then you go too."

A few days later, feeling unwell with vertigo and malaise, Aschenbach learns the Polish family is finally leaving. He goes to the beach. Tadzio, with his last remaining companions, is playing unsupervised. Another boy, Jaschu, forces Tadzio into a wrestling match, pinning him and pressing his face into the sand, nearly strangling him. Aschenbach, enraged, is about to intervene, but Jaschu releases Tadzio. Pale and disheveled, Tadzio walks slowly to the water's edge, ignoring his companions. He wades into the shallows, crosses to a sand-bank, and stands, facing the open sea, isolated. He turns and looks back over his shoulder towards the shore. Aschenbach, watching, feels his head rise and sink on his breast, his face taking on the "loose, inwardly relaxed expression of deep sleep." He imagines Tadzio smiling, nodding, and signaling him to "come out," guiding him towards "egregious promises." As often before, Aschenbach stands up to follow him.

Minutes later, Aschenbach is found collapsed in his chair. That same day, news of his death reaches a "respectfully shocked world."

summary_llm:
**The Ingenious Gentleman Don Quixote of La Mancha**

**Chapter I: Character and Pursuits**
An unnamed gentleman from a village in La Mancha, bordering on fifty years old, lives a modest life with his housekeeper, niece, and a lad. He dedicates almost all his time to reading books of chivalry with such fervor that he neglects his estate, even selling land to acquire more books. He particularly admires the works of Feliciano de Silva. His mind becomes so immersed in these tales of enchantments, battles, and romances that he loses his wits, believing the fictional events to be true history. He decides it is his duty to become a knight-errant, roaming the world to right wrongs and achieve eternal fame. He cleans his great-grandfather's rusty armor, improvising a helmet out of pasteboard for its missing parts. He names his old, lean horse Rocinante and, after much deliberation, names himself Don Quixote. Inspired by Amadis of Gaul, he adds "of La Mancha" to his name. Finally, he chooses a lady to dedicate his deeds to: a good-looking farm-girl from a nearby village, Aldonza Lorenzo, whom he renames Dulcinea del Toboso.

**Chapter II: The First Sally**
Don Quixote, filled with purpose, sets out one hot July morning. He is immediately struck by the realization that he has not been dubbed a knight, a crucial element of chivalry, and resolves to be knighted by the first person he encounters. He journeys all day, talking to himself and imagining his future fame. Towards nightfall, he and Rocinante are exhausted. He spots an inn, which he immediately perceives as a magnificent castle. At the door, he sees two young women, whom he imagines to be noble maidens. A swineherd's horn blast further convinces him of his delusion. Don Quixote courteously addresses the women, who laugh at his appearance. The innkeeper, a fat and peaceful man, comes out, whom Don Quixote mistakes for the "Alcaide of the fortress." The women help him remove parts of his armor, but his makeshift helmet, tied with green ribbons, cannot be removed without cutting. Don Quixote refuses to allow it. He is fed ill-prepared stockfish, which he believes is trout, and is helped to drink through a reed because his helmet prevents him from eating or drinking easily. A sowgelder's pipe convinces him he is being entertained with music. Still, he is distressed by not being formally dubbed.

**Chapter III: The Droll Way in which Don Quixote had himself Dubbed a Knight**
Driven by his desire for knighthood, Don Quixote kneels before the innkeeper after supper, demanding to be dubbed a knight. The innkeeper, amused by Don Quixote's madness, decides to humor him. He explains there's no chapel, so the vigil of arms can take place in the courtyard. He also advises Don Quixote to carry money, clean shirts, and ointment, as real knights-errant do. Don Quixote agrees. He places his armor on a trough by a well and begins his vigil. When a carrier attempts to water his mules, disturbing the armor, Don Quixote strikes him down with his lance. A second carrier suffers the same fate. Other carriers begin stoning Don Quixote, who defiantly protects his armor. The innkeeper intervenes, explaining Don Quixote is mad. To prevent further violence, the innkeeper hastily performs a mock knighting ceremony, reading from his ledger and striking Don Quixote on the neck and shoulder. He then has the two women (named La Tolosa and La Molinera by Don Quixote) gird on his sword and spur. Don Quixote, now a "dubbed knight," mounts Rocinante and departs, without paying.

**Chapter IV: What Happened to our Knight when he Left the Inn**
Elated by his knighting, Don Quixote decides to return home to gather money, shirts, and a squire. On the way, he hears cries and finds a youth, Andres, being flogged by his master, Juan Haldudo. Don Quixote intervenes, ordering the farmer to pay Andres his overdue wages. He dismisses the farmer's attempts to deduct costs and guarantees the payment. After Don Quixote leaves, the farmer flogs Andres even more severely, mocking Don Quixote. Andres vows to find Don Quixote to report the treachery. Don Quixote, believing he has successfully righted a wrong, continues his journey, praising Dulcinea. He encounters a group of Toledo traders and, mistaking them for knights, challenges them to confess Dulcinea's unparalleled beauty. When one trader makes a joking remark, Don Quixote charges him. Rocinante stumbles and Don Quixote falls. A muleteer from the group beats the prone Don Quixote with his broken lance. The traders stop the muleteer and continue their journey, leaving Don Quixote severely battered and unable to move, though he attributes his state to a knightly mishap caused by his horse.

**Chapter V: In which the Narrative of our Knight's Mishap is Continued**
Unable to move, Don Quixote recalls a ballad about Baldwin, wounded on a mountainside, and begins reciting it. A peasant from his village, Pedro Alonso, finds him, recognizes him, and tries to help. Don Quixote, in his delusion, believes the peasant is the Marquis of Mantua and continues his recitations, then switches to the story of the Moor Abindarraez. The peasant, realizing Don Quixote is mad, hoists him onto his ass and gathers his scattered armor, leading him back to the village. The housekeeper and niece are distraught, having been worried about Don Quixote for three days. They blame his chivalry books. Don Quixote, put to bed, claims his injuries are bruises from fighting ten giants. The curate and barber resolve to burn all his books.

**Chapter VI: Of the Diverting and Important Scrutiny which the Curate and the Barber made in the Library of our Ingenious Gentleman**
The curate, barber, housekeeper, and niece begin the "scrutiny" of Don Quixote's library. Many books of chivalry are condemned and thrown into the yard for burning, including "Sergas de Esplandian," "Amadis of Greece" (and its lineage), "Don Olivante de Laura," "Florismarte of Hircania," and "The Knight Platir." "The Knight of the Cross" is also burned. "The Mirror of Chivalry" is banished. However, "Amadis of Gaul" and "Palmerin of England" are spared. "Don Belianis" is set aside for purgation. "Tirante el Blanco" is highly praised for its realistic portrayal of knights and is saved. Several pastoral poetry books are also examined, with most, including Montemayor's "Diana," being spared with some cuts, while others like Gil Polo's "Diana" are kept. "The Fortune of Love" and "The Pastor de Fílida" are also preserved, as are the epic poems "Araucana," "Austriada," and "Montserrate." "The Tears of Angelica" is saved.

**Chapter VII: Of the Second Sally of our Worthy Knight Don Quixote of La Mancha**
Don Quixote, still delirious, shouts about a tourney, leading his household to restrain him. He believes he was cudgelled by Don Roland. That night, the housekeeper burns all the condemned books. The curate and barber wall up the book room, telling Don Quixote that a magician named Friston carried away his study and books. Don Quixote accepts this, believing Friston is an enemy trying to thwart his glory. After fifteen days of quiet at home, Don Quixote persuades a farm laborer, Sancho Panza, to become his squire, promising him the governorship of an island. Don Quixote sells and pawns property for funds. He repairs his helmet and secures a buckler. Sancho brings his ass, Dapple. They leave at night, unseen. Sancho, dreaming of his governorship, discusses his wife becoming a queen. Don Quixote assures him of a kingdom.

**Chapter VIII: Of the Good Fortune which the Valiant Don Quixote had in the Terrible and Undreamt-of Adventure of the Windmills, with other Occurrences worthy to be fitly Recorded**
Don Quixote and Sancho encounter thirty or forty windmills. Don Quixote, in his delusion, sees them as monstrous giants and charges. His lance shatters, and he and Rocinante are thrown. Sancho helps him, pointing out they are just windmills. Don Quixote attributes the transformation to the enchanter Friston. Suffering from his injuries, Don Quixote declares that knights-errant must not complain of wounds, though he allows Sancho to do so. Sancho eats from his provisions. They find a dry branch for a new lance. The next day, Don Quixote warns Sancho not to interfere in battles with knights. They see two Benedictine friars on mules and a coach with a lady. Don Quixote believes the friars are magicians abducting a princess and charges them. He unhorses one friar, who flees. Sancho attempts to strip the fallen friar. The friars' muleteers beat Sancho, leaving him senseless. Don Quixote informs the lady in the coach that he has rescued her and commands her to go to El Toboso to tell Dulcinea of his feat. A Biscayan squire in her retinue challenges Don Quixote. Don Quixote disarms, draws his sword, and after a fierce fight, strikes the Biscayan down. He makes the Biscayan promise to present himself to Dulcinea. The narrative pauses here, noting the original author's abrupt stop.

**Chapter IX: In which is Concluded and Finished the Terrific Battle between the Gallant Biscayan and the Valiant Manchegan**
The second author describes finding more papers in Arabic, which, when translated, continue the story. The battle between Don Quixote and the Biscayan is concluded. Don Quixote defeats the Biscayan, who, bleeding, agrees to his terms: to present himself to Dulcinea del Toboso. Sancho, now recovered, expresses joy over the victory but Don Quixote corrects him, stating it was not an "island" adventure. The author details the discovery of the Arabic manuscript and its translation, confirming the identity of Don Quixote, Sancho Panza ("Sancho Zancas" in the illustration), and Rocinante. He also mentions a marginal note about Dulcinea's skill in salting pigs.

**Chapter X: Of the Pleasant Discourse that Passed between Don Quixote and his Squire Sancho Panza**
Sancho, worried about the Holy Brotherhood, suggests they hide. Don Quixote scoffs, claiming knights are above the law. Sancho wants to dress Don Quixote's wounds. Don Quixote boasts of a "balsam of Fierabras" that can cure all injuries. Sancho is eager for the recipe. Don Quixote vows not to eat from a tablecloth until he obtains a new helmet. Sancho reminds him the Biscayan is already presenting himself to Dulcinea. Don Quixote modifies his vow to obtaining *another* helmet. Sancho laments the scarcity of knights and helmets. Sancho eats from his provisions. They spend the night in a wood. Don Quixote, having lost his lance, fashions a new one from a dry branch. Don Quixote spends the night in vigil, thinking of Dulcinea. Sancho sleeps soundly. They continue their journey, and Don Quixote warns Sancho not to intervene against knights. They arrive at an inn.

**Chapter XI: What Befell Don Quixote with Certain Goatherds**
Don Quixote mistakes the inn for a castle again. The kind innkeeper's family treats his injuries. Sancho is also bruised. Don Quixote believes the innkeeper's daughter is a princess who has fallen in love with him, and promises her loyalty while affirming his love for Dulcinea. Maritornes, an Asturian servant, has a prearranged rendezvous with a carrier. Don Quixote, still believing she is the princess, embraces her in his bed. The jealous carrier discovers them and brutally beats Don Quixote. The bed collapses, and a general brawl erupts in the dark, involving Sancho (who is also beaten) and the innkeeper. An officer of the Holy Brotherhood enters, thinking Don Quixote is dead. Don Quixote, recovering, attributes the violence to enchantments.

**Chapter XII: Of what a Goatherd Related to those with Don Quixote**
Don Quixote, still believing in enchantments, orders Sancho to get ingredients for the balsam of Fierabras. Sancho retrieves them. Don Quixote mixes and boils the balsam, performing blessings. He drinks it, vomits violently, but then feels cured. Sancho also drinks it, but it causes him severe illness and vomiting. Don Quixote attributes Sancho's suffering to his not being a knight. Don Quixote, feeling well, wants to leave. He again refuses to pay the innkeeper, citing the laws of chivalry. The innkeeper and others seize Sancho and give him a blanketing as payment. Don Quixote, seeing this, cannot intervene, believing he is enchanted. Sancho, furious but unable to do anything, eventually escapes on Dapple, leaving his alforjas (provision bags) behind. Don Quixote and Sancho meet a goatherd, Pedro, who tells them the story of Chrysostom, a wealthy student-shepherd who died of love for the beautiful shepherdess Marcela. Chrysostom's will demands a pagan burial at the spot where he first saw Marcela, which causes a commotion in the village. Pedro describes Marcela's beauty and independent spirit, her kindness to the shepherds but her scorn for their advances, leading many to despair. Don Quixote decides to attend Chrysostom's burial.

**Chapter XIII: In which is Ended the Story of the Shepherdess Marcela, with Other Incidents**
Don Quixote, Sancho, and the goatherds set out for Chrysostom's burial. They meet two travelers (Vivaldo and his companion) and their servants, also going to the burial. Vivaldo asks Don Quixote about his armed state, and Don Quixote explains his calling as a knight-errant, citing King Arthur and other legendary knights. The travelers realize he is mad. Don Quixote gives a long discourse on the merits of a knight-errant's life compared to a churchman's. Vivaldo questions the knight's practice of commending himself to ladies instead of God, and the necessity of every knight having a lady. Don Quixote insists on both, describing Dulcinea's superhuman beauty and noble (though modern) lineage. They reach the burial site, where Cardenio is recognized by the curate. On the bier lies Chrysostom, dressed as a shepherd. Ambrosio, Chrysostom's friend, speaks of his virtues and unrequited love for Marcela, and his command to burn his papers. Vivaldo suggests preserving the papers, taking one titled "Lay of Despair."

**Chapter XIV: Wherein are Inserted the Despairing Verses of the Dead Shepherd, together with Other Incidents not Looked For**
Vivaldo reads Chrysostom's "Lay of Despair," which laments Marcela's cruelty, his own jealousy, suspicion, and absence. Ambrosio explains that Chrysostom wrote it during a self-imposed absence from Marcela. Suddenly, Marcela herself appears on a rock, stunning everyone with her beauty. Ambrosio angrily confronts her, accusing her of Chrysostom's death. Marcela defends herself eloquently, arguing that her beauty is a gift of nature, not a tool for deceit. She explains she lives in solitude, never encouraging lovers, and is not to blame for those who persist against hope. She asserts her freedom and purity. Don Quixote, moved by her defense, vows to protect her. The shepherds finish the burial, laying Chrysostom's body in the grave with an epitaph about Marcela's cruelty. Don Quixote resolves to seek Marcela. The narrative ends the "Second Part" here, indicating more to come.

**Chapter XV: In which is Related the Unfortunate Adventure that Don Quixote Fell in with when he Fell Out with Certain Heartless Yanguesans**
Don Quixote and Sancho search for Marcela in the wood for two hours, then rest by a stream. They eat from their provisions. Sancho unhobbles Rocinante, who tries to mate with a drove of Galician ponies. The Yanguesan carriers beat Rocinante. Don Quixote and Sancho intervene. Don Quixote attacks the carriers, wounding one. The carriers retaliate with stakes, beating both Don Quixote and Sancho severely, leaving them incapacitated on the ground. The carriers then leave. Sancho, recovering, calls for the balsam. Don Quixote promises to make it but blames their defeat on attacking commoners, not knights. He tells Sancho to fight commoners himself in the future. Sancho, a man of peace, refuses. They argue. Sancho suggests returning home. Don Quixote, bruised and missing teeth, relies on Sancho to get him on Dapple. They head towards an inn.

**Chapter XVI: Of what Happened to the Ingenious Gentleman in the Inn which he took to be a Castle**
The innkeeper asks what happened. Sancho lies, saying they fell from a rock. The kind landlady and her daughter, with Maritornes, tend to Don Quixote in a crude garret. Sancho exaggerates Don Quixote's fame. Don Quixote, believing he's in a castle, mistakes the innkeeper's daughter for a princess in love with him. Maritornes, who has an arrangement with a carrier, enters the dark room. Don Quixote, mistaking her for the princess, grasps her. The jealous carrier attacks Don Quixote. The bed collapses. A general brawl ensues in the dark, involving the innkeeper, Maritornes, and Sancho. An officer of the Holy Brotherhood arrives, believes Don Quixote is dead, and raises an alarm.

**Chapter XVII: In which are Contained the Innumerable Troubles which the Brave Don Quixote and his Good Squire Sancho Panza Endured in the Inn, which to his Misfortune he took to be a Castle**
Don Quixote recovers, attributing the night's events to enchantment and a "giant's hand." Sancho recounts his own beating. Don Quixote promises the balsam. The officer returns with a light. Don Quixote, offended by the officer's address, is struck on the head with the lamp. Don Quixote again attributes it to an enchanted Moor. Sancho, suffering, questions his master's beliefs. Don Quixote orders Sancho to get balsam ingredients. Don Quixote prepares and drinks the balsam, vomits, then feels cured. Sancho drinks it too, but it makes him violently ill. Don Quixote attributes this to Sancho not being a knight. Don Quixote, feeling cured, wants to leave. He refuses to pay the innkeeper, claiming knight-errantry privileges. The innkeeper and others seize Sancho and give him a blanketing. Don Quixote is enraged but cannot intervene, believing himself enchanted. Sancho, after being blanketed and given wine by Maritornes, escapes on Dapple, leaving his alforjas behind.

**Chapter XVIII: In which is Related the Discourse Sancho Panza Held with his Master, Don Quixote, and Other Adventures worth Relating**
Sancho, bruised and alforjas-less, rejoins Don Quixote. Don Quixote still believes the inn was enchanted. Sancho, convinced it was real, suggests they go home. Don Quixote scoffs, emphasizing the glory of chivalry. Sancho complains of only getting beatings. Don Quixote promises a magic sword. They see two dust clouds, which Don Quixote believes are two armies of giants. Sancho sees only two droves of sheep. Don Quixote names the imaginary armies and their leaders. He charges one "army" (a flock of ewes). The shepherds stone him, breaking his lance, injuring him, and smashing his balsam flask. Sancho finds him injured. Don Quixote blames enchanters for turning armies into sheep. He asks Sancho to check his teeth, then vomits the balsam onto Sancho's beard. Sancho, disgusted, vomits back on Don Quixote. Sancho discovers his alforjas are missing and wants to quit. Don Quixote consoles him, saying good times follow bad. They leave, camping out in the fields.

**Chapter XIX: Of the Shrewd Discourse which Sancho held with his Master, and of the Adventure that Befell him with a Dead Body, together with other Notable Occurrences**
Sancho suggests their misfortunes are due to Don Quixote breaking his oath. Don Quixote admits he forgot. Night falls, they are hungry, and their alforjas are still missing. They see approaching lights and a litter. Sancho is terrified; Don Quixote sees an adventure. He encounters men in white (encamisados) with torches, accompanying a black litter. Don Quixote demands they identify themselves. They refuse. Don Quixote attacks, unhorsing one man and scattering the rest. The fallen man, a licentiate, explains they are priests transporting a body to Segovia. Sancho, meanwhile, loots a mule laden with provisions. Don Quixote is chagrined but accepts the licentiate's explanation. Sancho, having seen his master's "rueful countenance," suggests Don Quixote adopt the name "Knight of the Rueful Countenance." Don Quixote likes the idea. They eat the stolen provisions, but lack wine or water. They hear a constant hammering noise.

**Chapter XX: Of the Unexampled and Unheard-of Adventure which was Achieved by the Valiant Don Quixote of La Mancha with less Peril than any Ever Achieved by any Famous Knight in the World**
Sancho suggests they find water, despite the hammering noise. Don Quixote, taking the noise as a call to adventure, makes a grand speech about reviving knight-errantry and imitating Amadis or Roland. He tells Sancho to wait for three days while he descends into the perilous abyss. Sancho weeps, begs him not to go, and tries to stall by claiming it's almost dawn. When Don Quixote refuses to be deterred, Sancho secretly ties Rocinante's legs with Dapple's halter. Don Quixote, finding his horse unable to move, attributes it to enchantment and agrees to wait for daylight. To pass the time, Sancho begins a long, rambling story about a goatherd and goats crossing a river. Don Quixote loses count of the goats, and Sancho declares the story ended. Sancho discreetly relieves himself in the dark. At dawn, they discover the noise comes from six fulling hammers. Don Quixote is mortified; Sancho laughs. Don Quixote beats Sancho with his pike for the mockery. Don Quixote rationalizes, saying that enchanters disguise things and that his courage was still evident. Sancho, now with renewed fear of his master's madness and beatings, promises to be more respectful. They discuss squire wages, and Don Quixote promises Sancho riches from future kingdoms.

**Chapter XXI: Which Treats of the Exalted Adventure and Rich Prize of Mambrino's Helmet, together with Other Things that Happened to our Invincible Knight**
They encounter a barber wearing his brass basin on his head to shield from rain. Don Quixote immediately identifies it as Mambrino's helmet and charges the barber, who falls from his ass and flees, leaving the basin. Sancho identifies it as a basin. Don Quixote insists it's the enchanted helmet, explaining enchanters alter appearances. Sancho questions this logic, especially in light of past beatings. Don Quixote allows Sancho to swap Dapple's trappings with the barber's ass. Sancho suggests they serve a king or emperor, and Don Quixote agrees, imagining his future as a king. Sancho fantasizes about his wife becoming a queen. Don Quixote outlines the path to fame for knights.

**Chapter XXII: Of the Freedom Don Quixote Conferred on Several Unfortunates who against their Will were being Carried where they had no wish to go**
Don Quixote and Sancho encounter a chain of galley slaves being escorted by guards. Don Quixote believes these men are being taken against their will and vows to free them, seeing it as his duty to right wrongs. He questions each prisoner about their crimes, hearing various tales of petty theft, confession under torture, and pimping. Gines de Pasamonte, a notorious criminal and author of his own life story, is among them. Don Quixote, convinced these men are unjustly oppressed, attacks the guards, freeing the galley slaves. The freed slaves, in a display of ingratitude, stone Don Quixote and Sancho, steal Sancho's coat and the basin-helmet, and flee. Don Quixote blames enchanters for their treachery.

**Chapter XXIII: Of what Befell Don Quixote in the Sierra Morena, which was one of the Rarest Adventures Related in this Veracious History**
Don Quixote laments the ingratitude of the galley slaves. Sancho, fearing the Holy Brotherhood, convinces Don Quixote to take refuge in the Sierra Morena. That night, Gines de Pasamonte, the galley slave, steals Dapple from the sleeping Sancho. Sancho wakes to discover Dapple missing and laments bitterly. Don Quixote consoles him, promising him three ass-colts. They discover a valise containing gold crowns and fine linen. Don Quixote finds a memorandum book with a sonnet and a love letter, suggesting the owner is a rejected lover. They then spot a ragged, wild-looking man leaping among the rocks. A goatherd tells them the story of Cardenio, a once noble youth driven mad by love and betrayal, now living in the mountains. Cardenio appears, and Don Quixote tries to engage him. Cardenio, in a mad fit, attacks Don Quixote with a stone, beating him and Sancho before fleeing. Sancho fights the goatherd, whom he blames for not warning them. Don Quixote separates them, still eager to hear Cardenio's story.

**Chapter XXIV: In which is Continued the Adventure of the Sierra Morena**
Cardenio, now lucid, tells Don Quixote and the others his full story. He fell in love with Luscinda. His friend Don Fernando, Duke Ricardo's son, came to his city, saw Luscinda, and fell in love with her. Don Fernando used a trick to send Cardenio away and secretly married Luscinda. At the wedding, Luscinda declared herself Cardenio's wife in a hidden note and attempted suicide with a dagger. Don Fernando, enraged, left. Cardenio, witnessing this, fled to the Sierra Morena, losing his reason intermittently. He ends his tale.

**Chapter XXV: Which Treats of the Strange Things that Happened to the Stout Knight of La Mancha in the Sierra Morena, and of his Imitation of the Penance of Beltenebros**
Don Quixote decides to perform a penance in imitation of Amadis of Gaul, who griered over Oriana's rejection. He explains he must act mad without cause to prove his love for Dulcinea. Sancho questions his sanity, especially regarding Mambrino's helmet (still a basin to him). Don Quixote strips naked and performs somersaults for Sancho, who then leaves on Rocinante to deliver a letter to Dulcinea. Sancho, returning to the inn, meets the curate and barber. He tries to keep his master's location secret but eventually reveals everything. The curate and barber decide to trick Don Quixote into returning home.

**Chapter XXVI: In which are Continued the Refinements wherewith Don Quixote played the part of a Lover in the Sierra Morena**
Don Quixote, alone, debates whether to imitate Roland's furious madness or Amadis's melancholy. He decides on Amadis, praying and carving verses about Dulcinea on trees. Sancho, meanwhile, has encountered the curate and barber. He confesses the truth about Dulcinea's "enchantment" and his master's madness. The curate and barber, having heard Don Quixote's story and Sancho's account, decide to rescue him. They plan for the curate to disguise himself as a distressed damsel and the barber as her squire. Sancho is instructed to tell Don Quixote that Dulcinea commanded him to return.

**Chapter XXVII: Of how the Curate and the Barber Proceeded with their Scheme; together with Other Matters worthy of Record in this Great History**
The curate and barber borrow clothes and create disguises. The innkeeper and his wife, having heard of Don Quixote's madness, confirm his eccentricities. The curate, realizing his disguise as a damsel is indecorous, suggests the barber take the role. Sancho is instructed to lead them to Don Quixote and to lie about delivering the letter to Dulcinea, claiming she is illiterate and gave a verbal command for Don Quixote to come to her. Sancho agrees, hoping this will lead to his master becoming an emperor. They find Don Quixote, still performing his penance. The disguised barber (Dorothea) kneels before him, begging his aid to avenge a giant who usurped her kingdom (Micomicon). Don Quixote grants the boon, promising to restore her. Sancho, still dreaming of his governorship, imagines selling black vassals from Micomicon. The curate and Cardenio, also disguised, watch. The barber's false beard falls off, but the curate quickly reattaches it with a "charm." Don Quixote still believes it's all enchantment.

**Chapter XXVIII: Wherein is Told the Distressed Duenna's Tale of her Misfortunes**
The duchess asks Sancho about his critical remarks about duennas. The Distressed Duenna (the majordomo in disguise), led by Trifaldin (another servant), appears with twelve veiled duennas, all with beards. She recounts her tale: she was governess to Princess Antonomasia of Kandy. Don Clavijo, a gentleman, seduced and married the princess. Queen Maguncia (the princess's mother) died of grief. The giant Malambruno, the queen's cousin, then enchanted Don Clavijo into a crocodile and Antonomasia into a brass ape, and inflicted beards on all the duennas, stating that only Don Quixote can reverse the enchantment by fighting Malambruno. Don Quixote agrees to the adventure. Sancho is reluctant to travel to Kandy and get a beard shaved. The duke promises Sancho his island if he helps. Don Quixote also demands that Sancho begin his 3,300 lashes for Dulcinea's disenchantment.

**Chapter XXIX: Which Treats of the Droll Device and Method Adopted to Extricate our Love-stricken Knight from the Severe Penance he had Imposed upon Himself**
Doña Rodriguez (the duenna of the house) comes to Don Quixote's room at night, mistaking him for a potential lover, and explains her own grievance: her daughter was seduced by a rich farmer's son who now refuses to marry her, and the duke won't intervene. She also reveals the duchess has two "issues" on her legs, which Don Quixote misinterprets. Suddenly, the duke's servants (the same who disguised as Merlin and others) burst in, flog Doña Rodriguez and pinch Don Quixote as a trick. Don Quixote believes it's enchantment. Meanwhile, Sancho, as governor of Barataria, faces various cases. He cleverly resolves a dispute about a cane containing money and another about a woman defending her purse, banishing a man for idleness. He also deals with a tailor's dispute. These deeds are sent to the duke.

**Chapter XXX: Of Matters Relating and Belonging to this Adventure and to this Memorable History**
Altisidora, feigning death, sings a lament for Don Quixote, blaming his coldness. She claims to have seen devils in hell playing tennis with books, specifically a false "Second Part of Don Quixote." She recovers and admits her "death" was a trick. Don Quixote rejects her again, reaffirming his loyalty to Dulcinea. Don Quixote eventually departs the castle. Sancho is given 200 gold crowns by the majordomo. Altisidora sings a scornful farewell. Don Quixote and Sancho proceed towards Saragossa. They encounter Roque Guinart, a famous highwayman, and his band. Roque's men rob Sancho, but Roque, recognizing Don Quixote, returns the stolen items (except some handkerchiefs). Don Quixote gives Roque moral advice. Roque then helps a young woman, Claudia Jeronima, who shot her lover, Don Vicente Torrellas, for breaking a marriage promise. Roque finds Don Vicente wounded. Claudia, remorseful, faints as Don Vicente dies. Claudia decides to become a nun. Roque writes to a friend in Barcelona to prepare for Don Quixote's arrival.

**Chapter XXXI: Which Treats of Many and Great Matters**
Don Quixote, still recovering from his wounds and the cat incident, is entertained by the duke and duchess. Sancho writes a letter to his wife, Teresa, informing her of his governorship, the duchess's gift, and Dulcinea's disenchantment requiring lashes. Teresa writes back, overjoyed, sending acorns to the duchess and planning to go to court. The page delivers the letters. Don Quixote, Sancho, and the duke and duchess discuss Don Quixote's adventures and the continuing enchantment. Sancho's talk of his family's lineage and the common wisdom of proverbs amuses them.

**Chapter XXXII: Of the Reply Don Quixote gave his Censurer, with Other Incidents, Grave and Droll**
An ecclesiastic at the duke's table criticizes Don Quixote's madness and knight-errantry. Don Quixote defends his profession eloquently, asserting its importance in upholding virtue and justice. Sancho supports his master. The duke, amused by the ecclesiastic's irritation, promises Sancho a government. The ecclesiastic, disgusted, leaves. The duchess's damsels play a trick on Don Quixote, "washing" his beard with lye and soap. Sancho expects similar treatment but dislikes it. Don Quixote is asked to describe Dulcinea, but he says her beauty is beyond words and that she is enchanted. He explains that enchanters persecute him, transforming Dulcinea into a coarse peasant.

**Chapter XXXIII: Of the Delectable Discourse which the Duchess and her Damsels held with Sancho Panza, well worth Reading and Noting**
Sancho, questioned by the duchess, confesses he invented Dulcinea's enchantment to deceive his master and avoid his wrath. The duchess reveals that their enchanters confirm Dulcinea *is* enchanted, despite Sancho's trick. Sancho is confused but accepts this. He recounts his experience in the Cave of Montesinos (a fabricated tale to humor Don Quixote). Sancho then assures the duchess he will be a good governor.

**Chapter XXXIV: Which Relates how they Learned the Way in which they were to Disenchant the Peerless Dulcinea del Toboso, which is one of the Rarest Adventures in this Book**
The duke and duchess plan a new trick. They take Don Quixote hunting. A wild boar appears, and Don Quixote bravely confronts it. Sancho, terrified, climbs a tree, but the branch breaks, leaving him hanging. After the boar is killed, a demon courier appears, announcing that Merlin will reveal the method for Dulcinea's disenchantment. Three triumphal cars arrive, carrying figures of sages. Merlin (the majordomo in disguise) appears and declares that Dulcinea will be disenchanted if Sancho inflicts 3,300 lashes upon his bare buttocks. Sancho refuses vehemently. Altisidora, disguised as the enchanted Dulcinea, appears and pleads with Sancho. Sancho, still resistant, argues about the unfairness. The duke persuades him, promising his island. Sancho agrees, on his own terms (voluntary, no blood drawn, fly-flappers count, Merlin counts). Don Quixote is overjoyed.

**Chapter XXXV: Wherein is Continued the Instruction given to Don Quixote touching the Disenchantment of Dulcinea, together with Other Marvellous Incidents**
Sancho confesses he only gave himself five lashes. The duchess insists on a painful scourge. Sancho writes a letter to Teresa, mentioning his government, the lashes, and a hunting suit for Sanchica. The duchess also writes to Teresa. Later, Trifaldin (the majordomo disguised as a bearded squire) arrives with other bearded duennas. The Distressed Duenna (another disguised servant) tells the story of Princess Antonomasia and Don Clavijo, who were enchanted by the giant Malambruno, and she and her duennas were given beards. Malambruno's wooden horse, Clavileño the Swift, is sent. Sancho refuses to ride it. The duke promises Sancho his island. Sancho and Don Quixote are blindfolded and mounted on Clavileño. Servants blow bellows and use tow to simulate wind and fire. Don Quixote believes they are flying high. Sancho peeks, claiming to see the earth as small as a mustard seed and men like hazelnuts, and that he even dismounted to play with celestial goats. Clavileño explodes, and they fall to the ground. They find a parchment stating the adventure is complete, the duennas are shaved, and Dulcinea will be disenchanted after Sancho's lashes.
