Virgil then proposes to guide the narrator through an eternal space where he will hear despairing shrieks of tormented spirits and see others content in fire, hoping for future bliss. He warns that a worthier spirit must lead the narrator if he wishes to ascend to the regions of the blessed, as Virgil is adjudged a rebel to the Almighty King's law. The narrator, desiring to escape his plight, begs Virgil to lead him to Saint Peter's gate and the dismal spirits. Virgil then moves onward, and the narrator follows.

**Canto II: Virgil's Commission from Beatrice**
As day departs and shadows darken the air, the narrator prepares for the difficult journey. He expresses doubt about his worthiness for such a high enterprise, comparing himself unfavorably to Aeneas (Silvius's sire) and Paul, who traveled to the immortal tribes for momentous purposes. He fears his voyage will end in folly. Virgil perceives this as "vile fear" and reveals why he came. He was among a group of spirits "suspended" (in Limbo) when a blessed and lovely dame, Beatrice, with eyes brighter than the day star, called him. Beatrice told Virgil that her friend (the narrator) was hindered by fear in the desert and turned back, and she feared he was lost. She asked Virgil to assist him with his eloquent tongue, saying it would bring her comfort and that she would praise Virgil to her Master. The narrator then asks Beatrice why she was not loath to leave her "ample space" for the lower regions. Beatrice explains that she is so framed by God's grace that human misery and hell's fire do not affect her. She also reveals that another blessed dame in high heaven (Lucia) grieved for the narrator and influenced God's stern judgment. Lucia had then urged Beatrice, who was seated with Rachel, to help the narrator. Beatrice came down, trusting Virgil's eloquence. Virgil concludes his explanation, stating that Beatrice's tearful eyes doubled his zeal, and he already saved the narrator from the beast. He urges the narrator to overcome his fear, as three blessed maids (Beatrice, Lucia, and the unnamed blessed dame) plan his safety. The narrator, feeling his vigor restored, declares his purpose renewed and affirms Virgil as his guide, master, and lord. They then enter the "deep and woody way."

**Canto III: The Gate of Hell and the Indolent**
They arrive at a lofty portal inscribed with words announcing it as the entrance to the city of woe, eternal pain, and the land of the lost, founded by divine justice, power, wisdom, and primeval love, enduring eternally. The inscription ends with "All hope abandon ye who enter here." The narrator finds these words of hard meaning. Virgil tells him to leave all distrust and fear behind, as they will now see souls doomed to misery who have lost "intellectual good." Virgil takes the narrator's hand and leads him into the "secret place." There, sighs, lamentations, moans, horrible languages, outcries of woe, accents of anger, and deep voices, combined with the sound of hands smiting together, create a tumult that whirls through the air, which is stained with solid darkness. The narrator weeps upon entering. He asks Virgil what he hears and who these woe-stricken people are. Virgil explains these are the wretched souls of those who lived without either praise or blame, mingled with a band of angels who were neither rebellious nor faithful to God. Heaven drove them out, and Hell refuses them. The narrator asks what aggrieves them so. Virgil says they have no hope of death, their blind life is so wretched that they envy every other lot, and both fame and justice scorn them. He instructs the narrator to look and pass by. The narrator then sees a rapidly whirling flag and a train of spirits so numerous he never thought death had despoiled so many. He recognizes some, including one who yielded to base fear and abandoned his high station. He understands these are spirits displeasing to both God and His foes. These naked wretches are stung by wasps and hornets, their cheeks bloody with tears, collected at their feet by worms. Looking further, he sees a throng on the shore of a great stream, eager to cross. Virgil says they will know more when they reach the "woeful tide of Acheron." The narrator remains silent, ashamed. An old man, Charon, hoary with age, approaches in a bark, crying out to the wicked spirits that they will never see the sky again, as he takes them to eternal darkness, fierce heat, and ice. He tells the narrator, a "live spirit," to leave. When the narrator doesn't move, Charon says he must come by another passage, on a nimbler boat. Virgil silences Charon, stating, "so 't is will'd, Where will and power are one." Charon falls silent. The spirits, faint and naked, change color and gnash their teeth, blaspheming God, their parents, mankind, the place, time, and their birth. They draw to the strand, and Charon, with burning eyes, collects them, striking lingerers with his oar. Like autumn leaves, they cast themselves one by one from the shore into Charon's boat. They are carried over the dark wave, and another throng continually gathers on this side. Virgil explains that all who die subject to God's wrath come here, eager to cross because heaven's justice goads them. He confirms that no good spirit has ever passed this way, which explains Charon's complaint about the narrator. The gloomy region then shakes terribly, accompanied by a blast of sad earth shooting forth a vermilion flame, which overcomes the narrator's senses, causing him to drop as if seized by sudden slumber.

**Canto IV: Limbo and the Noble Pagans**
A crash of heavy thunder breaks the narrator's deep slumber, rousing him. He finds himself on the brink of a lamentable valley, a dread abyss filled with innumerable plaints, dark, deep, and thick with clouds, preventing him from discerning its bottom. Virgil, pale, proposes they descend into this "blind world," leading the way. The narrator, seeing Virgil's pallor, asks how he can proceed if his guide yields to dread. Virgil explains his pallor is from pity for the suffering souls below, not fear, and urges them to hasten. They enter the first circle, where only sighs are heard, making the eternal air tremble, caused not by torture but by grief from vast multitudes of men, women, and infants. Virgil explains these spirits are blameless of sin but lacked baptism, "the portal to thy faith." They lived before the Gospel and thus did not serve God aright. Virgil states he is among them, lost for these defects, afflicted only by "desiring without hope." Grieved, the narrator asks if any soul of mighty worth ever left this Limbo to be blessed. Virgil replies that he was new to that state when a "puissant one" (implied to be Christ) arrived with a victorious trophy and drew forth Adam, Abel, Noah, Moses, Abraham, David, Israel and his family (including Rachel), and many others, exalting them to bliss. Before these, no human spirit was saved.

As Virgil speaks, they continue through the "wood" of spirits. They see a flame shining in the darkened hemisphere, indicating a tribe in high honor. The narrator asks who these honored spirits are, separated from the rest. Virgil explains their renown in the upper world earns them favor in heaven. A voice calls out, "Honour the bard Sublime! his shade returns that left us late!" Four mighty spirits, neither sorrowful nor glad, approach. Virgil identifies them: Homer (the monarch of sublimest song, leading with a falchion), Flaccus (Horace, excelling in satire), Naso (Ovid), and Lucan. They greet Virgil, honoring him. The narrator is made the sixth of this learned band. They pass on, speaking of matters left untold, until they reach a magnificent castle, seven times walled and surrounded by a pleasant stream, which they cross as on dry land. Through seven gates, the narrator enters with the sages into a mead of lively verdure. Here, a majestic, authoritative race dwells, speaking seldom but sweetly. They retire to an open, bright, lofty place where many great spirits are manifest. The narrator sees Electra, Hector, Aeneas, Caesar, Penthesilea, King Latinus with his daughter Lavinia, Brutus (who chased Tarquin), Lucretia, Marcia (Cato's wife), Julia, Cornelia, and, apart, the fierce Soldan. He also spies the "master of the sapient throng" (Aristotle) amidst other philosophers: Socrates, Plato, Democritus, Diogenes, Heraclitus, Empedocles, Anaxagoras, Thales, Zeno, Dioscorides, Orpheus, Linus, Tully, Seneca, Euclid, Ptolemy, Hippocrates, Galenus, and Averroes. Virgil then leads the narrator away from this serene air into a climate "ever vex'd with storms," to a place where no light shines.

**Canto V: The Carnal Sinners and Francesca da Rimini**
They descend to the second circle, which, though a lesser space, contains much more grief. Here, Minos stands, grimly examining the crimes of all who enter. He gives sentence by coiling his tail around himself a number of times corresponding to the degree of descent into Hell. Souls confess their crimes to him. Minos warns the narrator to beware how he enters and not to be deceived by the broad entrance. Virgil silences Minos, stating that their passage is willed "where will and power are one." The narrator then hears rueful wailings. He comes to a place where "light was silent all," filled with a bellowing noise like a stormy sea, as a restless, furious blast of hell drives and whirls spirits, dashing them with "sore annoy." Shrieks, lamentations, moans, and blasphemies against God are heard. The narrator understands these are "carnal sinners," in whom reason is swayed by lust, borne by the gust like starlings in winter. Like cranes, they wail as they traverse the sky. He asks Virgil who these "scourg'd" spirits are. Virgil identifies Semiramis, an empress who made luxury lawful; Dido, who slew herself for love; and Cleopatra, a lustful queen. He also points out Helen, Achilles, Paris, Tristan, and a thousand others who died for love. The narrator is overcome with pity. He expresses a desire to speak to two spirits coming together, appearing light before the wind. Virgil tells him to entreat them by the love that carries them. When they are closer, the narrator calls to them. They issue from the troop where Dido ranks, speeding through the ill air. One of the spirits (Francesca) thanks the narrator for his pity and offers to speak while the wind is mute. She mentions her birthplace on the Po river. She explains that "Love, that in gentle heart is quickly learnt," entangled her beloved by her fair form, which was taken from her cruelly. "Love, that denial takes from none belov'd," caught her by pleasing him, and he still does not desert her. "Love brought us to one death: Caina waits The soul, who spilt our life." The narrator looks down in thought, pondering what "sweet thoughts" and "fond desire" led them to their "ill pass." He then asks Francesca how love granted them knowledge of their uncertain wishes. She replies that there is no greater grief than to remember joy in misery. She then recounts how one day they read of Lancelot and how love enthralled him. Alone and without suspicion, their eyes met and cheeks paled as they read. At one point, when they read of the smile rapturously kissed by one deep in love, the other (Paolo) kissed her lips. She states, "The book and writer both Were love’s purveyors. In its leaves that day We read no more." As she speaks, the other spirit wails so sorely that the narrator, heartstruck, faints and falls to the ground like a corpse.

**Canto VI: Gluttony and Florentine Prophecy**
The narrator's senses revive, and he finds himself in the third circle, where ceaseless, accursed, heavy, and cold showers of large hail, discolored water, and sleety flaw descend through the dark air, making the land stink. Cerberus, a cruel, fierce, and strange monster with three throats, barks over the multitude below. His eyes glare crimson, his beard is black, his belly large, and his hands clawed, with which he tears, flays, and dismembers the spirits. The spirits howl like curs, rolling to shield themselves. When Cerberus sees the narrator and Virgil, he opens his jaws. Virgil, taking handfuls of earth, casts it into Cerberus's maw, silencing him. They walk over the prostrate shades, whose emptiness seems like substance. One spirit raises himself and asks the narrator if he recognizes him, as he was "fram'd Or ere my frame was broken." The narrator, not recognizing him due to his suffering, asks his identity. The spirit identifies himself as Ciacco from the narrator's city (Florence), damned for gluttony, like all others here. The narrator expresses grief and asks Ciacco about the future of Florence, if any just citizens remain, and the cause of its discord. Ciacco prophesies that after long striving, the citizens will come to blood, and one party will chase the other out. The first party will fall within three years, and the other will rise by "borrowed force" of one who now rests "under shore," oppressing the first. He states there are only two just men, but they are neglected. Avarice, envy, and pride are the "three fatal sparks" that have set all hearts on fire. The narrator then asks about other worthy Florentines. Ciacco replies these are "blacker spirits," sunk deeper by various crimes, whom the narrator may see if he descends farther. He asks the narrator to remember him when he returns to the "pleasant world," then falls back. Virgil explains that Ciacco will not leave his bed until the last angel-trumpet, when all will resume their bodies and hear their eternal doom. The narrator asks if these tortures will increase, mitigate, or remain severe after the great judgment. Virgil explains that as things grow to more perfection, they feel more sensibly both good and pain; though these accursed souls won't reach true perfection, they will approach it more nearly then. They continue their journey, discussing, until they reach where steps lead below, finding Plutus.

**Canto VII: Prodigal and Avaricious, and the Wrathful**
Plutus loudly exclaims, "Ah me! O Satan! Satan!" Virgil reassures the narrator that Plutus has no power to hinder them and then silences Plutus, telling him his fury will consume him, as their passage is willed on high. Plutus drops to the ground. They descend to the fourth ledge, where the narrator observes more pains. He sees a numerous race leading a "dance" like waves clashing, rolling weights with their chests, then striking each other, exclaiming, "Why holdest thou so fast?" and "And why castest thou away?" They traverse the circle and meet again. The narrator asks who these shorn-headed people are, asking if they were connected to the church. Virgil explains they were distorted in mind, making no proper use of their wealth. He clarifies that Popes and Cardinals, "crowned with no hairy cowls," are also here, ruled by Avarice. The narrator hopes to recognize some. Virgil states their ignoble life makes them indiscernible, and they will forever meet in this "rude shock." Their ill-giving and ill-keeping deprived them of the beautiful world. Virgil then describes Fortune as a general minister ordained by God to rule over the world's advantages, changing them from race to race, beyond man's wisest care. She plans, judges, and reigns, swift and ceaseless in her changes, execrated by many but blessed in her own sphere. They must move on to heavier woe. They cross the circle to the next steep, arriving at a boiling well that pours into a dark foss. They journey beside the inky waters. The dismal stream expands into the Stygian lake. The narrator sees a miry tribe, naked and enraged, sunk in the marsh, striking each other with hands, heads, breasts, and feet, and tearing each other with fangs. Virgil explains these are souls overcome by anger. He adds that beneath the water dwells a multitude whose sighs make bubbles on the surface. Fixed in the slime, they lament their former sad, lazy lives in the sweet air and their current sadness in the murky settlings. They gurgle these strains, unable to utter distinct words. They continue their route, observing the gulping souls, until they reach a tower's low base.

**Canto VIII: The City of Dis**
Before reaching the tower's base, they see two lights on its height, and another light answers from afar. The narrator asks Virgil their meaning. Virgil replies they will soon see what awaits them on the filthy waters. A small bark, ferried by one, quickly comes toward them. The ferryman cries, "Art thou arriv'd, fell spirit?" Virgil replies, "Phlegyas, Phlegyas, This time thou criest in vain; No longer shalt thou have us, but while o'er The slimy pool we pass." Phlegyas pines in ire. Virgil steps into the skiff, and the narrator follows, causing the vessel to seem more heavily laden. As they cross the "dead channel," a spirit asks the narrator why he comes before his hour. The narrator asks the spirit who he is. The spirit says he mourns. The narrator, recognizing him, tells him to tarry in woe. The spirit stretches his hands toward the bark, but Virgil thrusts him back, saying, "Away! down there, To the other dogs!" Virgil then embraces the narrator, praising his just disdain, identifying the spirit as Filippo Argenti, noted for arrogance in life. The narrator wishes to see Argenti whelmed in the dregs, and Virgil promises this wish will be satisfied before they reach the shore. Immediately, the miry tribes attack Argenti, crying, "To Filippo Argenti!" He turns his fangs on himself. They leave him and hear a sudden lamentation. Virgil announces they are nearing the city named Dis, with its grave denizens. The narrator sees vermilion minarets in the valley, which Virgil explains are eternal fire within. They reach the deep fosses moating the city, whose walls appear made of iron. The mariner (Phlegyas) cries, "Go forth! The entrance is here!" On the gates, the narrator sees over a thousand spirits, hurled from heaven, who angrily question his presence, as he is alive. Virgil makes a sign for secret parley. The spirits' scorn abates, and they tell Virgil to come alone, and the narrator to return alone. The narrator is filled with dread, believing he will never return. He cries to Virgil not to desert him, but to retreat together if denied passage. Virgil assures him that no one can deny their passage, as it is permitted by "high Authority." He tells the narrator to wait and comfort his spirit, as he will not leave him. Virgil departs. The narrator hesitates. He cannot hear their terms, but they confer briefly before fleeing inside and closing the gates on Virgil. Virgil returns with tardy steps, eyes on the ground, confidence erased, sighing, "Who hath denied me these abodes of woe?" He assures the narrator his anger is no ground for terror and he will vanquish. He mentions their insolence is not new and that someone of "strong might" is coming unescorted down the steep to open the land for them.

**Canto IX: The Furies, Medusa, and the Arch-Heretics**
The narrator's fear is evident in his pale cheeks, affecting Virgil's demeanor. Virgil, listening intently, states they must win this fight, as aid is offered, but laments its delay. The narrator questions Virgil about whether any descend to this depth from Limbo. Virgil replies it rarely happens, but he once came here, conjured by the sorceress Erictho, to draw a spirit from "Judas' circle" (the lowest place), so he knows the road. He adds that the noisome lake encompasses the "city of grief," which they cannot enter without rage. The narrator is then drawn to the burning top of a lofty tower, where he sees three hellish Furies, stained with blood, with green hydras, adders, and cerastes twisting around them instead of hair. Virgil identifies them as Megaera, Alecto, and Tisiphone. The Furies claw their breasts, smite themselves, and raise a shrill clamor, crying, "Hasten Medusa: so to adamant Him shall we change." They threaten that if the Gorgon is shown, the narrator's return upwards will be lost. Virgil turns the narrator around and covers his eyes with his own hands. A loud-crashing, terrible sound comes over the waves, shaking the shores, like an impetuous wind. Virgil uncovers the narrator's eyes and directs him to look where the smoke is thickest. The narrator sees more than a thousand spirits fleeing before one figure who passes over the Stygian sound with unwet feet, sent from heaven. This messenger, full of noble anger, comes to the gate, touches it with his wand, and it flies open. He addresses the "Outcasts of heav'n," rebuking their insolence against God's will and reminding them of Cerberus's defeat. He then silently turns back. The narrator and Virgil, now secure, enter unopposed. The narrator looks around and sees a wide space replete with pain and torment, thick with sepulchres, like those in Arles or Pola, but here scattered with intensely burning flames. Lamentable moans issue from the open lids. The narrator asks who is interred in these vaults. Virgil answers, "The arch-heretics are here, accompanied By every sect their followers." He adds that more tombs are freighted, with like buried with like, and varying degrees of heat. They turn to the right and pass between the afflicted and the ramparts.

**Canto X: Heretics and Florentine Politics**
They proceed by a secret pathway between the walls and the tormented souls. The narrator asks Virgil if those in the sepulchres can be seen, as their lids are open. Virgil replies they will all be closed when the spirits return from Josaphat with their bodies. He states that Epicurus and his followers, who believe the spirit dies with the body, occupy this part. A voice from a vault suddenly calls out to the narrator, recognizing his Tuscan speech and suggesting the speaker may have dealt severely with the narrator's land. The narrator draws closer to Virgil, who tells him to turn and behold Farinata, who has uplifted himself from his girdle, appearing to scorn even hell. Virgil pushes the narrator toward him, warning him to speak clearly. Farinata asks the narrator about his ancestors. The narrator reveals his lineage. Farinata, uplifting his brow, cries that they were fiercely adverse to him and his party, and he scattered them twice. The narrator replies that his ancestors returned each time, an art Farinata's party has not learned. Then, from an unclosed jaw beside Farinata, another shade rises, looking for someone else with the narrator. Seeing his hope quenched, he weeps and asks, "Where is my son? and wherefore not with thee?" The narrator replies he is led by Virgil, whom Guido (the son) perhaps had in contempt. The spirit immediately cries out, "How! said'st thou he HAD? No longer lives he?" The narrator's delay in replying causes the spirit to fall back supine and disappear. Farinata, meanwhile, remains stern, stating that his party's lack of skill in returning from exile torments him more than his fiery bed. He prophesies that the narrator will know the full weight of that "art" (exile) before fifty lunar cycles pass. He then asks why the Florentine people are so cruel against his kin. The narrator replies that the "slaughter and great havoc" at Arbia, which stained its flood, caused the prayers against Farinata's kin. Farinata sighs, then states he stood alone when Florence was about to be razed, and he openly forbade the deed. The narrator adjures him to solve his doubt: how they view the future but are uninformed of the present. Farinata answers they see "objects far remote" plainly, like one with evil sight, by the "large spendour" of the Almighty Ruler. But as things approach or exist, their intellect fails, knowing nothing of human state except what others bring them. Their knowledge will expire when "on futurity the portals close." The narrator, remorseful for his previous silence, asks Farinata to tell the fallen spirit that his offspring still lives and that his silence was due to his thoughts being occupied by the error Farinata solved. Virgil calls the narrator back. The narrator asks Farinata who else shares his lot. Farinata replies more than a thousand are there, including Frederick II and the Lord Cardinal. He then withdraws. The narrator ruminates on the words of ill foreboding. Virgil enjoins him to remember the harmful words, noting that Beatrice will unfold the future tenor of his life. They turn left, leaving the wall, and go by a path to a valley exhaling noisome steam.

**Canto XI: Structure of Lower Hell**
They reach the edge of a high bank, where more cruel woes are stored. To avoid the fetid exhalation from the abyss, they stand behind a monument inscribed, "I have in charge Pope Anastasius, whom Photinus drew From the right path." Virgil explains they must delay for their senses to accustom to the dire breath. The narrator asks for a way to use the time. Virgil then explains the structure of the lower circles of Hell within these rocks: three close circles in gradation below. All malicious acts, abhorred in heaven, end in injury, caused either by force or fraud. Fraud, being peculiar to man, is more displeasing to God and incurs severer punishment.
The **violent** occupy the first circle, divided into three rounds.
1.  Violence against one's neighbor and possessions: slayers, smiters, plunderers, robbers.
2.  Violence against oneself and one's blessings: suicides (depriving oneself of life and light) and squanderers (reckless waste of talent).
3.  Violence against God: denying and blaspheming His power, contemning nature and her law (Sodom, Cahors, and those contemptuous of the Godhead in their hearts).
**Fraud** is handled in the next circle.
1.  Fraud against one whose trust is won, or on one who withholds strict confidence (breaking the bond of love nature makes): dissimulation, witchcraft, flatteries, theft, falsehood, simony, seducers to lust, those who pawn their honesty.
2.  Fraud against general love and special faith (traitors): the traitor is eternally consumed in the lesser, innermost circle, the "dread seat of Dis."
The narrator, pleased by Virgil's clarity, asks why those in the dull pool (the angry), beaten by rain (the gluttonous), or driven by tempest (the lustful) are not punished within the fiery city of Dis, or why they are condemned at all if God's wrath is not on them. Virgil reminds him of his "ethic page" (Aristotle), which describes three dispositions adverse to Heaven's will: incontinence, malice, and mad brutishness. Incontinence offends God least and incurs least guilt. He explains that those (the incontinent) outside these walls are doomed to vain repentance, receiving less vengeance from divine justice than the "fell spirits" (violent and fraudulent) within Dis. The narrator expresses satisfaction. He then asks Virgil to explain why usury offends celestial goodness. Virgil replies that philosophy reveals how nature imitates the celestial mind and its art, and human art follows nature, making it "second in descent From God." Both were the source of life and excellence for humankind. The usurer walks another path, setting nature and art at nought, placing hope elsewhere. Virgil urges them to proceed, as the time is right for their steep passage down.

**Canto XII: The Violent against Neighbor - Tyrants**
They reach a precipice, rough as an Alp, where a shattered rock forms a passage into the chasm. On the ridge lies the Minotaur, gnawing itself in rage. Virgil tells the monster they are not Theseus, but come only to observe its torments. The Minotaur plunges in a fit of rage, allowing them to descend quickly through the ruined crags. The narrator ponders the ruin. Virgil explains that when he previously descended, this rock was intact, but it toppled down shortly before Christ ("He") arrived to carry off "spoil" from the highest circle, causing a great trembling. He directs the narrator's attention to the "river of blood" (Phlegethon) below, where those who injured by violence are steeped. The narrator sees an ample, bow-shaped foss, circling the plain, guarded by Centaurs with keen arrows. Three Centaurs approach, one asking their purpose and threatening to shoot. Virgil replies they will answer to Chiron when closer, calling the Centaur rash. Virgil identifies Nessus (who died for Deianira), Chiron (who nursed Achilles), and Pholus (prone to wrath). These Centaurs guard the foss, shooting spirits who emerge too far from the blood. As they approach, Chiron notes that the narrator "moves what he touches" (is alive). Virgil explains the narrator is alive, brought by necessity, and a heavenly lady (Beatrice) commissioned him. He asks for a Centaur to guide them across the ford, carrying the narrator. Chiron assigns Nessus. They move along the border of the crimson-seething flood. Nessus points out tyrants immersed in blood, some up to their brows, including Alexander and Dionysius, Azzolino, and Obizzo of Este. He points to another, immersed to the throat, who "in God's bosom smote the heart, Which yet is honour'd on the bank of Thames." The blood becomes shallower, eventually only imbruing their feet, allowing them to cross. Nessus explains that the river's depth decreases here, but on the other side, it sinks lower, where Heaven's justice punishes Attila, Sextus, Pyrrhus, and the Rinieri of Corneto and Pazzo. Nessus then turns back alone.

**Canto XIII: The Violent against Self - Suicides and Profligates**
They enter a forest of dusky foliage, gnarled and thick branches, and venomous thorns, unlike any cultivated field. Harpies, with broad wings, human faces, keen talons, and huge winged bellies, nest and wail in this "drear mystic wood." Virgil warns the narrator that he is in the second round and will remain until the "horrid sand," urging him to look around. The narrator hears sad plaints but sees no one. Virgil, sensing his doubt, tells him to break a twig. The narrator plucks a branch, and the trunk cries, "Why pluck'st thou me?" As dark blood trickles, it adds, "Wherefore tear'st me thus? ... Men once were we, that now are rooted here." The narrator, terrified, drops the bough. Virgil apologizes to the injured spirit, explaining the narrator's disbelief, and asks the spirit to identify himself so the narrator can revive his fame in the upper world. The trunk, pleased by the "pleasant word," identifies itself as one who held "both keys to Frederick's heart," skillfully managing his innermost secrets. His faith cost him his life. He explains that the "harlot" (envy), a common vice of courts, inflamed minds against him, leading to his downfall. His soul, disdainful of scorn, sought refuge in death, becoming "unjust toward myself." He swears he never broke faith to his liege lord and asks the narrator to clear his memory. The narrator, filled with pity, cannot ask more. Virgil asks the spirit how souls are tied in these gnarled joints and if any are ever freed. The trunk, breathing hard, explains that when a fierce soul tears itself from its body, Minos condemns it to this wood. It falls wherever chance hurls it, sprouting into a savage plant. The Harpies feeding on its leaves cause pain and a vent for grief. They will come for their bodies, but will not be clad in them, as it is not just to have what one takes from oneself; their bodies will be hung on their thorns. Suddenly, a noise like a wild boar hunt surprises them. Two naked spirits, torn with briers, flee headlong, breaking branches. The foremost cries, "Haste now, haste thee death!" The other, Lano, falls with a bush. Behind them, black female mastiffs, gaunt and fleet, chase. They tear the fallen spirit piecemeal. Virgil leads the narrator to the thicket that Lano hid in, which mourns through its bleeding wounds, crying, "O Giacomo Of Sant' Andrea! what avails it thee, That of me thou hast made thy screen? For thy ill life what blame on me recoils?" Virgil asks the thicket who it is. It answers that it lived in Florence, which changed its patron (from the Baptist), and that it "slung the fatal noose from my own roof," meaning it committed suicide.

**Canto XIV: The Violent against God - Blasphemers**
Moved by charity, the narrator collects the scattered leaves and restores them to the hoarse trunk. They reach the limit separating the second from the third round, revealing horrible justice. They arrive on a wide, arid plain of thick sand, where no plant grows. The mournful wood waves around it, and the sad foss spreads around the wood. Many naked spirits weep pitifully, subjected to different laws: some lie supine, some crouch seated, others pace incessantly. Slowly, dilated flakes of fire fall over all the sand, and the marble underneath glows, increasing the pain. Wretched hands incessantly try to shake off the heat. The narrator asks Virgil about a huge spirit lying writhen in proud scorn, seemingly heedless of the burning. The spirit, aware of the question, exclaims he is "such as I was When living, dead such now I am," and boasts that Jove cannot take sweet revenge, even if he launches bolts at him with all his might. Virgil, raising his voice, identifies him as Capaneus, one of the seven kings who besieged Thebes, punished because his pride remains unquenched. Virgil warns the narrator not to step on the hot sand but to keep close to the wood. They pass silently to a brook gushing from the forest, whose crimsoned wave fills the narrator with horror. This brook runs through the sand, with stone-built bottom and banks, providing a passage where the flames are quenched. Virgil states this river is the most remarkable thing they've seen since entering Hell. The narrator asks for more knowledge. Virgil explains that on the island of Crete, once pure, stands a huge ancient form (the Old Man of Crete) within Mount Ida. Its head is gold, breast and arms silver, middle brass, and lower part steel, except for a clay right foot. From fissures in its rent parts, tears distill, forming Acheron, Styx, and Phlegethon, which then flow beneath to form Cocytus at the lowest depth. The narrator asks why this stream appears only now. Virgil explains that the place is round, and though they have passed much, they have not yet made the circuit of the whole orb. The narrator then asks about Phlegethon and Lethe. Virgil says the red seething wave (Phlegethon) could have answered the first, and Lethe will be seen not here but where spirits wash away blame removed by penitence. Virgil then declares it's time to quit the wood and follow his steps on the flame-free margins.

**Canto XV: The Violent against Nature - Sodomites**
They proceed on one of the solid margins, enveloped in a mist from the stream that saves them from fire. They encounter a troop of spirits who eye them intently. One spirit recognizes the narrator, catching his skirt and crying, "What wonder have we here!" The narrator recognizes him as Sir Brunetto Latini. Brunetto asks if he may turn back a little to speak. The narrator eagerly agrees, asking if he may sit with him. Brunetto explains that any who stop here for an instant must lie for a hundred years without relief, so the narrator must pass on while he walks beside him. The narrator walks with his head bent in reverence. Brunetto asks what chance or destiny brings the narrator to Hell before his death, and who guides him. The narrator explains he was lost in a valley in the serene life, met Virgil, and is now being led home. Brunetto advises the narrator to follow his star to a glorious haven, prophesying that an "ungrateful and malignant race" (from Fiesole/Florence) will show him enmity for his good deeds. He urges the narrator to cleanse himself of their ways, as fortune has honor in store, and he will be desired by both parties. The narrator expresses regret that Brunetto is not still in the world, remembering his teaching on how to win eternity. He writes down Brunetto's prophecy, saving it for Beatrice. He declares himself prepared for whatever fortune brings. Virgil notes, "He listens to good purpose who takes note." The narrator continues to speak with Brunetto, asking who are most known among his tribe. Brunetto names Priscian and Francesco d'Accorso's son, and another who was transferred from Florence to Vicenza. He says he would add more but must desist, as a new mist and a company he cannot join are approaching. He commends his "TREASURE" (his works) to the narrator. Brunetto then turns and speeds away, appearing like a winner in a race.

**Canto XVI: The Violent against Nature - Sodomites and the Abyss**
They arrive where the water's din is heard falling into the next round. Three swift-running spirits issue from a troop beneath the tormenting storm, crying for the narrator to stay, deeming him an "inmate of our evil land." The narrator notes their recent and old flame-inflicted wounds. Virgil pauses, saying these spirits merit courtesy. The three spirits, upon reaching them, spin around in a restless wheel, directing their faces toward the narrator. One spirit asks the narrator to identify himself, using their great renown as a reason. He identifies the one whose track the narrator follows as Guidoguerra, a noble man, and the next as Aldobrandi. He identifies himself as Rusticucci, brought to this evil by his savage wife. The narrator expresses grief and pity, stating he is a countryman who knows their deeds and names. He explains he is on a journey to the center with a sure guide. Rusticucci asks if courtesy and valor still dwell in Florence, as Borsiere, a recently condemned spirit, brings sad news. The narrator cries out about Florence: "An upstart multitude and sudden gains, Pride and excess, O Florence! have in thee Engender'd, so that now in tears thou mourn'st!" The three spirits look at each other, as men receiving truth, then praise the narrator and ask him to speak of them among mankind if he escapes Hell. They then break their circle and flee swiftly. Virgil pursues his track, and the narrator follows. The water's sound becomes so near and loud they can barely hear each other, like a roaring river falling down a precipice. The narrator has a cord around his girdle, which Virgil bids him loosen. The narrator gives it to Virgil, who casts it into the deep abyss. The narrator wonders at this strange signal. Virgil states that what he expects, and what the narrator is dreaming of, will quickly appear. He then swears to the reader that he saw a shape swimming up through the murky air that would quell the stoutest heart, like one returning from loosening an anchor, who springs up and draws in his feet.

**Canto XVII: Geryon, Usurers, and the Descent**
Virgil addresses the approaching monster, Geryon: "Lo! the fell monster with the deadly sting! Who passes mountains, breaks through fenced walls And firm embattled spears, and with his filth Taints all the world!" Virgil beckons Geryon to shore. The monster appears, its head and upper part on land, but its bestial train not touching the shore. Its face has the semblance of a just man, but the rest is serpent-like, with shaggy claws, and its back, breast, and sides painted with variegated nodes and orbits. It sits perched on the rim, its tail upturned in the void, armed with a scorpion's sting. Virgil announces they must turn towards this beast. They descend toward the right, walking ten paces on the verge to escape the flame and burning marl. Arriving near Geryon, the narrator observes a tribe of spirits seated on the sand near a wide chasm. Virgil instructs the narrator to briefly observe their mien, while he parleys with Geryon to secure its "strong shoulders" for passage. The narrator walks alone among the seated spirits. Their pangs gush from their eyes, and they shift their hands against the vapors and torrid soil, like dogs fighting gnats. The narrator notices each wears a pouch with various colors and emblems around their neck, on which their eyes seem to feed. He sees a yellow purse with a lion's face, another redder than blood with a white-winged goose, and one with a fat azure swine. The spirit with the swine addresses the narrator, asking what he does there. He identifies himself as a Paduan with Florentines and states his neighbor Vitaliano will sit on his left. He mentions hearing them exclaim, "'O haste that noble knight! he who the pouch With the three beaks will bring!'" The spirit then writhes his mouth and lolls his tongue. The narrator returns to Virgil, who is already seated on Geryon's haunch. Virgil encourages him to be bold for the steep descent, telling him to mount first so Virgil can be in the middle to protect him from the tail. The narrator is terrified but spurred by shame, settles on Geryon's huge shoulders. He tries to say "clasp me firm!" but words fail. Virgil embraces him. Virgil commands Geryon to move with ample, easy gyres, mindful of its unusual burden. Geryon loosens from the rim, turns its forked tail, and steers like an eel, gathering air with retractable claws. The narrator experiences immense dread, compared to Phaeton or Icarus. He sees only air and the beast. Geryon slowly wheels downward, the narrator only perceiving their descent by the wind rising to his face from below. He hears the hideous crash of a cataract beneath them, conceiving new terror at the plunge, seeing flames and hearing wailings. He crouches his limbs, realizing how their downward course winds closer to the torments. Geryon lands them at the base of the deep-furrowed rock and springs away like an arrow.

**Canto XVIII: Malebolge - Panderers, Seducers, and Flatterers**
They are now in Malebolge, a place of dark-stained rock, winding in a circle, with a spacious gulf in its midst. The surrounding circle forms ten trenches (bolge) between the gulf and the high craggy banks. Flinty paths, like bridges, advance from the rock's base, crossing moles and dikes to the gulf. Virgil leads left, and the narrator follows. In the first chasm, they see naked sinners being scourged by horned demons with huge lashes, making them bound at the first stripe. The narrator recognizes one sinner, Venedico Caccianemico, and asks what brings him to this "bitter seas'ning." Venedico reluctantly confesses he led "fair Ghisola To do the Marquis' will." He also states that Bologna sends many barterers here, more than tongues taught between the Reno and Savena. A demon strikes him with a thong, crying, "Away! corrupter! here Women are none for sale." They move on to a rock that allows them to ascend to the right, departing from the barriers. Where an arch lets pass the scourged souls, Virgil tells the narrator to pause and observe other miserable spirits. From the old bridge, they watch a pack coming from the other side, excoriated by the lash. Virgil points out a lofty shade, Jason, who won the ram from Colchos. He beguiled Hypsipyle on Lemnos and left her pregnant, and Medea's injuries are also avenged here. All who practiced similar deceit are with him. They move to the next pier. In the second chasm, they hear ghosts jibbering in melancholy sounds, snorting, and smiting themselves. A scurf of foul steam hangs on the banks. The narrator sees a crowd immersed in ordure, appearing as "Draff of the human body." He spots one with a grimed head and identifies him as Alessio Interminei of Lucca. Alessio confesses his flatteries sunk him low. Virgil then points out a "besotted, sluttish courtezan," Thais, who tears herself with nails, whose false lip answered her paramour's "Thankest me much!" with "Say rather wondrously."

**Canto XIX: Simoniacs**
The narrator cries out against Simon Magus and his followers, who prostitute sacred things for gold and silver, for theirs is the third chasm. They mount the following vault. The livid stone is full of equal, circular apertures, like baptismal fonts. From each, a sinner's feet and legs up to the calf emerge, the rest hidden. Their soles are burning, causing violent quivering. Flames glide from heel to point. The narrator asks who is burning in fiercer agony with a ruddier flame. Virgil offers to carry him down. The narrator agrees, trusting Virgil's will. They descend to the depth, and Virgil sets him down directly over the orifice of the quivering limb. The narrator asks the spirit to speak. The spirit shouts, mistaking the narrator for Pope Boniface VIII, asking if he is already there and surfeiting with wealth so early, for which he feared not to take the "lovely lady" (the Church) and mangle her. The narrator, bewildered, is instructed by Virgil to say he is not who the spirit believes. The narrator replies as instructed. The spirit wrenches his feet and sighs woefully. He then reveals he was robed in the "mighty mantle" (papal vestments) and was the son of a "she-bear" (implying nepotism), eager to advance his "whelps." He put his money (simony) above and himself here. His predecessors in simony are dragged beneath his head. He will fall lower when the one he mistook the narrator for arrives, but he has stood here longer than the coming one will. He prophesies that after him, "one yet of deeds more ugly shall arrive, From forth the west, a shepherd without law," who will cover both his and the current spirit's form. This "new Jason" will receive favor from France's monarch. The narrator questions the spirit, reminding him that St. Peter was asked only to "Follow me!" when given the keys, and took no gold or silver. He condemns the spirit's avarice for corrupting the world, treading down good men, and raising bad. He recalls the Evangelist's prophecy of the harlot on the waves (the corrupted Church). He exclaims, "Ah, Constantine! to how much ill gave birth, Not thy conversion, but that plenteous dower, Which the first wealthy Father gain'd from thee!" As the narrator speaks, the spirit, struck by wrath or conscience, violently springs up, spinning on his soles. Virgil is pleased by the narrator's "true words." He catches the narrator in his arms, lifting him, and retraces their descent. He carries him up to the summit of the rock, then gently places him on the rugged path, from where another vale appears.

**Canto XX: Soothsayers**
The narrator looks into a depth moistened with tears and sees a tribe weeping silently, walking with backward gait. Each one is reversed at the neck-bone, so their countenance is averted from the reins, forcing them to advance backward. The narrator weeps, leaning against a rock. Virgil rebukes him, saying, "Here pity most doth show herself alive, When she is dead. What guilt exceedeth his, Who with Heaven’s judgment in his passion strives?" He points out Amphiaraus, for whom earth gaped, now making his breast his shoulders, looking backward. He points out Tiresias, who changed from male to female. Aruns, facing more with his belly, who dwelt in a cavern and beheld stars and the sea. Next is Manto, who searched many regions and fixed her seat in Virgil's native land (Mantua). Virgil recounts Mantua's origin: a lake named Benacus forms the Mincius river, which flows to a marsh. Manto, seeking solitude, settled in this waste territory, where tribes later gathered and built Mantua on her dead bones. Virgil warns against other false origins. The narrator affirms Virgil's words as certain. He asks if there are other spirits of note. Virgil points out Eurypylus, who gave the sign to cut the cable when Greece was emptied of males. Next is Michael Scot, skilled in magic. Guido Bonatti and Asdente (who now regrets not being a cordwainer) are also there. Finally, he points to "wretches" who left their crafts to become Diviners, practicing baneful witcheries. Virgil states they must move on, as the constellation Ursa Major (Cain with his fork of thorns) now confines on either hemisphere, touching the wave beneath Seville's towers. He reminds the narrator that the moon was round last night, aiding him in the wood. They move onward.

**Canto XXI: Barrators (Corrupt Officials)**
They pass from bridge to bridge, reaching a summit to view another gap in Malebolge. Marvelous darkness shadows the place. A glutinous, thick mass boils like pitch, liming the shore beneath. The narrator sees only the surge. Virgil draws him closer, exclaiming, "Mark! mark!" The narrator turns and sees a black devil running along the rock, with fierce cruelty, wings outspread, and nimble feet, carrying a sinner on his shoulder. The devil cries to other "keen-taloned fiends" on their bridge to whelm this "elder of Santa Zita" (a corrupt official) beneath the pitch, as that land (Lucca) has many more barterers (except Bonturo). He dashes the sinner down and returns for more. The sinner sinks and rises writhing. The dark demons grapple him with hooks, shouting that he must be covered and sport himself in secret if he can filch. Virgil tells the narrator to hide behind a rock and not fear, as Virgil has been in such a fray before. Virgil passes beyond the bridge's head. The devils rush from beneath the arch, pointing their weapons at Virgil. Virgil shouts for one to come forth and decide if he shall be torn. They shout, "Go, Malacoda!" One advances, asking what this turn avails Virgil. Virgil replies he came securely by divine will and destiny, as Heaven's pleasure is for him to lead another through this wilderness. Malacoda's pride falls, he drops his instrument of torture, and tells the others they have no power to strike Virgil. Virgil tells the narrator to return safely. The narrator moves quickly, fearing the fiends might break their compact. He adheres to Virgil's side, observing their unkindly visage. The fiends protrude their hooks, one asking if he should touch the narrator's hip, and another answering yes. Malacoda quickly tells Scarmiglione to stay. He then informs them that the rock offers no further footing, being shattered at the base of the sixth arch, but another rock nearby will yield safe passage. Malacoda states that twelve hundred threescore years and six, plus five hours, have passed since the way was broken. He dispatches a troop of ten scouts, led by Barbariccia (Alichino, Calcabrina, Cagnazzo, Libicocco, Draghinazzo, Ciriatto, Graffiacane, Farfarello, and Rubicant), to search around the bubbling tar and safely lead Virgil and the narrator where the other crag traverses the dens. The narrator expresses concern about such an escort, noting their gnarls and threatening scowls. Virgil reassures him, saying their gnarls are only tokens of spite against the tormented souls. The fiends turn left over the pier, each pressing his tongue between his teeth, and Barbariccia gives an "obscene triumphant" signal.

**Canto XXII: Barrators' Deception**
The narrator reflects on seeing various military maneuvers but never such a strange movement as the ten demons. He continues to gaze at the pitch and those burning within. Sinners show their backs to ease pain, then quickly hide. Like frogs at a moat's brink, the sinners stand, but draw back under the wave when Barbariccia approaches. One sinner remains. Graffiacan seizes his locks and drags him up, appearing like an otter. The devils shout for Rubicant to flay him. The narrator asks Virgil who this soul is. Virgil asks the sinner his origin. The sinner replies he was born in Navarre, served king Thibault, and turned to peculating, for which he is now punished. Ciriatto rips him with a tusk. Barbariccia stops him and tells Virgil to inquire further. Virgil asks about his partners in guilt from Latian land. The Navarrese sinner replies he just parted from one not far thence. Libicocco seizes his arm, mangling it. Draghinazzo aims for his thighs, but Barbariccia restrains them. Virgil asks who the spirit was from whom he parted. The sinner replies it was "the friar Gomita" of Gallura, "vessel of all guile," who took money to release his master's enemies and bartered in every charge, and Michel Zanche is with him. He points out another devil grinning, fearing mauling. Barbariccia rebukes Farfarello, who rolls his eyes to strike. The Navarrese sinner offers to make Tuscan or Lombard spirits appear if the fiends abate their fury, promising to whistle for seven others. Cagnazzo deridingly calls it a mischievous device to plunge him down. The sinner insists it is mischief for himself. Alichino gainsays the others, saying if the sinner casts himself down, he won't chase on foot but will fly above the pitch. He suggests they quit the vantage ground to see if he can prevail alone. The fiends all turn their eyes to the other shore. The Navarrese sinner chooses his time, plants his feet on land, and leaps, escaping. The fiends are stung with resentment, especially Alichino, who pursues, shouting, "Thou art caught." But the sinner plunges beneath, and Alichino, raising his breast, retires. Calcabrina, in fury, flies after Alichino, and turns his talons on his comrade. They grapple on the dyke and both fall into the boiling lake. The heat arbitrates, gluing their plumes. Barbariccia dispatches four others, armed, who descend to their posts, stretching hooks toward the floundering fiends. The narrator and Virgil depart, leaving them to that broil.

**Canto XXIII: Hypocrites**
They go in silence and solitude. The narrator muses on Aesop's fable of the mouse and frog, and then fears the devils, having been foiled, will pursue them with greater fury. His hair stands on end. He tells Virgil to hide them quickly. Virgil assures him his thoughts are seen from within and that he has a plan: if the right coast inclines enough, they will descend into another chasm and escape. Before Virgil finishes, the fiends approach with spread wings. Virgil catches the narrator like a mother saving her babe from fire, and casts himself supine down the jutting beach to a pendent rock. Virgil runs along the edge, carrying the narrator in his bosom, faster than water turning a mill wheel. They reach the lowest bed just as the fiends reach the steep above. Virgil is fearless, as High Providence prevented the fiends from leaving their assigned foss. In the depth, they see a "painted tribe" pacing slowly, weeping, faint and toiled. They wear caps with hoods, low over their eyes, like Cologne monks, dazzling gold outside but leaden and heavy within. They turn left with them. The narrator asks Virgil to find a spirit whose name is known. One spirit, hearing Tuscan, calls out for them to stop. Virgil tells the narrator to pause and proceed at their pace. Two spirits approach, burdened by their load. They eye the narrator askance, then confer, noting he seems alive. They ask him, "Tuscan, who visitest The college of the mourning hypocrites," to identify himself. The narrator replies he was bred in Florence and still wears his body. He asks who they are, suffering such grief. One answers their bonnets, bright orange outside, are leaden and heavy. They were "Joyous friars" from Bologna, Catalano (the speaker) and Loderingo, taken by Florence as arbitrators, and their conduct is known in Gardingo. The narrator begins to speak of their miseries but is interrupted by seeing one spirit fixed to a cross with three stakes. Catalano explains this pierced spirit (Caiaphas) was he who counseled the Pharisees that one man should suffer for the people. He lies transverse, and everyone must feel his weight. The father of his consort (Annas) and others from that council are also there. Virgil asks the friar if there is an opening to the right for them to leave without constraint on the dark angels. The friar replies that a rock from the next circle is nearer than they hope, but its cope is shattered here, and they can mount by the ruin. Virgil, realizing Malacoda lied in Canto XXI, stands with head bent, then states, "He warn'd us ill, Who yonder hangs the sinners on his hook." The friar adds that he heard at Bologna that the devil "is a liar, And the father of lies!" Virgil proceeds with disturbed anger, and the narrator follows.

**Canto XXIV: Thieves**
The narrator describes his disheartenment and quick recovery, likening it to a peasant losing hope in winter but regaining it with the changing world. They reach the fallen bridge. Virgil, with a sweet look, assesses the ruin and lifts the narrator up, carefully planning their ascent across the rugged, narrower, and steeper rock. The narrator constantly talks to appear less faint. A voice from the other foss speaks angrily, but the narrator cannot see for darkness. He asks Virgil to descend. Virgil replies, "I answer not, But by the deed." They descend to the eighth mound, where the chasm reveals a crowd of terrible, strange, and hideous serpents. Naked spirits, winged with horrid fear, run amid this woe, their hands bound behind them by serpents whose tails and heads twist in folds before them. An adder darts up and transpierces one spirit at the neck. The spirit instantly kindles, burns, and changes to ashes. The dust then spontaneously rolls up, and the self-same form instantly resumes, like the Arabian Phoenix. The sinner stands aghast. Virgil asks who he is. He answers he is Vanni Fucci, "not long since rained down from Tuscany To this dire gullet," who preferred beastial life and found his den in Pistoia. The narrator asks Virgil to make him stay and inquire his crime, knowing him as choleric and bloody. Vanni Fucci, depicted with dismal shame, confesses he is doomed here for rifling the sacristy and falsely charging another. To ensure the narrator doesn't joy, Vanni Fucci prophesies future events: Pistoia will first pine, reft of the Neri; then Florence will change citizens and laws. From Valdimagra, a vapor drawn by Mars will drive a storm over Piceno's field, bursting to strike down every helpless Bianco. This is told to rend the narrator's heart.

**Canto XXV: More Thieves and Transformations**
After speaking, Vanni Fucci raises his hands in mockery, crying, "Take them, God! I level them at thee!" Serpents immediately coil around his neck and arms, silencing him and binding him. The narrator laments Pistoia's evil, having never seen a spirit swell so proudly against God. Vanni Fucci flees. A centaur, full of fury, Cacus, comes shouting for the "caitiff." Serpents swarm on his haunch up to his human face, and a fire-breathing dragon lies on his shoulders. Virgil identifies Cacus, punished for fraudfully stealing a great herd, killed by Alcides (Hercules). While Virgil speaks, the centaur speeds away. Three spirits come up under them. The narrator doesn't know them, but one names another: "Where Doth Cianfa lurk?" The narrator signals Virgil. He warns the reader that what he is about to tell is hard to believe. A six-footed serpent springs onto one of the spirits (Agnello), fastening upon him: its midmost grasps his belly, forefeet seize his arms, fangs flesh his cheeks, and hinder feet spread on his thighs, with its tail curled on his reins. They melt into each other like burning wax, mingling hues, becoming one form, losing both original shapes. The other two spirits exclaim, "Ah, how dost thou change, Agnello! See! Thou art nor double now, Nor only one." The two heads become one, two figures blend into one form, two arms are made of four lengths, and other body parts change into unseen members, leaving no trace of former shape. The miscreate image passes on. Then, an adder, all on fire, livid and swart, approaches the entrails of another of the two remaining spirits. It transpierces him. The spirit falls down, looks at the serpent, but speaks not, motionless, yawning. The serpent eyes the spirit, and the spirit the serpent. One breathes thick smoke from the wound, the other from the mouth; their vapor columns join. The narrator claims his account surpasses Lucan and Ovid's transformations. The serpent splits its train into a fork. The pierced spirit draws his steps together, legs and thighs compacted, so no juncture is visible. The tail takes the spirit's lost figure, its skin softening, while the spirit's indurates to a rind. The monster's armpits join the spirit's shoulders. The monster's two shorter feet lengthen as the spirit's dwindle. The feet behind twist up to become the part man conceals, which in the wretch is cleft in twain. The shadowy smoke veils both with a new color. One rises upright, and the other falls prone. Their glaring eyes are not yet shifted, though features change. The mounting face of the one standing retreats to the temples, superfluous matter shoots out as ears, the rest shapes the nose, and lips swell. The one on the earth extends his sharpened visage, drawing ears into his head like a slug its horns. His tongue, continuous, severs, while the other's fork closes and unites. The smoke disperses. The soul transformed into the brute glides off, hissing. The other (Buoso), now talking, sputters and turns his new-grown shoulders on him, saying to another, "Along this path Crawling, as I have done, speed Buoso now!" The narrator notes Sciancato was the only one of the first three who didn't change.

**Canto XXVI: Fraudulent Counselors - Ulysses and Diomede**
The narrator ironically praises Florence for its infamy, finding three of its citizens among the plunderers. He prophesies that Florence will soon suffer. They depart the depth, Virgil scaling the flinty steps, drawing the narrator up. They proceed through crags, needing hands to climb. Sorrow seizes the narrator as he recalls what he saw. In the eighth chasm, numerous flames shine like fire-flies, each enclosing a sinner so completely that no token of the theft is visible. The narrator bends forward on the bridge, grasping a flinty mass. Virgil explains that the spirits are "Swath'd in confining fire." The narrator asks who is in a flame that comes so parted at the summit, like the funeral pile of the Theban brothers. Virgil replies that Ulysses and Diomede endure penal tortures there, enduring vengeance for their former wrath. These two deplore the ambush of the horse (Trojan Horse), which opened a portal for imperial Rome's seed, and the guile that reft Achilles from Deidamia, and the stratagem that despoiled Troy of its Palladium. The narrator begs Virgil to pause so he can speak to the "horned flame." Virgil praises the prayer but tells the narrator to refrain his tongue, as Virgil will question them (being Greeks, they might shun discourse with the narrator). When the flame arrives, Virgil addresses the two spirits in one fire. He asks, if he merited anything from them by his "lofty strain" when alive, they should not move until one unfolds how death overtook him. The greater horn of the old flame rolls, murmuring, wagging its top like a tongue, and speaks. Ulysses (implied) recounts his escape from Circe. Neither fondness for his son, reverence for his father, nor love for Penelope could overcome his zeal to explore the world and search the ways of life. He sailed into the deep main with one bark and his faithful band, seeing the shores of Iberia, Morocco, Sardinia, and other islands. Aged, they reached the strait pass where Hercules ordained boundaries. He exhorted his companions not to refuse proof of the unpeopled world, following the sun, reminding them they were formed for virtue and knowledge. These words sharpened their minds. They turned their poop to the dawn, making their oars wings, gaining on the left. They saw stars of the other pole, their own so low it rose not from the ocean-floor. After five lunar cycles, a dim, lofty mountain appeared. Joy turned to mourning when a whirlwind from the new land struck their vessel, whirled it thrice, then lifted the poop and sank the prow, and the booming billow closed over them.

**Canto XXVII: More Fraudulent Counselors - Guido da Montefeltro**
The flame rises, stilling its light, and passes on. Another flame follows, from whose top a confused sound draws their eyes. The voice within addresses the narrator, who recently spoke in Lombard phrase, and asks if those in Romagna have peace or war, as he was from the mountains there. Virgil prompts the narrator to speak, identifying the spirit as a Latian. The narrator replies that Romagna was never without war in its tyrants' bosoms. He describes the current state of various Romagnol cities: Ravenna is steadfast, ruled by Polenta's eagle; the Malatesta family grasp the land; the Malatesta of Rimini still make "an augre of their fangs"; Faenza and Imola range under the Ordelaffi lion, an inconstant partisan; and Cesena lives between tyrant power and liberty. The narrator asks the spirit to identify himself. The fire roars, then speaks, saying that if it thought its answer would reach someone who could return to the world, it would remain silent. But since no one returns from this depth, it answers without fear of infamy. The spirit states he was first a "man of arms," then clothed himself in Saint Francis's girdle, hoping to make amends, and his hope would not have failed but for the high priest (Pope Boniface VIII) who seduced him into sin again. He describes himself as cunning, knowing "all ways of winding subtlety." When he reached the point of life to "lower sails," he repented and confessed. The "chief of the new Pharisees" (Boniface VIII), waging war near the Lateran, not against Saracens or Jews but against Christians (specifically, the Colonna family at Penestrino), sought his aid to cure his pride, asking for counsel to destroy Penestrino. Boniface claimed power to shut and open heaven. Yielding, the spirit deemed silence more perilous and advised Boniface that "Large promise with performance scant" would ensure triumph. When he died, Saint Francis came for him, but a dark cherub met him, crying, "Wrong me not; he is mine, And must below to join the wretched crew, For the deceitful counsel which he gave." The cherub argued that the impenitent cannot be absolved and that repentance and will cannot coexist. The spirit was seized and borne to Minos. Minos twined his tail eight times, biting it with rage, saying, "This is a guilty soul, that in the fire Must vanish." Hence, the spirit roves, prey to sorrow. The flame, having spoken, parts in dolour. The narrator and Virgil go up along the rock to another arch overhanging the foss of committed sin.

**Canto XXVIII: Sowers of Discord**
The narrator describes the impossibility of fully recounting the wounds and blood he now sees in the ninth chasm, comparing it to immense historical slaughters. He sees one spirit, Mohammed, torn from chin to hinder passage, his entrails dangling, who cries, "Now mark how I do rip me! lo! How is Mohammed mangled!" He points out Ali, his face cleft from chin to forelock. All others here, when living, sowed "scandal and schism," and are thus rent. A fiend behind hacks them cruelly with a sword, re-slivering them after their wounds close each time they complete the dismal way. Mohammed asks who the narrator is, lingering to delay pain. Virgil replies that the narrator is alive, not condemned, and Virgil guides him through hell to observe their state. Over a hundred spirits, amazed, forget their pangs and stop to mark the narrator. Mohammed warns the narrator to bear tidings to Dolcino: if he wishes not to follow soon, he must arm himself with good food to avoid falling victim to Novara's power due to snow. Mohammed departs. Another shade, Piero of Medicina, pierced in the throat, with mutilated nostrils and one ear lopped, advances. He bares his wind-pipe, smeared with crimson, and asks the narrator to instruct Guido and Angelo of Fano that they will be cast into the waves near Cattolica through the perfidy of a fell tyrant (Malatestino), an injury fouler than any seen by Neptune. The one-eyed traitor will bring them to conference, then shape their end. The narrator asks who is the one whose sight brings such sad remembrance to the speaker. Piero lays his hand on the cheek-bone of a fellow-spirit, expanding his jaws, crying, "Lo! this is he I wot of; He speaks not for himself: the outcast this Who overwhelm’d the doubt in Caesar’s mind, Affirming that delay to men prepar’d Was ever harmful." (Curio, who advised Caesar). The narrator notes Curio's terrified look, with his tongue cut from his throat. Then one maimed of each hand, Mosca de' Lamberti, bleeding stumps sullied his face, cries, "Remember thee Of Mosca, too, I who, alas! exclaim’d, “The deed once done there is an end,” that prov’d A seed of sorrow to the Tuscan race." The narrator adds, "Ay, and death to thine own tribe." Mosca hurries off, grief-stung. The narrator lingers to behold the troop. He sees a headless trunk, pacing onward, bearing its severed head lantern-wise in hand. The head looks at them and says, "Woe's me!" The spirit lights himself thus, two in one, and one in two. At the bridge's foot, he thrusts his head into view, saying, "Now behold This grievous torment... And that on earth Thou mayst bear tidings of me, know that I Am Bertrand, he of Born, who gave King John The counsel mischievous. Father and son I set at mutual war... For parting those so closely knit, my brain Parted, alas! I carry from its source, That in this trunk inhabits. Thus the law Of retribution fiercely works in me."

**Canto XXIX: Falsifiers - Alchemists**
The narrator's eyes are overwhelmed by the multitude of disfigured souls. Virgil rouses him, asking why he shows such weakness, stating the valley is twenty-two miles around and time is short. The narrator replies that if Virgil knew he was looking for a spirit of his blood, Geri of Bello, he might excuse the delay. Virgil tells him not to afflict himself for Geri, noting he saw Geri point menacingly at the narrator but the narrator was too busy with Bertrand de Born to notice. The narrator explains that Geri's violent, unavenged death made him contemptuous, which is why he passed silently, making the narrator more compassionate. They discourse until the rock shows the next valley. Over the last cloister of Malebolge, a volley of lamentations, headed with pity, assails the narrator, making him close his ears. The torment and stench are compared to all the maladies of various pestilent places combined. They descend to the left. The narrator's sight is livelier to explore this depth, where "All-searching Justice" punishes forgers. The sight of these spirits, languishing and piled in stacks, is compared to the plague in Aegina. They lie confused, one over another, or crawl sideling. Two spirits sit propped against each other, barked round with tetter from head to foot. They rapidly ply their keen nails due to fierce itchiness, scraping off crust like scales from fish. Virgil asks one (who is scratching fiercely) if any of Latian land are among them. The weeping spirit replies both are from Latium and asks who Virgil is. Virgil states he descends with a living man to show him hell's abyss. The spirits start asunder, trembling. The narrator asks their names and race, wishing their memory to survive in the upper world. One answers he dwelt in Arezzo. Albero of Sienna brought him to die by fire, but that is not why he is here. He told Albero in sport that he learned to wing his flight in air, and because he didn't make Albero a Daedalus, Albero had him burned. Minos doomed him to this last chasm for practicing alchemy on earth. The narrator asks if any race is as frivolous as Sienna's. The other leprous spirit hears and exempts Stricca (who used fortune's gifts temperately) and Niccolo (who discovered spice luxury), and the troop with whom Caccia of Asciano lavished his estates and Abbagliato showed his rare wisdom. He then tells the narrator to look closely to know he is Capocchio's ghost, who forged transmuted metals by alchemy and aped creative nature.

**Canto XXX: More Falsifiers - Impersonators, Coinfalsifiers, and Liars**
The narrator describes the frenzies of Athamas and Hecuba to illustrate the madness he now witnesses. He sees two pale, naked ghosts scampering wildly. One (Gianni Schicchi) reaches Capocchio, sinks fangs into his neck-joint, and drags him prone. The other shape (the alchemist from Arezzo) is left trembling and says, "That sprite of air is Schicchi; in like mood Of random mischief vents he still his spite." The narrator asks the alchemist to identify the other. The alchemist replies it is "the ancient soul Of wretched Myrrha," who burned with unholy flame for her father and assumed a false shape to commit sin. The one passing on (Gianni Schicchi) dared to counterfeit Donati's features to affix a seal to a feigned testament to gain property. The two furious shades vanish. The narrator turns to other cursed spirits. He sees one, Adamo, shaped like a lute, suffering from swollen dropsy, his paunch not suiting his visage, his lips gasping for drought. Adamo asks the narrator to regard his woe, craving one drop of water. He constantly sees the rills of Casentino, which dry him up more than his disease. He falsified metal with the Baptist's form (florens) in Romena, for which his body was burned on earth. He would not change a limpid spring for the sight of the Counts of Romena, who employed him. He explains he is fettered and was induced by them to stamp florens with three carats of alloy. The narrator asks about two "abject pair" smoking on Adamo's right. Adamo replies he found them there and they haven't moved since. One is the "false accuser of the Hebrew youth" and the other is Sinon, the "false Greek from Troy." Sharp fever drains their moisture. Sinon, galled, smites Adamo's paunch. Adamo strikes back. Adamo says his heavy limbs prevent movement, but he has an arm for such employ. Sinon retorts that Adamo didn't have such a ready arm when he went to the fire, but it was readier when he coined false gold. Adamo says Sinon speaks true but did not give true testimony when questioned at Troy. Sinon replies if he spoke false, Adamo falsely stamped the coin. Sinon is here for one fault, Adamo for more. Adamo retorts, "O perjur'd one, The horse remember, that did teem with death, And all the world be witness to thy guilt." Sinon returns, "To thine, witness the thirst Whence thy tongue cracks, witness the fluid mound, Rear'd by thy belly up before thine eyes, A mass corrupt." Adamo retorts that Sinon's mouth gapes wide with evil sayings. Adamo, though thirsty, is stuffed with moisture, while Sinon is parched and would lap up Narcissus' mirror. The narrator is fixed on listening. Virgil admonishes him, "Now beware: a little more, And I do quarrel with thee." The narrator feels shame. Virgil says a less grievous fault might be expiated by less shame. He tells him to cast sorrow from his soul, and if chance brings him to such wrangling again, Virgil will be at his side, as such wrangling is for "vulgar minds."

**Canto XXXI: The Giants**
Virgil's sharp reproof, which previously wounded the narrator, now ministers his cure. They turn their back on the vale of woe, crossing the mound in silence. In the dim twilight, the narrator hears a horn sound aloud, its peal making thunder feeble. He spies many lofty towers, which Virgil explains are not towers, but giants, immersed from their navel downwards around the bank. As they near the brink, the narrator's error flees, and fear comes over him. The shore is turreted with giants, half their length rearing up. The narrator descries the face, shoulders, breast, much of the belly, and arms of one. Nature's wisdom is displayed in framing these monsters for mad War, for when brute force and evil will combine with subtlety, no resistance avails. The giant's face is as long and bulky as the pine topping Saint Peter's fane; his stature is immense, with thirty palms of his body exposed. The giant (Nimrod) shouts in fierce, unintelligible lips, "Raphel bai ameth sabi almi." Virgil addresses him, telling him to vent his rage with his horn, for he accuses himself. Virgil explains Nimrod is the one through whose ill counsel one tongue no longer prevails in the world (Babel), and they must pass on, as his language is understood by none. They turn left and find another, fiercer, and huger shade, Ephialtes, fettered from the neck down, five times around. Virgil says this proud one tried his strength against Jove and is thus requited, his great prowess now unmoving. The narrator wishes to see Briareus. Virgil answers that Antaeus, who speaks and is unfettered, is not far and will place them where guilt is at its depth. Briareus is farther on, in chains, like Ephialtes but more fell. Ephialtes shakes like a tower rocked by earthquake. The narrator fears death, but seeing his chains, is reassured. They journey on to Antaeus, who emerges five ells without his head from the cave. Virgil addresses Antaeus, recalling his strength in battle and his spoils of lions, and asks him to place them down where numbing cold locks up Cocytus, promising Antaeus renown in the upper world as the narrator lives. Antaeus stretches his hands and catches Virgil. Virgil catches the narrator, so they are both one burden. Antaeus stoops like the leaning tower of Carisenda. Antaeus lightly places them in the abyss, where Lucifer ingulfs Judas. He then rises like a mast.

**Canto XXXII: Traitors to Kindred and Country**
The narrator expresses the difficulty of describing this "hole of sorrow," calling the folk here "ill-starr'd" and wretched. They stand in the dark pit beneath the giants' feet, but lower. A voice warns the narrator not to tread on the heads of his "poor brethren." The narrator turns and sees a lake, frozen like glass, thicker than the Danube or Tanais. Spirits stand with only their jaws out, blue-pinched and shrunk in ice, moving their teeth like a stork, their faces held downward, expressing cold and dolour. He sees two spirits so strictly joined their hair is mingled. He asks who they are. Their eyes distill tears onto their lips, which the frost binds. They clash together like enraged goats. One spirit, whose ears the cold had reft, asks why the narrator speculates so long. He identifies the two joined spirits as the sons of Alberto, from the valley of Bisenzio, stating Caina has no more worthy pair for congealment, not even those mentioned. He identifies himself as Camiccione, awaiting his kinsman Carlino, whose deep guilt will wash out his own. The narrator sees a thousand dog-like grimaces, chilling him with horror. As they journey toward the middle, the narrator accidentally strikes the face of one spirit. The spirit weeps, exclaiming, "Wherefore dost bruise me? Unless thy errand be some fresh revenge For Montaperto, wherefore troublest me?" The narrator asks Virgil to wait, as he wants to rid himself of doubt. The narrator asks the spirit who he is. The spirit retorts, asking who the narrator is, roaming Antenora and striking with such force. The narrator replies he is living, hoping to enrol the spirit's name for fame. The spirit replies he offers the opposite of what he covets and tells him to vex him no more. The narrator seizes his hinder scalp, demanding his name, threatening to pull out his hair. The spirit says he will not tell. The narrator pulls out tufts of hair. Another spirit cries, "What ails thee, Bocca?" (Revealing the spirit's name as Bocca degli Abati). The narrator tells Bocca he will bear true tidings of him to his shame. Bocca replies, "Tell what thou list; but as thou escape from hence To speak of him whose tongue hath been so glib, Forget not: here he wails the Frenchman's gold. 'Him of Duera,' thou canst say, 'I mark'd, Where the starv'd sinners pine.'" He also points out Beccaria, Soldanieri, Ganellon, and Tribaldello. They leave him. The narrator then sees two spirits pent in one hollow by the ice, one's head like a cowl to the other. The uppermost gnaws the other's brain where the spine joins, like Tydeus gnawing Menalippus' temples. The narrator asks the gnawing spirit the cause of such beastly hate, offering to repay him in the world above if his grievance is just.
