He reflects on her "jilted beauty" and his own sexual desires. He then thinks about Molly, Martha, and other women, and the nature of female desire and menstruation. He picks up a piece of paper on the strand, but cannot read it. He writes "I." in the sand, then effaces it. He sees a bat flying and thinks about metempsychosis. He hears George's church bells cooing "Cuckoo."

**Chapter 14:**
The scene is the National Maternity Hospital, where Mrs. Mina Purefoy is in prolonged labor. The narrative uses an archaic, evolving prose style. A group of men, including Stephen Dedalus and Leopold Bloom, are gathered. The opening emphasizes the importance of human procreation. The text explains the hospital's provision for mothers. Bloom, a "man that on earth wandering far had fared," arrives at the house, feeling "lone." He is there for Mrs. Purefoy. He meets a nursingwoman (a nun), who tells him that Mrs. Purefoy has been in labor for three days. Bloom asks about Doctor O'Hare, and the nun replies that he died three years ago of "bellycrab." Bloom is saddened. He questions the nun about the dead man's death, and she tells him he was shriven and given holy rites. He is advised to consider his own "last end that is thy death." Bloom then asks about Mrs. Purefoy. The nursingwoman describes the difficult birth. A young medical student named Dixon arrives. Bloom and Dixon know each other from when Bloom sought healing for a chest wound inflicted by a "dragon." Bloom enters the "castle" (hospital) to rest. Inside, there is a board with "frightful swords and knives" and "strange fishes withouten heads." There is "fecund wheatkidneys" that swell like a "vast mountain." The learning knight (Dixon) pours Bloom a drink, which Bloom discreetly empties into his neighbor's glass. The nun appeals to them to stop their "wassailing" for the sake of the laboring woman. Stephen is present with other medical students (Lynch, Madden, Lenehan, Crotthers, Costello) and Bloom. They discuss birth and righteousness, with Madden arguing that the wife should live, even if the babe dies. Stephen, with his "mien of a frere," argues about "Godpossibled souls that we nightly impossibilise." He speaks of Lilith, abortions, and how the Church values souls. He also discusses how the body can be infused with a soul and the canon law that a mother who dies in childbirth is a "dam to bear beastly." They ask Bloom if he would risk life to save life, but he evades the question. Bloom is grave, remembering his wife's labor and the death of his only son, Rudy. He grieves for Stephen's "riotous" life. Stephen pours drinks. He then gives a speech about "time's ruins build eternity’s mansions" and how "in woman’s womb word is made flesh but in the spirit of the maker all flesh that passes becomes the word that shall not pass away." He speaks of the "second Eve" and the "sacred pigeon." Punch Costello tries to sing a bawdy song but is interrupted by nurse Quigley, who demands order. Dixon asks Stephen why he didn't take friar's vows, and Stephen replies, "obedience in the womb, chastity in the tomb but involuntary poverty all his days." Lenehan implies Stephen "besmirched the lily virtue of a confiding female." Stephen asserts he is "the eternal son and ever virgin." They joke about "disrobing and deflowering of spouses" like priests in Madagascar. Stephen recounts a poem from "Maid's Tragedy." Stephen argues that Shakespeare's "theme of the false or the usurping or the adulterous brother or all three in one" is always with him, and links this to "original sin." He asserts paternity is a legal fiction and that Shakespeare was his "own father." He then lists Shakespeare's brothers and their names in plays. Stephen then mentions "that brother motive" in Irish myths. Mulligan enters with Alec Bannon. Mulligan proposes a "national fertilising farm" on Lambay Island, named "Omphalos," to encourage procreation, where he would offer his services. Dixon mocks him. The Scotch student (Crotthers) congratulates Mulligan and mentions a locket he carries. Mulligan describes a "lady" in "artless disorder." Lynch proposes a "two things" for which "innocence of our original garb... is the fittest... only garment." Miss Callan, a nurse, enters and informs Dixon that the lady in labor has given birth to a "bouncing boy." The students cheer. Costello makes a lewd comment. Dixon rebukes them for disrespecting the nursing profession and the "house of Horne." Bloom, having observed the "impudent mocks," reflects on the students' "extravagancies." He tells his neighbor that the birth is good news. He thinks of the students' "wonderfully unequal faculty of metempsychosis." He reflects on his own status as an "alien" and his past generosity. The nursingwoman (Miss Callan) officially informs the medical officer of the birth of an heir. The delegates discuss various aspects of birth, including abnormal births, a "plasmic memory," and copulation between women and "males of brutes." Mulligan interjects, postulating "a nice clean old man" as the object of desire. Stephen, asked about Siamese twins, recites the ecclesiastical ordinance against putting asunder what God has joined. Mulligan then tells a horror story: Haines, disguised as a murderer of Samuel Childs, appears from a secret panel, holding a phial of poison and a portfolio of Celtic literature. Haines confesses his crime and says his "hell, and Ireland’s, is in this life." He vanished with a cry "The black panther!" Mulligan declares the "mystery was unveiled," and Haines was the third brother. Bloom's past is then reviewed, showing his youth as a "precociously manly" traveler and then his later life. He reflects on his one-time affair with Bridie Kelly. The "equine portent" grows in the sky, becoming the "everlasting bride," Martha, Millicent, and the "bride, ever virgin." Stephen, crowned with vine leaves, says he is "lord and giver of their life" to the ghosts of the past. Lenehan recounts a horse race where "Throwaway" won, while Boylan's "Sceptre" lost. Bloom, observing the scene, is not mesmerized by the students. He offers a bottle of Bass to the students, pouring some out carefully. The debate continues, with Crotthers, Lynch, Costello, and Madden present. Mulligan and Bannon enter. Mulligan explains his "Omphalos" project. Lynch discusses women and their "natural garment" for a bath. The bell rings, and Miss Callan announces the birth of the baby. Dixon leaves. Bloom reflects on his "plenitude of sufferance." The anonymous narrator reveals that the sailor's tattoo of Antonio's face changes expression. The sailor tells a story about man-eaters and shows a postcard of savage women. Bloom realizes he is thinking of his own travel plans. The narrator (Sailor Murphy) recounts his travels and claims his wife is waiting for him. Bloom thinks of "Enoch Arden" and "Rip van Winkle." Murphy shows his discharge papers. He tells a story about a crocodile and man-eaters. Bloom sees the streetwalker again. Stephen argues against the idea of a simple substance soul. Bloom counters that a supernatural God is not necessarily proven. Stephen cites holy writ. Bloom criticizes him for reading old books. Bloom suspects Mulligan put a narcotic in Stephen's drink. He also suspects Mulligan is "picking your brains." Bloom sees a group of Italians arguing over money.

**Chapter 15:**
The scene shifts to Nighttown, Dublin's red-light district. A deafmute idiot, a pigmy woman, a gnome, and a crone are seen. Cissy Caffrey sings a bawdy song. Private Carr and Private Compton, two soldiers, pass by. Stephen Dedalus and Lynch walk through the crowd. Stephen chants in Latin. A bawd propositions them. Edy Boardman gossips about Cissy Caffrey. Stephen flourishes his ashplant, shattering light. He talks about gestures as a universal language. Lynch calls his philosophy "Pornosophical philotheology." Stephen talks about Shakespeare and Socrates being "shrewridden" and "henpecked." He tells Lynch they are going to Georgina Johnson, and hands Lynch his ashplant. A navvy lurches and ejects snot. River fog creeps through the streets. Bloom appears, flushed and panting, stuffing food into his pocket. He sees his distorted reflection in mirrors. He buys a pig's crubeen and a sheep's trotter from a pork butcher, groaning from a stitch in his side. He sees a searchlight, identifies it as the fire brigade, and hums "London's burning." He dodges a tram, barely avoiding a collision. He sees a sign "Wet Dream" and a phallic design. He reflects on Molly's drawing on a carriage pane. Whores proposition him. The retriever dog sniffs him. His deceased father, Rudolph, appears as a figure in Zion attire, scolding Bloom for his drunkenness and for having "no soul." Bloom apologizes. His mother, Ellen Bloom, appears, lamenting what "they have done to him." Molly Bloom appears in Turkish costume, haughty and mocking, telling Bloom he has "cold feet." She slaps a camel and insults Bloom. Bloom offers to be her "business menagerer." She asks if he notices any change and calls him a "poor old stick in the mud." A lemon soap emerges, singing about Bloom and the sky. Sweny, the druggist, appears. Molly asks if his heart trembles. She walks away disdainfully. The bawd seizes Bloom's sleeve, offering "Ten shillings a maidenhead." Bridie Kelly appears briefly. Gerty MacDowell limps forward, bloody clout in hand, saying Bloom "did that. I hate you." Bloom denies ever seeing her. The bawd insults Gerty. Gerty tells Bloom he saw "all the secrets of my bottom drawer." Mrs. Breen appears, teasing Bloom about being "in the haunts of sin." They discuss Molly. Two black minstrel figures sing. Bloom flirts with Mrs. Breen, reminding her of their past. She asks what he is hiding. Bloom says he has a "snack for supper." Richie Goulding appears, weighed down by his legal bag, full of various foods and pills. Pat, the waiter, appears with a dish of gravy. Richie groans about his back. Bloom points to the navvy as a spy. Mrs. Breen calls Bloom's story "cock and bull." Bloom tries to tell her a "secret" about how he came to be there, but she is "all agog." They walk on. The bawd calls Bloom "Jewman's melt!" Bloom, in an elaborate sporting suit, recounts a memory of Molly at the Fairyhouse races. Mrs. Breen recalls the Leopardstown races. Bloom subtly insults Mrs. Breen's old hat. Mrs. Breen squeezes his arm. Bloom mentions Molly eating a spiced beef sandwich and how she disliked Mrs. Joe Gallaher's style. Mrs. Breen fades away. Bloom passes loiterers discussing a man who urinated in a porter bucket. Whores call out to Bloom. He passes a gramophone blaring. The navvy drags the two redcoats into a shebeen. Bloom loses them, reflecting on his "wildgoose chase." He sees a chalked "Wet Dream" on a wall. The retriever sniffs him. Two watchmen approach Bloom and accuse him of "Commit no nuisance." Gulls appear, eating Banbury cakes. Bob Doran, drunk, falls into an area. Signor Maffei, a lion tamer, appears, introducing his "educated greyhound" and "Mademoiselle Ruby." The watchmen ask Bloom for his name and address. He presents a card for "Henry Flower." They accuse him of "unlawfully watching and besetting." Bloom produces a crumpled yellow flower, claiming it was given to him by a man whose name he doesn't know, and tries to explain his assumed name. The Dark Mercury appears, saying the Castle is looking for Bloom, and that he was "drummed out of the army." Martha Clifford appears, veiled, accusing Bloom of "Breach of promise." Bloom defends himself, claiming "Mistaken identity" and referring to himself as a "medical man." Martha claims her real name is Peggy Griffin and threatens to tell her brother. Bloom calls her "inebriated." The second watchman is tearful. Bloom claims to be a "respectable married man" and invokes his father, Major Brian Tweedy, a war hero. A voice calls him "Turncoat! Up the Boers!" Bloom defends his British loyalty. Myles Crawford appears, dismissing Bloom's literary claims. Philip Beaufoy accuses Bloom of plagiarizing his "bestselling copy." A voice from the gallery calls Bloom "Moses, Moses, king of the jews, / Wiped his arse in the Daily News." Bloom calls it "Overdrawn." Beaufoy insults Bloom's "private life" and "quadruple existence." Mary Driscoll, a scullerymaid, accuses Bloom of making "a certain suggestion" and interfering with her clothing. Bloom says she "counterassaulted." George Fottrell calls for order. Bloom, holding a waterlily, gives a long, unintelligible speech. J.J. O'Molloy defends Bloom, calling him an "infant, a poor foreign immigrant" and attributing his actions to "atavism." Bloom, barefoot and pigeon-breasted, sings a "Li li poo lil chile" song. O'Molloy defends Bloom as a "lonehand fight," saying "When in doubt persecute Bloom." Dlugacz appears with oranges and a pork kidney. O'Molloy, resembling John F. Taylor, speaks of the "sacred benefit of the doubt." Mrs. Yelverton Barry accuses Bloom of an anonymous letter, offering to send her a pornographic book. Mrs. Bellingham accuses him of sending her an edelweiss blossom from a potato plant and urging her to "defile the marriage bed." Mrs. Mervyn Talboys accuses him of sending her an obscene photograph and imploring her to "horsewhip" him. Other ladies hold up improper letters. Mrs. Talboys vows to "flay him alive." Bloom, quailing, says "I love the danger." Mrs. Talboys demands he take down his trousers. Davy Stephens, with newsboys, passes by. The bells of George's church toll. A panel of jurors (Cunningham, Power, Dedalus, Kernan, Lambert, Menton, Crawford, Lenehan, Leonard, Flynn, M'Coy, and a Nameless One) appear, condemning Bloom. The Recorder, Sir Frederick Falkiner, in judicial garb, sentences Bloom to be hanged. Long John Fanning, the subsheriff, asks "Who'll hang Judas Iscariot?" Rumbold, the barber, appears as the hangman. Bloom, terrified, appeals to Hynes, but Hynes disavows him. The second watchman reveals a "bomb" near Bloom. Paddy Dignam's ghost appears, explaining he died of "bellycrab" and requests his other boot. Tom Rochford appears from a machine. Kisses flutter around Bloom. Zoe Higgins, a whore, approaches Bloom and asks if he's looking for someone. She identifies the house as Mrs. Cohen's, "eightyone." She flirts with him, feeling his thigh and then his pocket, where she finds his "talisman" (potato), which she takes. Bloom is captivated by her. She tells him she's English. Bloom offers to make a "stump speech." Chimes ring, calling him "Lord mayor of Dublin!" He imagines himself giving a speech about tramlines and machines. He envisions a grand procession where he is crowned "Leopold the First." The Man in the Macintosh appears, identifying Bloom as "Leopold M'Intosh, the notorious fireraiser." A cannonshot. Bloom's bodyguard distributes items including rubber preservatives and pornographic books. Women rush to touch his robe. Bloom becomes a "little father" to octuplets, all handsome and successful. Bloom, asked if he is the Messiah, says "You have said it." He performs miracles. Brini, Papal Nuncio, recites a long genealogy leading to Bloom. A deadhand writes "Bloom is a cod." Crab and a female infant question Bloom about his past. Bloom blushes. Irish Evicted Tenants sjambok him. Bloom seats himself in a pillory. Artane orphans and Prison Gate Girls caper around him, singing. Hornblower announces Bloom will carry the sins of the people to "Azazel" and "Lilith." People cast stones at Bloom. Mastiansky and Citron call him "Belial." Mesias, Bloom's tailor, presents a bill. Reuben J Dodd appears with his drowned son's corpse, betraying Bloom. The Fire Brigade arrives. Brother Buzz invests Bloom in a yellow habit. Lieutenant Myers sets fire to Bloom. The Daughters of Erin pray for "Kidney of Bloom," "Flower of the Bath," etc. Bloom becomes "mute, shrunken, carbonised." Zoe mocks him. Bloom, as a "black bogoak pig," mourns his ruin. Zoe continues to tease him. Bloom expresses bitterness about love. Zoe seductively leads Bloom towards the musicroom. He hesitates, but she draws him over the threshold. Inside, Lynch and Kitty are present. Florry Talbot lolls on a sofa. Stephen repeats a series of empty fifths on the pianola. Lynch points out Stephen's "knowledge bump." The gramophone blares "The Holy City." Stephen talks about the "ineluctably preconditioned" self. Reuben J Antichrist appears. Florry sinks, crossing herself. A rocket bursts, and "the End of the World, a twoheaded octopus," whirls. Elijah shouts a sermon. Kitty, Zoe, and Florry confess their sins. Lyster and Best appear. Mananaun MacLir, the sea-god, appears, claiming to be "the light of the homestead." A skeleton hand strangles the light. Virag, in various costumes, talks about promiscuous nakedness and the female body, making lewd remarks. Henry Flower appears. Stephen, drunk, plays the piano. Artifoni advises him. Philip Drunk and Philip Sober appear. Virag rants against the Pope and describes sexual acts. Kitty recounts a smothered child. Virag describes sexual acts. Ben Dollard sings. Henry Flower murmurs love songs. Virag leaves, leaving a flybill. Stephen and Lynch discuss religion. Cardinal Stephen Dedalus appears, singing a bawdy song. Bloom offers Zoe chocolate. Lynch and Kitty eat chocolate. Kitty talks about the bazaar. Bloom, in Svengali's overcoat, exorcises. Bella Cohen, the massive whoremistress, enters. She eyes Bloom with "hard insistence" and says, "Married, I see." She claims she was "her was you dreamed before?" Bloom, "cowed," feels her "domination." He confesses he is "exhausted, abandoned, no more young." He sees her unfastened bootlace. He kneels to tie it, recalling his past as a shoefitter. She places her foot on his neck, calling him "Footstool!" Bloom groans. Bello (Bella transformed into a man) taunts him, demanding he wear women's clothes. Bloom is forced to try on women's undergarments. Bello accuses him of being a "male prostitute." Bloom defends himself. Bello further humiliates him, threatening to ride him "for the Eclipse stakes" and to "slaughtered and skewered" him. Bloom whimpers. The whores hold Bloom down. Mrs. Keogh, the cook, appears. Bello sits on Bloom's upturned face, smoking a cigar and cursing his bad luck on "Throwaway." Bloom, goaded, calls them "Monsters!" Bello makes him kiss his figged fist. Bello orders Bloom to shed his male garments and "don the shot silk." Bloom shrinks. Bello describes the "cruel force" of corsets and the "frilly flimsiness of lace." Bloom, transformed into a "charming soubrette," protests he washed Molly's clothes out of "thrift." Bello mocks his "hegoat's udders" and lists the many men who have "violated" Molly. Bloom, "broken," sobs. The circumcised wail over him. A nymph descends from an oakframe, telling Bloom he found her in "evil company." Bloom, crawling, confesses he was a "perfect pig." The nymph accuses him of "Sacrilege!" and strikes at his loins. Bloom protests. The nymph flees, a "cloud of stench escaping." Bella Cohen returns to her normal form. Bloom, composed, insults her. Zoe bangs chords on the piano. Bloom asks for his potato back. Stephen asks, "To have or not to have." Zoe gives him the potato from her stocking. Stephen gives Bella a banknote, saying "We are all in the same sweepstake." Stephen, at the piano, notes the time is "eleven?" and poses a riddle. Zoe gives Bloom the money she earned. Bloom counts his money and Stephen's. Stephen lights a cigarette. Zoe tells Stephen he has a "Woman's hand." Black Liz, a rooster, clucks. Bloom shows a scar on his hand. Stephen says he is "twentytwo." Boylan's car passes. Boylan calls out to Bloom, asking if "Mrs Bloom dressed yet?" Bloom, in flunkey's clothes, says no. Boylan throws him a sixpence and hangs his hat on Bloom's "antlered head," saying he has "private business with your wife." Bloom, horrified, offers Boylan vaseline. The whores talk about Boylan and Molly. Boylan gives a "Godblazeqrukbrukarchkrasht!" and Molly's voice replies with a "Weeshwashtkissinapooisthnapoohuck?" Bloom, agitated, cries "Show! Hide! Show! Plough her! More! Shoot!" Stephen and Bloom look in a mirror, seeing Shakespeare's face. Shakespeare mocks Bloom. Mrs. Dignam, in widow's weeds, passes by, dragging her children. Martin Cunningham, bearded, re-features Shakespeare’s face. Mrs. Cunningham sings. Stephen talks about queens and prize bulls. Zoe links Stephen. Stephen describes Paris brothels. Bella laughs. Stephen talks about a dream of a watermelon. He calls out "Pater! Free!" Simon Dedalus's voice answers. A fox runs, chased by hounds. Garrett Deasy, plastered with postage stamps, brandishes his hockeystick. Private Carr, Private Compton, and Cissy Caffrey sing. Stephen and Zoe dance. Maginni, a dancing professor, enters and dances. The hours of morning, noon, and twilight are personified dancing. Stephen and Zoe dance. Kitty joins. Stephen snatches his ashplant. All dance. Stephen's mother appears, emaciated, reproachful. Buck Mulligan, in jester's dress, mocks her. Stephen, horrified, rejects her. His mother reminds him of his song "Love's bitter mystery." Stephen asks for "The word known to all men." His mother urges him to repent. Stephen calls her "ghoul!" His mother warns him of "God's hand!" Stephen, in rage, shouts "Shite!" and "Non serviam!" He smashes the chandelier. Bloom cries "Stop!" Stephen flees. Bella demands payment for the lamp. Bloom, seizing Stephen's ashplant, argues. He throws a shilling on the table and rushes out. Corny Kelleher arrives in a hackney car with two lechers. Bloom avoids them, hurrying away. A hue and cry of various Dubliners pursues Bloom. At a corner, Stephen stops. Private Carr asks if Stephen insulted Cissy Caffrey. Stephen replies in academic terms. Private Carr gets angry, asking how Stephen would like his jaw bashed in. Stephen says he detests action. Edward the Seventh appears, sucking a jujube. He shakes hands with everyone. Stephen, nervous, declares "Let my country die for me." Edward the Seventh, as "Joking Jesus," sings. Bloom attributes Stephen's words to absinthe. Kevin Egan and Patrice appear. Don Emile Patrizio Franz Rupert Pope Hennessy points a mailed hand at the privates. The citizen calls for a dove with razors to "slit the throats of the English dogs." The Croppy Boy's ghost appears and is hanged. Rumbold, the barber, performs the execution. Edward the Seventh dances. Private Carr questions Stephen. Stephen says he has no money. Old Gummy Granny (Ireland) appears, calling Stephen "Hamlet." Private Carr gets furious. Major Tweedy and the Citizen argue. Stephen quotes about "the harlot’s cry." Private Carr threatens Stephen. Bloom asks Cissy Caffrey to speak. Cissy clutches Carr and cries "Police!" Stephen, ecstatically, quotes a song. Distant voices cry "Dublin's burning!" Brimstone fires erupt. Bands blare. Factory lasses and society ladies dance. Father Malachi O'Flynn celebrates "camp mass." Private Carr threatens Stephen and strikes him in the face. Stephen falls, stunned. Bloom picks up his hat. Major Tweedy calls "Cease fire!" The retriever barks. The crowd demands Stephen be let up. A hag and a bawd argue. Bloom pushes them back. Private Compton and Carr retreat. The watchmen take notes. Corny Kelleher vouches for Stephen. Bloom, speaking confidentially, asks the watchmen to let the matter drop. Corny Kelleher offers Bloom a lift. Bloom declines, saying he will wait for Stephen. The car drives off. Bloom shakes Stephen by the shoulder. Stephen groans, murmuring poetry. Bloom notices Stephen's face reminds him of his mother. A fairy boy (Rudy) appears to Bloom, reading.

**Chapter 16:**
Mr. Bloom helps the disoriented Stephen, brushing shavings from him and handing him his hat and ashplant. He suggests they go to a cabman's shelter for a drink. Bloom realizes he forgot his latchkey and the back button of his trousers is missing. They walk towards the shelter. Bloom describes his miraculous escape from a tram accident earlier. Stephen thinks of Ibsen and stonecutters. Bloom cautions Stephen about the dangers of Nighttown and "women of ill fame," suggesting he needs self-defense skills. He subtly criticizes Mulligan for deserting Stephen and for "picking your brains." Stephen states that Mulligan is "Judas." They pass under the Loop Line bridge, where Stephen recognizes Gumley, a corporation watchman and his father's old friend. Bloom discretely moves away as a figure (Corley) approaches Stephen. Corley, a dissolute man, tells Stephen a sob story about being broke and deserted by friends. Stephen remembers Corley's past and offers him a job at Mr. Garrett Deasy's school. Corley declines, saying he couldn't teach. Stephen admits he has nowhere to sleep. Corley suggests a dosshouse. Stephen discovers his cash is missing, but finds halfcrowns in another pocket. He gives one to Corley. Corley asks Stephen to put in a good word for him with Boylan for a sandwichboard job, mentioning a fellow named Bags Comisky. Bloom observes Corley and his "dilapidated hat," concluding he is a "parasite." Stephen rejoins Bloom and tells him Corley asked him to ask Boylan for a job. Bloom is evasive, mentioning his own face was familiar. He asks how much Stephen gave Corley, then questions why Stephen left his father's house. Stephen replies, "To seek misfortune." Bloom asks about Stephen's father, who has moved. Stephen says he's in Dublin. Bloom diplomatically suggests Stephen could go back home. Stephen, however, remembers the last time he saw his family. Bloom advises against trusting Mulligan. He suggests Mulligan might have drugged Stephen. Bloom reflects on Mulligan's versatility and rescue of a drowning man. He concludes Mulligan is "picking your brains." They observe a group of Italians arguing. Bloom and Stephen enter the cabman's shelter. Bloom orders coffee and a bun. He observes the "redbearded bibulous individual" (the sailor) who has been staring at them. Bloom comments on Italian as a "beautiful language" for singing. Stephen replies they were "haggling over money." The keeper serves them. Stephen suggests "Sounds are impostures... like names." Bloom agrees, mentioning his own name was changed. The sailor asks Stephen's name, and Stephen replies "Dedalus." The sailor recognizes the name, then boasts about Simon Dedalus's marksmanship. Bloom is struck by the coincidence. The sailor introduces himself as D.B. Murphy of Carrigaloe, Queenstown, and says his wife is waiting for him after seven years at sea. Bloom imagines Murphy's homecoming. The sailor asks for tobacco. He shows his discharge papers and describes his extensive travels, including being chased by pirates and seeing man-eaters. He shows a postcard of savage women. Bloom is reminded of his own travel plans to London and a concert tour. He reflects on the "great opportunity" for tourist travel and the need for new routes. He reflects on how the man in the street is "debarred from seeing more of the world." He thinks of various Irish and foreign attractions. The sailor describes a Chinese man with magic pills and his experience of seeing a man killed in Trieste with a knife. He claims the park murders were done by foreigners using knives. Bloom and Stephen exchange glances, knowing "Skin-the-Goat" (the keeper) is listening. Bloom recalls the Phoenix Park murders. The sailor asks for his papers back. Bloom asks if he's seen the Rock of Gibraltar. The sailor expresses tiredness of the sea. Bloom reflects on the "enormous dimensions of the water." He thinks about the "lies a fellow told about himself" versus what others say. He acknowledges that "Analogous scenes are occasionally... met with." He talks about Aztecs. He links the sailor's "stab in the back" story to Italians, noting their passion. He then links this to Molly's Spanish background. Stephen interjects that the "temperaments at the door" were arguing over money. Bloom agrees. Stephen speaks of Dante and isosceles triangles. Bloom connects it to "blood and the sun" and his visit to the museum, where he admired Greek statues. He dislikes "rumpled stockings." The others discuss accidents at sea. The sailor claims a pious medal saved him. They discuss the wreck of the "Palme" off Daunt's rock. The sailor leaves his seat to urinate outside. Bloom observes him drinking rum and easing himself, waking a horse. The corporation watchman, Gumley, shifts in his box. Bloom reflects on Gumley's downfall. They lament the decline of Irish shipping. The keeper claims "wrecks and wreckers" are common and asks if the British government paid Captain John Lever to wreck a ship in Galway Bay. The sailor returns, singing a chanty about "Johnny Lever." The keeper blames England for draining Ireland's resources. The sailor says the Irish are the "best troops in the army." The keeper cares nothing for any empire. Bloom dismisses the claims, believing the English "concealed their strength." He notes that Irish soldiers fought for England as often as against her. He sees the scene as a "confidence trick." He decides that it's better to avoid such "careers of wrongdoing." He admires the courage of men who brandish knives. He tells Stephen that he silenced a man who called him a Jew by saying "his God, I mean Christ, was a jew too and all his family like me though in reality I’m not." Stephen mumbles a Latin phrase. Bloom emphasizes mutual equality and his dislike of violence. He discreetly tells Stephen that Jews are accused of ruining countries, but that history proves the opposite. He advocates for every Irishman having a "comfortable tidysized income." Stephen, staring, states, "Count me out," meaning work. Bloom clarifies he means "work in the widest possible sense." Stephen retorts, "Ireland must be important because it belongs to me." Bloom, unable to interpret, drops the subject. He thinks about O'Callaghan, a "half crazy faddist" who wore a suit of brown paper. He considers writing about "My Experiences... in a Cabman’s Shelter." He reads the newspaper, noting the "L. Boom" misprint of his name. He is also surprised by "Throwaway" winning the Gold Cup. He notes the "Return of Parnell" article. Bloom is surprised by the others' memories of Parnell. He speculates on Parnell's death. He reflects on the "idol with feet of clay." The proprietor disparages Parnell's wife. Campbell praises her. Skin-the-Goat makes a coarse joke. Bloom thinks about the "historic story" of Parnell's affair. He concludes that the husband was "not up to the scratch." He thinks about the "eternal question of the life connubial." He tells Stephen that "blood and the sun" explain everything. Stephen gives a muddled answer. Bloom shows Stephen a faded photo of Molly, in an evening dress, low cut. Bloom calls her "Mrs Bloom, my wife the prima donna Madam Marion Tweedy." He describes her beauty. He thinks about leaving the photo for Stephen to admire. He reflects on the "makebelieve" in marriage and the "sensational extent" of the Parnell scandal. He compares his minor injury at a Parnell rally to the "mud-slinging" surrounding Parnell. He thinks about how women incite men. He reflects on the need for Stephen to find a "Miss Right." He asks Stephen when he dined, and Stephen replies "The day before yesterday." Bloom reflects on their shared thoughts. He decides it is time to go. He offers Stephen to come home for cocoa and a shakedown, believing Stephen will be safe and warm. He thinks about the "grasswidower" sailor and the "most vulnerable point" of Achilles. He pays the fourpence for their drinks. He and Stephen leave the shelter. Bloom explains that tables are turned upside down to "sweep the floor in the morning." They walk arm in arm. Bloom tells Stephen that Molly "would have the greatest of pleasure in making your acquaintance as she is passionately attached to music of any kind." Stephen describes variations on an air by Sweelinck. Bloom suggests Stephen could have a successful singing career. He plans to advise Stephen to break ties with Mulligan. The horse pulling a sweeper stops and mired three globes of turds. Bloom and Stephen pass through the chains, and walk towards Gardiner Street. Stephen sings the end of the ballad. The driver watches them walk away.

**Chapter 17:**
Bloom and Stephen walk together from Beresford Place towards Bloom's home at 7 Eccles Street. They discuss music, literature, Ireland, women, prostitution, diet, the Roman Catholic Church, celibacy, jesuit education, and Stephen's collapse. They find common factors: sensitivity to art, preference for continental life, and disbelief in orthodox doctrines. They differ on diet and civic self-help (Bloom) versus the eternal affirmation of the spirit (Stephen). Bloom covertly agrees with Stephen's correction of an historical anachronism. Stephen attributes his collapse to a "matutinal cloud," while Bloom blames gastric issues. They both agree on the neutral influence of gaslight on trees. Bloom recalls past nocturnal conversations about similar topics, from 1884 to 1893. He notes that "progressive extension of the field of individual development and experience was regressively accompanied by a restriction of the converse domain of interindividual relations." They arrive at 7 Eccles Street. Bloom realizes he forgot his latchkey in another pair of trousers. He climbs over the area railings, falls, but is uninjured. He enters through the scullery, lights gas and a candle. Stephen, waiting outside, sees these actions. Stephen enters softly, following Bloom to the kitchen. Bloom extinguishes the candle and builds a fire. Stephen thinks of others who kindled fires for him, including his father and mother. Stephen observes handkerchiefs and stockings hanging to dry on a rope. Bloom sees a saucepan and kettle on the range. He gets water from the tap, reflecting on water's universality and qualities, the drought, and the city's water supply problems. He washes his hands with lemon soap. Stephen declines a bath, calling himself "hydrophobe." Bloom represses hygiene advice. Bloom notes Stephen's confidence and power. The kettle boils. Bloom considers shaving. He reflects on the "surety of the sense of touch" in his hand and his reluctance to shed human blood. Bloom opens the kitchen dresser, revealing various items, including coins, olives, Plumtree's potted meat, cocoa, tea, sugar, milk, and ribsteak. He notices two lacerated scarlet betting tickets. He recalls the Gold Cup horse race result from the "Evening Telegraph," and earlier intimations of the result in pubs and from Elijah's throwaway. He considers the difficulties of interpretation and counterestimating losses. He is satisfied at having sustained "no positive loss" and brought "positive gain to others." He prepares cocoa for Stephen and himself, serving Stephen the cream usually reserved for Molly. Stephen accepts the cocoa. Bloom considers mending Stephen's jacket and giving him a handkerchief. Bloom drinks his cocoa faster. He reflects on the pleasures of literature and his own youthful poem. He identifies four "separating forces" between them: name, age, race, creed. He recalls anagrams of his name and an acrostic he sent Molly. He lists reasons he couldn't complete a topical song, including the Queen's Jubilee, the new fish market, theater competition, Nelly Bouverist's underclothing, and rhymes. Their ages are compared, showing a widening disparity. These calculations are subject to the "cessation of existence" or "annihilation of the world." He recalls two previous encounters with Stephen, one in 1887 and one in 1892. Bloom declines Stephen's dinner invitation. A third link is revealed: Mrs. Riordan (Dante), who stayed with Stephen's parents and later with Bloom at the City Arms Hotel. Bloom sometimes pushed her in her bathchair. Bloom justifies his equanimity by thinking of his own youth. He meditates on schemes for wealth through various inventions and land reclamation. He lists several Irish and foreign places. He imagines himself as a gentleman farmer, magistrate, and the owner of "Bloom Cottage." He outlines a civic role for himself. He proves his rectitude from youth, citing his conversion, his advocacy for political theories, and his presence at a torchlight procession. He calculates how he would pay for his country residence. He considers "rapid but insecure means to opulence," like a wireless telegraph to transmit race results, finding treasure, or a Spanish prisoner's donation. He also considers industrial channels like waste reclamation and hydroelectric power. He meditates on these schemes to alleviate fatigue. He fears committing homicide or suicide during sleep. His final meditations are on a unique advertisement. He unlocks a drawer, revealing Milly's copybook with diagrams, photographs of Queen Alexandra and Maud Branscombe, a Yuletide card, sealing wax, pennibs, a sandglass, a sealed prophecy, a bazaar ticket, a letter from Milly, a cameo brooch and scarfpin, Martha Clifford's letters, a cryptogram, a press cutting on corporal punishment, a pink ribbon, rubber preservatives, envelopes, Austro-Hungarian coins, lottery coupons, a magnifying glass, erotic photocards, a recipe, a stamp, a chart of his body measurements, and a prospectus for a rectal remedy addressed (erroneously) to Mrs. L. Bloom. He adds a fourth letter from Martha Clifford to this collection. He reflects on his magnetic appeal to women. The second drawer contains Bloom's birth certificate, an endowment assurance policy (naming Milly), a bank passbook, a certificate of stock, cemetery dockets, and his father's deedpoll changing his name from Virag to Bloom. Other objects include a daguerreotype of Rudolf and Leopold Virag, a haggadah book, a photocard of the Queen's Hotel in Ennis (his father's), and an envelope addressed "To My Dear Son Leopold." These evoke memories of his father's melancholia and suicide. Bloom feels remorse for disrespecting certain Jewish beliefs. He recalls his father narrating migrations. He notes his father's eccentricities in old age. He finds consolation in his financial documents. He imagines a hypothetical descent into mendicancy and destitution. He considers departure desirable due to cohabitation issues and the attractive character of various localities. He ponders the signs for navigation. He imagines a public advertisement for his disappearance. He considers "Everyman or Noman" as his binomial denomination. He thinks of himself as a wanderer, eventually returning as an "estranged avenger." He considers what would make his return irrational. He then re-enters his house, his head hitting a timber angle. He notices the furniture has been rearranged (by Molly for Boylan). He sees a sofa, a majolica table, and a piano with "Love's Old Sweet Song" open. He places an incense cone in the candlestick, which emits "aromatic oriental incense." He observes other objects on the mantelpiece: a stopped clock, a dwarf tree, and an embalmed owl. He sees his own "solitary... mutable... man" image in the mirror, reflecting his resemblance to his parents. He sees his books inverted on the shelves. He reflects on the need for order. He removes his collar and unbuttons his clothes. He touches a bee sting scar and extracts a shilling from his waistcoat pocket. He compiles his budget for the day. He removes his boots and socks, picks at a toenail, and inhales its odor with satisfaction, recalling childhood habits. His ultimate ambition is to purchase a thatched bungalow, "Bloom Cottage," with various amenities. He envisions himself as a gentleman farmer and a resident magistrate. He outlines a course of action based on justice. He recalls his early rectitude and political involvement. He calculates the cost of the residence and various means to acquire wealth. He considers projects like the reclamation of land and the exploitation of hydroelectric power. He justifies his meditations as a way to alleviate fatigue. He fears homicide or suicide during sleep. His final meditations are on a unique advertisement. He inventories the contents of his first and second drawers, filled with personal documents and mementos. He reflects on his father's suicide and his own past. He contemplates the cycles of life and death, concluding that human life is infinitely perfectible in some ways, but limited by "generic conditions." Stephen affirms his significance as a "conscious rational animal." Bloom apprehends this substantially. They stand at the kitchen door, Stephen with his hat, Bloom with a candle. A cat enters. They emerge into the garden, observing the stars. Bloom meditates on cosmic evolution and involution. He finds the problems of inhabitability of planets and redemption "of a different order of difficulty." He considers various features of constellations and their influence. His logical conclusion is that it was "not a heaventree, not a heavengrot." He accepts the aesthetic value of the spectacle. He considers astrological influences. He notes the "special affinities" between the moon and woman. They see a lamp shining in Molly's bedroom window. Bloom tries to explain the mystery of his wife, denoted by the lamp. They then urinate together in the garden, with their backs to each other. They observe a shooting star. Bloom inserts a key into the lock to unlock the door. They take leave of each other at the door. They hear the church bells. Bloom reflects on his defunct companions. He sees the daybreak. He returns indoors, accidentally hitting his head on a sideboard in the rearranged parlor. He examines the piano, the flowers, the ashtray, and the music for "Love's Old Sweet Song" open on the piano. He then sits down, extracts a cone of incense, lights it, and it emits "aromatic oriental incense." He looks at the clock stopped at 4:46 a.m. in 1896. He looks at an embalmed owl and a dwarf tree. He sees his own "solitary... mutable... man" reflection in the mirror, and the inverted books on the shelves. He puts away his clothes, noting the damage to his sock. He removes his boots and socks, picks his toenail, and inhales its odor with satisfaction. His ultimate ambition is to buy a specific country residence. He envisions himself as a successful, respected gentleman farmer. He contemplates the ways to acquire wealth. He justifies his meditations for sleep. He fears murder or suicide. His final thoughts are on a perfect advertisement. He catalogues the contents of his drawers, including letters, photos, and personal items. He adds a fourth letter from Martha Clifford. He reflects on his attraction to women. He lists his financial documents and his father's name change. He recalls his father's melancholia and suicide, feeling remorse for past disrespect of beliefs. He thinks about his father's migrations and habits. He reflects on his hypothetical descent into poverty. He considers departure from Dublin. He lists attractive places in Ireland and abroad. He considers navigation signs. He imagines an advertisement for his disappearance. He accepts "Everyman or Noman" as his name. He foresees himself wandering, then returning as an "estranged avenger." He questions the rationality of such a return. He considers the inertia of staying. He thinks about the advantages of an occupied bed. He recapitulates the day's events, from breakfast to Nighttown, as a series of "rites." He wonders about the "brief sharp unforeseen heard loud lone crack" he heard. He wonders "Who was M'Intosh?" He finally comprehends "Where was Moses when the candle went out?" He silently enumerates the day's "imperfections." He recalls his father's face. He sees Molly's clothes, including new hose, violet garters, and large drawers, on a trunk. He removes his remaining clothes and gets into bed. He encounters "new clean bedlinen, additional odours, the presence of a human form, female, hers, the imprint of a human form, male, not his, some crumbs, some flakes of potted meat." He smiles, reflecting that everyone imagines himself first, but is always last in an infinite series. He lists Molly's past lovers. He reflects on Boylan's vigor and impressionability. He feels envy and jealousy, but also abnegation and equanimity. He justifies his sentiments by considering the "preordained frangibility of the hymen" and grammatical transitions. These reflections converge on "Satisfaction at the ubiquity... of adipose anterior and posterior female hemispheres." He experiences "an approximate erection" and kisses Molly's rump. This is followed by "silent contemplation" and "proximate erection." He then narrates parts of his day to Molly, omitting Martha, the pub brawl, and Gerty, but including Leah, supper at Wynn's, and the "Sweets of Sin" book, and Stephen's collapse. He notes the limitations of their conjugal rights and mental intercourse since Milly's puberty. He identifies the "upcast reflection of a lamp" moving above their thoughts. They lie at an angle of 45 degrees. He is "the childman weary, the manchild in the womb." He thinks of a long list of sailors. He then falls asleep, hearing a clock cooing "Cuckoo."

**Chapter 18:**
Molly Bloom begins a long, unpunctuated internal monologue, reflecting on her life, primarily her sexual and emotional experiences. She thinks about Bloom's unusual request for breakfast in bed and his past pretensions with Mrs. Riordan. She dismisses his intelligence, contrasting him with more attractive men. She recalls his recent secretive letter-writing, suspecting an affair. She speculates on her own desirability and the possibility of taking a young lover. She remembers her past sexual encounters, particularly with Lieutenant Mulvey in Gibraltar, which was her first kiss. She thinks of her current affair with Blazes Boylan, recalling his recent visit and their intimacy. She acknowledges her own body, her physical desires, and her disdain for modesty. She thinks about her daughter Milly, now grown up, and the difficulty of motherhood. She reflects on the hypocrisy of men and society's expectations of women. She recalls past rows with Bloom, including one about politics where he made her cry, and another about a dancing master. She thinks about Bloom's odd habits and his tendency to be unlucky. She considers her own singing talent and how it has been underutilized. She remembers her first real kiss and the excitement it caused. She ponders her own age and attractiveness, comparing herself to other women. She thinks about Bloom's attempts to make money and his various schemes, which she largely dismisses as foolish. She recalls her father, Major Tweedy, and his military career in Gibraltar. She thinks about the clothes she wears and her dissatisfaction with her current wardrobe. She remembers dancing with Boylan and the physical sensation of his touch. She continues to reflect on her sexual desires and fantasies, wishing for a man to "take me sometime when hes there and kiss me in his arms." She thinks about her confession to Father Corrigan and her lack of true remorse. She remembers her experiences with men in Gibraltar and elsewhere, noting their aggressive pursuit of women. She thinks about her weight and her body. She recalls Bloom's compliments and his "gentle" nature, but also his perceived lack of passion. She contrasts herself with other women, believing she has more character and understanding of men. She thinks about the limitations imposed on women and her own desire for freedom. She remembers Bloom's proposal on Howth Head, and her "yes" that sealed their fate. She thinks about her own sensuality and the beauty of nature. She ends her monologue with a powerful, repeated affirmation of "yes," embracing life, love, and her own desires.
